This was FANTASTIC! I made it for a tapas dinner party and it went over famously. I followed the advice of others and used gingerale in place of the club soda. Very addictive! Makes for a good party! Thank you!!!
I am not a Sangria drinker, but I loved this recipe! I mixed with diet sprite and thought it was a great refreshing summer drink!
I used merlot, limeade and a couple packets of splenda. Just a splash of diet sprite when serving. Excellent. Best sangria.

This is definitely the best sangria I have ever had (and I have tried many)! I made two batches, one with a cabernet and one with a chardonnay, both were fabulous! I didn't use the sliced fruit suggested or the cherries, instead I cut up oranges and granny smith apples into bite size pieces. I added the sugar as suggested, but left out the carbonated water. This drink was the hit of the party, everyone wanted the recipe! Thanks HJacoby!

This was SO good! The best sangria I've had. We made o.j. cubes so it wouldn't dilute the flavour and it was perfect! I also used Sprite rather than club soda. Will definitely make it again this summer.
I used Limeade instead of the Lemonade and Splenda instead of sugar. For the soda water, I used Diet Sprite. Everyone loved it! I will definitely make this again.
Great Recipe. I made it for a 4th of July party and it was a great Hit!
Loved it! This was my first attempt at making Sangria and it was excellent. My neighbor, who makes her own, said this was even better than hers!
The very best Sangria!! I double the recipe and used Grand Marnier instead of triple sec, mmmmmm. Didn't need any suger. Thank you my new favorite drink
This sangria was excellent. I omitted the sugar, the cherries, added peach schnapps and gingerale instead of carbonated water. A summer keeper! Thanks HJ!
SCRAP THE CHERRIES AND ADD AN APPLE... EXCELLENT RECIPE
Love this drink, but I substitute the orange juice for cranberry juice. it cuts the citrus tastle a little and makes the drink oh so close to those served at the Olive Garden.
Simply Amazing. Was a complete hit! Even my friends that were not big fans of sangria loved it. I dreamed about it for days after trying to make excuses to make it again...hehehe.

Great if you have everything, if you don't and need to make some compromises it's still flavorful. I did not have lemonade concentrate but a can of tropicana lemonade did well. Ginger ale was also a welcome addition in lieu of carbonated water. You can really make this recipe work if you taste as you add. We loved the result!
The brandy and triple sec add a flavorful twist (and some kick!) to this recipe. I used a cabernet and omited the sugar and cherries for a tangy, dry sangria.
excellent! i nixed the cherries and added sliced fruit to the individual glasses.
Awesome... had a girl's movie & sangria night... everybody loved it!

This recipe is very similar to one that I use for holiday parties and other events...Its great and always a big hit. The only thing I do different is substitute white rum for the brandy, double the oj and omit the leamonade concentrate, and add pineapple slices instead of cherries!!! The great thing about sangria is that you can really make it your own by adding a variety of different ingredients!
FABULOUS! Makes drinking large quantities way too easy.

Outstanding! I prepared this to go along side Thanksgiving dinner. It was a big hit - which is especially noteworthy because about half my guests were of Spanish heritage. I doubled the recipe and added a lot more fruit than is mentioned above, inlcuding peaches, pineapple, grapes, 4 different frozen berries and Mandarin oranges. I skipped the carbonated water and used Ginger Ale.

This is excellent, It's the best Sangria I ever had, and it's so refreshing. I made it for a party once and Everyone said it's SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO GOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! They Wanted the Recipe, thanks HJacoby!!!

Made this for the first time for a office/holiday lunch. I originally doubled the recipe and it went so fast I had to make another triple recipe. Everyone loved it. It was the hit of the luncheon. I used gingel ale instead of club soda. I also added apples and included the optional sugar.
Great recipe. Served it at our supper club's Mexican night and everyone seemed to like it.
This was really nice. Not a five star for me, but clearly 4 star. Now....as we had more and more sangria, the rating certainly went up and up! Cheers!
We really liked this, it was served at a mom's night out party. I used rum instead of brandy because I had rum in the cupboard!
This Sagria recipe is great! We wanted something to go with the beer at our wedding reception and I found this recipe. It was a huge success!!!
Oustanding- be sure to habe some munchies available because this stuff was potent! We found ourselves digging for the cherries out of the pitcher... thanks!
Loved it. Next time I would chop up the fruit more. Also I omited the frozen lemonade and added more lemon juice and sugar. I also added a little bit of lemon zest.

Definitely the best! I used chianti, ginger ale, and apricot brandy because we like a sweeter Sangria. Hardly a 'far cry from the real thing'- Sangria originated in Spain, not Mexico! I made 2 recipes, and every drop of it was gone at the end of the party. I'd call that a success :-), Will definitely make again.
Served this at Easter dinner. Was a big hit. Finished quickly. As per another reveiw, I used Rum in place of Brandy and Peach Schnapps in place of triple sec and 7-up in place water.No added sugar.
Makes the best Sangria I've ever had!
I thought this recipe was the most awful thing I have ever tasted. I go to Mexico every year and this was a far cry from the 'real thing'; absolutely nasty, I definitely do not recommend this!

This was a huge hit at my last summer party. I made two pitchers and it disappeared in no time. I did refrigerate it overnight as others have suggested which helped make the flavors mix. Will be making again soon. Great recipe.
This is a great recipe for sangria. I used spiced rum in place of the brandy, but other than that followed the recipe exactly. I would recommend making more than one pitcher though. We ran out fast!

This is an amazing recipe. I've never had sangria before and decided that this recipe most appealed to me. I used everything the recipe called for and am I ever glad I did. I let it sit overnight in the fridge and it turned out beautifully. Thanks HJacoby!
I’m from Wisconsin and we make it with brandy and 7up or if we want a little sweeter we’ll us southern comfort, I’ve also seen it made with fireball.

I like using simple syrup much better than sugar. It is smoother and easier. I used really good quality Italian maraschino cherries (2) and that made a big difference over the cheap cherries. They made the cocktail better. I used Breckinridge Bourbon and it is really smooth.

As a simple syrup I used 1 1/2 of white Karo syrup instead of sugar. I also used club soda instead of water, the zest of orange peel instead of the meat of the orange and a little juice from the Marichino cherries. My daughter and I had one as a nightcap last night and it was perfect!!♥️
Great drink.
Great recipe
Muddle the cherry and twist that orange to get oils from the zest in there. Always muddle the cherry. SMH
Delicious!
The best OF recipe. I prefer the simple syrup to sugar cube.
Pretty simple and good.

This is one of the most successful recipes, however it’s too much simple syrup, that kills the palate of a high quality bourbon. I would recommend only 1/2 oz of simple syrup or lesser. But that me. Someone else may find swiftness more
It was very good. Some local bars add some interesting bitters that make it pop, but this is a great starting recipe for an Old Fashioned.
YESSSSS
Nice and simple. 2 tsp simple syrup is too much for me, reduce to 1 tsp. Yum!
I love this recipe! Since I am a wimp, I used 2 sugar cubes, but followed the rest of the recipe to the letter. A perfect 5:00 cocktail!
Added a splash of sprite and it was amazing!!
My husband is a snob where this beverage is concerned and he LOVES this recipe!! It’s perfect!!
I used cherry bitters.
This was the first time I made a cocktail and it was delicious! I learned that 1 jigger is 3 tbsp. I’m excited to keep learning
Yummy!!

Solid recipe. A couple things from the comments: use Bourbon! Not Jameson! Also, this isn’t a “sweet” cocktail. It’s meant to taste like bourbon. Try making your own simple syrup and infuse some dried fruits. I use blueberry. Finally, step up your game with some amarena cherries for garnish.
Delicious!!

This IS the classic version, just be sure to use the highest end liquor you can afford. (I use Makers Mark). Having said that, it makes a very strong drink, so rather than water it down with Sprite or Seven Up, try dipping the rim of the glass in orange juice, then in sugar - then proceeding with the recipe. Some will call it heresy - I call it delicious!
Perfect!
Delicious, except I muddled the fruit first in simple syrup, add ice, then whiskey! Garnish with another orange slice!
Yummy! I make my own maraschino cherries and put a teas or two of the juice in the drink. I also make my own simple syrup. Very easy !
While there are many ways to create this simple drink what to me is essential is to use a good rye rather than a bourbon.
Used Demerara sugar cubes instead of the simple syrup and 4 Roses yellow label bourbon. Very tasty and not too sweet.

Not a bad recipe at all. Ensure you are using the "good stuff" as others have mentioned. Makes a world of difference. I typically use a sugar cube and some water with bitters. Also make sure you get large ice cubes for this drink. They dont melt as fast and water it down. I would never use a full orange slice. This isnt a screwdriver. Instead a hint of orange goes a long way with a simple twist of the orange peel over the glass then put the twist in the drink. Also luxardo cherries are a MUCH better choice for this drink. A little pricey but well worth it. As an added bonus if you want this drink smoked, use wood chips on a safe surface, light them on fire with a blowtorch, then place your glass over the wood chips to catch the smoke. While the glass fills with smoke, make your old fashioned and transfer it in to the smoked glass.
Followed recipe. First time used a very old jar of bitters. I bought a new bottle and much better. Used bourbon.

If you are not a whiskey lover this is not the drink for you the bitters and syrup (and cherry and or orange) are not used to cover up the flavor but rather to add to it. If you believe that a Jack and Coke is a cocktail then you probably should stay away from drinks like this. I prefer making this cocktail without the cherry and orange.
My favorite! I always use a sugar cube and pour a little bitters and juice from the maraschino cherries jar over it before crushing it along the bottom of the glass.

loved this recipe!! The only issue is finding the ingredients in a convenient place and correct proportions Would anyone be interested in having a cocktail kit sold in stores with the necessary ingredients?

I used my favs to make this, Bulleit rye whiskey, made my own simple syrup with brown sugar, Angostora bitters, Luxor cherries, twist the skin of a clementine to release the oils and shook it all in a clean jar then poured over an ice sphere. It's very smooth sip by sip. Put your orange slice in there with that cherry and go sit by the fire.
Good beginning. I prefer to add the bitters, raw sugar and club soda to the bottom. I add bourbon and the thick orange slice, then fill the glass with ice cubes. Dangerously good.
I like to muddle the orange, cherry, sugar with the bitters first, and then add the liquor. Stir and add the ice cubes and a splash of club soda to top it off!
I added some grenadine to make it a little sweeter. And sometimes some seltzer.
I made this with angels envy and it was better than I expected
I added a splash of apple cider and it was perfect.

Made with Jack Daniels Tennessee Honey, fantastic! Stronger whiskeys will obviously make it stronger - so for comparison i tried adding a splash of ginger ale - wonderful addition. For color I drizzled in a little cherry juice.
Delicious! I used Jack Daniels and left out the orange.
A great classic cocktail. I used dried stevia and I muddle the
This was my dad's favorite drink when he dined out or when company came. I always wondered as a child what the Angostura bitters were for and now I know.
Very satisfying. I used caster sugar and it works out fine. Don't skip the cherry!

Hi! Y'all made me thirsty! Used what I had on hand. Brandy, brown sugar, "Cherries in Brandy" bought at mall during Holidays {and some of the juice}, squeeze lime and lemon juices, Brandy, and ice. Nummy! Had another sip after sitting a bit, even tastier. I think the Bing cherries make this particular one, plus brown sugar.
I am a bartender and I have never made an old fashion like this.

I love muddle old fashions.When my kids were little and going wild my husband would come home and make the best muddle old fashion using CC.I go down south and very few bartenders don't know what I'm talking about so I give them the recipe.Mash the fruit real good,add a dash of bitters,a 1/2 tsp of sugar,the CC and the ice cubes.Wow it's great.

Wisconsin Style Brandy Old Fashion Sweet 1/2 to 1 teaspoon of sugar, four drops bitters, orange slice with out rind, and cherry in bottom of glass. Muddle. Add two Oz favorite brandy. Fill glass with crushed ice. Add splash of seven-up and stir. Garnish as desired. Yum
Good recipe. I like it made with Scotch. Be sure to use "the good stuff!"

This sounds like a pretty standard old fashioned, and the way I used to make it. Now I use all fresh fruit, and it is the best ever. I combine several dashes of bitters, a fresh cherry (cut in half, remove bit, then squeeze some juice into glass and add remaining cherry). A slice of orange (a small amount if the juice is squeezed in, then twist the rind to get the oils and essence). Several ounces of bourbon (or rye, etc, but I love Makers) sugar/simple syrup (I prefer sugar in the raw or a cube, it will bring good flavor) add a splash of water and stir. You get good bourbon flavor, with just a touch of the sweet and the juice to cut it. If you are making something like an old fashioned you need to taste the bourbon, if you don't want to taste it go get a vodka red bull, or a wine cooler.
For an added twist use a little splash of olive juice, if your into a sweet and sour taste.

I thought this was going to grow hair on my chest! This was so super strong!!! I bought some Jameson whiskey for a dinner recipe and had some leftover and decided to try a classic cocktail. This tasted like straight whiskey on ice. I tried to modify it by doubling and then tripeling the simple syrup, doubling the oranges and squeazing them, and then adding in a couple of splashes of the cherry juice from the jar as others suggested. It made it more palateable then, but it still tasted too strong to drink. I wish I wouldn't have spent the extra money now on the bottle of bitters now. It couldn't be tasted anyway. I don't know what to think? Maybe, I just don't like whiskey? Hmmm
Amazing drink and my stand by selection. If Don Draper loves them, why can't you?

In Wisconsin, brandy or Whiskey old fashioneds are made at every bar. I prefer the brandy. Often the cherry/ies are muddled in the bottom of the glass. To simplify we use 7up/Sprite rather than water and simple syrup. Some people prefer using sour mix instead. Stores around here also sell Old Fashioned mix. Bottoms up.

I'm a native Louisvillian and using any thing but Ky. bourbon is a travesty! Makers Mark is my choice. I like bitters and use about 6 good shakes. To sweeten it up use a small squirt of agave syrup. Swish it around the bottom of the glass, Add ice, 2 oz. Makers Mark. Garnish with maraschino cherry plus a little juice from the bottle and slice of orange. (May sqeeze a wedge of orange.) Be prepared for a second one!
My favorite cocktail, but is prefer Southern Comfort with a splash of club soda

My father had one of these when he came home from work. When we do the same it is in his honor. I keep a jar of orange slices marinating in the simple syrup in the refrigerator for this drink. We use Ancient Age bourbon which is what he used. According to the reviewer in The New York Times Ancient Age is just as good as the top shelf brands. The aroma is so evocative of my dad's favorite drink and so 5:30ish.
The brandy old fashion is THE drink of northern Wisconsin supper clubs.
delish! i used club soda instead of water, instead for a little bit of fizz and doubled up on the orange slices.
Delcious! Recommend Red Stag by Jim Beam. It is infused with Cherry already.

Excellent and classic! It really makes so much difference when it's made from scratch. My only substitution: I used rye whiskey instead of bourbon. I've always preferred my Old Fashioned with rye, not sure why . . . maybe it's the slightly drier taste. Try it sometime!

This was my late father-in-law's drink of choice. Definitely use "the good stuff" when making these and while you don't always need the orange slice just like the Manhattan the cherry is always necessary.
It's a sweeter change from ice cubes. very enjoyable.

this is the classic recipe. It is missing something though. You will need 2 orange slices & 2 cherries. When you put the sugar cube/simple syrup & bitters in the glass, also add one orange slice and one cherry. This all gets muddled (squished) together, topped with ice and then the whiskey. Garnish as directed. DELICIOUS!
A classic cocktail. Good with any of the above mentioned spirits but also enjoyed with brandy as a twist. I prefer the rye old-fashioned.

This is my favorite drink in the winter except I substitute marachino cherry juice for the simple syrup and brandy for the whiskey. I also squeeze an orange wedge and add sour such as 50/50 or Squirt. Delicious.
To make it more palatable (for those who don't like straight booze) a splash of club soda or 7 up is great!
It’s called a Cape Codder.

For those who don't enjoy this drink some tips i've discovered. You can easily use margarita mix instead of lemon or even sour mix. I've found most pre made sour mixes are not made well and while margarita mix is arguably similar if not the same thing it does seem to make a difference. For the raspberry-flavored liqueur you really should use Chambord specifically. It's expensive but maybe start with the nips if you can find them but it makes a world of difference. Cheaper alternatives like razmataz do not have the specific flavor profile needed. Also, this could be me but it needs to be ice cold! if it gets warm in any way blegh. Pretty much this is a raspberry long island iced tea, easy to make and a punch in the face for sure.
Other than that if you don't like it then all good. We all have different tastes and can change any cocktail we want to fit it. This is the traditional recipe tho, play around a bit.

Pity the poor Margarita. The original concoction was a relative of the Sidecar: brandy, Cointreau & lemon juice served in sugar rimmed glass. The Margarita substituted tequila, with lime and salt being the traditional accompaniments. Then the mongrelization began. When I came upon the Margarita in the 70’s, it had been reduced to cheap tequila, bar mix and a pound of ice to be processed in a blender: an adult Slurpee. Follow the above recipe as if your life depended on it. Use a quality tequila, Cointreau and fresh squeezed lime juice. Triple Sec has always been used by bars as a cheap substitute for Cointreau, but they don’t taste the same. As far as turnbot’s use of an eggwhite, you are on your own. A Margarita is a cocktail, not the breakfast of champions.

This recipe is not bad: my "perfect margarita" calls for only half an ounce of triple sec (as opposed to 1 once; that much will override the great tequila flavour). Speaking of tequila: your margarita will be as good as the tequila you buy! Avoid the "well-brand" tequilas: for an affordable yet tasty tequila, get Cazadores or El Jimedor reposado. I'm not a fan of "straight up" style margaritas, so I'll always have mine with lots of rocks (ice), or blended. If you want a really frothy, truly PERFECT margarita... Before shaking, throw in half an egg white into your shaker! You'll never go back - trust me!

My favorite drink, with or without the coconut rum and with crushed ice or ice cubes, doesn't matter, It's Mmmmm Gooood!!
Very good. Also drank this on the rocks. Used Capri Sun since I didn't have any orange juice and it was quite tasty. I can see making a huge pitcher of these for a party. Pretty color to boot.

These drinks were pretty good - recently came back from the Dominican and they tasted exactly like the way they made them there. Next time I'd probably increase the coconut rum and decrease the ice but overall, was a very good recipe.

VERY good!! I served these at a "ladies night" party last week, everyone loved them! I added a bit more coconut rum to make them more tropical. They reminded me of Hawaiian Punch. WARNING: make sure you get the BIG bottles of rum!!! You won't want to stop with just one!!
I used to work at Applebee's and they also add banana liquer. Very tasty this way too!
Good recipe. I like it a little stronger so I increased the rum by 1/2 ounce.
Excellent, very tropical drink. I found this recipe a few weeks ago and have made it several times since. I originally made it using the blender, but now prefer it on the rocks.
Great drink on a hot day! Next time I am going to cut down on the ice. I might try 1/2 cup of ice.
I like mine "on the rocks" so I don't blend it all together, but serve on ice, instead. Great mix/blend of ingredients, wonderful taste. Love it! Thanks for sharing!

Very yummy, I did these on the rocks since I am not into icee drinks anymore. They were yummy. I drank one and feeling it. I did 3 oz oj 3 oz pj. 1 Shot captains morgans , 1 shot malibu, 1/2 shot grenadine. Perfect!!!!!!
Excellent drink. I made if for the Survivor finale and now my wife wants a pitcher for a party she is having. Sweet and smooth.
Blend it up in the stockroom and top it with an umbrella for a girl drink drunk! Yum Yum Yum!
Add a shot of Dark Rum on top of the drink after it is in the glass just like red lobster wonderfull
We enjoyed these over rocks, with a tad less grenadine and a tad more coconut rum. Very nice and "islandy".
I used coconut flavored drink mix in a can instead of coconut rum. Didn't bother to double up on the regular rum either. Love it.
These were the absolute perfect drink for our pool party! Everyone loved them and was asking for the recipe. We garnished the drink with pineapple & orange slices. I highly recommend this drink!
This drink was great! The perfect beverage for a summer cookout.
Tasting this was like being back on my Bahana cruise again. Awesome, thanks for sharing!
Great summer drink. Easy,tasty and refreshing!
Like being on vacation in my own backyard!!! Will make again and again and *hick-up* again.
great drink for when the girls come over for the evening!!
We are hooked!! Drink these every chance we get. Have served them for cookouts, and have taken them to pool parties. What a hit!
great drunk, I mean drink! I could drink these all night, you hardly taste the alcohol.
This was a good drink! Not overly sweet at all. Definitely will serve at my upcoming party!
this is definately a great drink, of all fruity drinks that I have ever tasted this one is the best.
This is very, very good. I am already on my second drink. Very fruity and refreshing.
Very very yummy!! I didn't blend mine, I served them "on the rocks." Everyone, young and old, enjoyed the drink.
No. It was perfect
This drink was soooo good! Making for 3rd time tonight.

I made this for a Luau and people raved. One person who had recently been to Hawaii said this Mai Tai was better than any he had there and thought he should give this recipe to the resort he went to for their use.
Added a splash of Margarita mix, it needed a bit more acidity. 😋
Taste of the Tropics..

It’s important to note that this is not the original Trader Vic recipe which is made with lime, orgeat, orange curaçao, and simple syrup. I like mine with just a dollop of maraschino cherry juice and a big chunk of mint. This is considered the Hawaiian Mai Tai, which is the post-1953 version made popular by Elvis. Decent drink but not a real Mai Tai.

This was easy and delicious! I like that it uses OJ instead of orange liquor as it isn't over the top strong for our group of older adults. Next time I would make my own grenadine (sugar, pom juice, lemon) to eliminate all the preservatives in store bought.

This was awesome!!! Reminded me and my husband of our honeymoon in Hawaii! I wouldn't change a thing. Bonus: We happened to have all the ingredients on hand, even the little drink umbrellas, so no trips to the store.

It was really good! Simple to make although Grenadine wasn’t as easy to find as I thought it would be. I had better success just free pouring than following the exact recipe. You definitely have to watch how much Malibu you put in because the coconut overpowers the sweeetness and tartness of the drink. I’ll be making more for sure!
Delicious
excellent
No changes made. Will definitely make again.
Change: Did not have coconut rum, so just used all spice rum. Very good! Note: Measurement for 1/2 a jigger in ounces is wrong in the recipe. Should be 0.75 ounces.
Delicious!
Delicious, couldn't find the branded rum that was listed so I grabbed spiced Captain Morgan and Malibu. A lovely tropical drink that packs a punch.
My husband said he feels like he's drinking Hawaiian Tropic sunblock. That's his highest compliment! Thanks for making us feel like we are on vacation during COVID-19.
Awesome
I used 1 to 1 ratio for the Malibu and the Captain Morgan. Plus I added 3/4 ounce of lime juice. It was fantastic.
Super yummyI! made it at a friend's house, minus the grenadine. (Cherry allergic) I will definitely make it again with the Pomegranate grenadine I have at home.
Delicious Mai Tai Recipe!! This is my go-to, so simple and good!
I'm out of ice today but it still tastes darn good!
I give it 5 stars. Cause I really liked it but tasted more like a Rum Punch, not Mai Tai
Super simple and super yummy! Great recipe to keep on hand.
Used one pack of Truvia per glass instead of simple syrup
this was awesome tropical greatness!
I like to mix the juice, spiced rum, and coconut rum in a pitcher. Then I add Grenadine after it is poured in a glass over ice. A splash of Dark rum on the top is a nice little addition as well.
Well balanced & delicious!
Sooo good

Perhaps not as authentic as some might enjoy, but tasty, simple, and scaleable for varying desires. I have made this a few times now over the last couple weeks, the girls loved it. Poured over ice and into travel mugs or into the fridge in a glass jar its nice for emergency applications. I am using regular white rum instead of coconut, mostly because that is what I keep on hand here.
I couldn't care less if these are "authentic". They are boozy and tropical and delicious and DANGEROUS.

I’m not a huge drinker or alcohol, but I do enjoy fruity tropical type drinks. I love pineapple juice and orange juice. I bought captain morgans coconut rum and had spiced rum from the country of Grenada. I wasn’t impressed with it. All I tasted was the alcohol and minimal juice flavor.
This was yummy my guests loved it .
This was yummy my guests loved it .
Very good...easy to make an entire picture full.
Wife loved it. Try adding 1 drop of pure almond extract. Adds a nice nutty earthiness to it. But only one drop.
Big hit at the pool party! These were so good!!! The coconut rum was so good
Delicious! My new fav mixed drink. I used good quality juices and rum.

I would never add almeretto , not do I add much grenadine(too sweet and sugary). I do add Orgeat syrup which is the only way to make a real Mai Tai. This is not readily available most times so I get why people add other stuff. But if you ever can make it with the syrup you will taste a world of difference.
Awesome
I make these just as the recipe says and adjust the amount of alcohol depending on my mood...I prefer this recipe over any that include sour mix or triple sec. It is so easy!
Easy and tasty! Exactly as written, Ingredient list is simple, this is my Friday night treat
Great recipe - tastes just like the ones at Don the Beachcomer's in Kona, Hawaii!
I Converted it into a virgin Mai-Tai, that is, non-alcoholic. Most of the kids liked it, and it was a little like a Shirley Temple.
Yum-my!

A big hit at our luau. Used regular Bacardi Rum and Malibu. Left out the grenadine. We had tried out the authentic recipe (with Jamaican rum, orgeat, etc) but it was not our thing (syrupy alcohol flavor). Dangerously delicious!
Good recipe!!!!
good and easy.
It is very delicious!
Tasted perfect! I added a lemon slice too...
I did make equal parts reg rum and coco rum, but think i can cut back on the cocnut rum... or increase the regular rum. :P Next attempt i think im going to try Tattoo in place of the regular rum.
Made it, nice however added half on ounce of velvet fellernum. Ahhhhhhh heaven.
Ooh la la!!! Definitely a keeper!!!

Tasty! I made a kiddie cocktail substituting ginger ale for the alcohol. The kids loved those too! I will use equal parts of spiced rum and coconut rum next time like others have suggested for a slightly stronger coconut flavor.
Absolutely delicious! Will continue to make these thanks!!!!
Simple and easy and delightful. Multiplied x8= perfection
Came out great! Thank you for the recipe
Dangerously delicious! Made it exactly as listed. Definite keeper!!
Delicious, almost as good as at the Outrigger in Waikiki!
A hit with everybody we've shared it with. We also doubled the coconut rum. This is going to get a lot of use poolside.

I set out to buy Trader Vic's Mai Tai mixer, but my local market didn't have it. I didn't have the flavored, but I did have both Bacardi Gold and Bacardi Superior. I mixed the two. I'm very happy with this recipe and will never need a mixer again.
Tastes just like all the mai tai's I've had on vacations! And very easy to make. Agree with everyone else to add equal amounts of the rums... Very tasty! Thanks for sharing.
Great for a girl's night in drink option!!
This was very easy. I added triple sec and it was delicious. I put the drink into a pineapple to make it look Tiki style. A big hit and very potent!
Made exactly as stated and yummo!!! Have made this my go-to drink of choice. Very quick and easy to whip up. Lovely and fruity and not over powering with alcohol which I love.
Yeah Baby!
I'm drinking this right now and I love it. I'm new to making cocktails (but not to drinking them! ) and this is my second time making this one. Delicious and easy.

Good recipe!!! 4 stars until I added my own touches. I added Amaretto for that almond flavor, equaled the spiced and coconut rum as some reviewers suggested and a hint of simple syrup. Was a hit at the family Luau. Went faster than the frozen pina colada daiquiris. Thanks for the recipe!!!
Favorite summertime drink!
Not too bad, my wife said, but this version is nothing like the Original 1933 Mai Tai version.
Easy and delicious. It was a crowd-pleaser at my birthday party.
perfect!!!
a very nice summer drink recipe.
Tastes like the ones in Hawaii

Simple recipe, but didn't care for the taste which was very disappointing since I made a whole pitcher! Don't know if it was the coconut rum, but something gave it a funky taste ~ and everything was just purchased to make these. I will continue my quest for a good one!
Added splash of dark rum on top (very fruity if you don't) and my parents who LOVE mai tai's said this was the best they have ever had!

I don't care that this is not an "authentic" Mai Tai - it is a pretty darn good drink - whatever it really is! I love the hint of spiciness from the spiced rum. I do want to try it again, this time adding the Amaretto & fresh lime as suggested by others. I do think that there's definitely enough coconut rum & would not add more. We were camping on the beach in the central California coast & as written, this refreshing cocktail fit right in!
Fabulous, easy... love the addition of coconut rum. Brings me back to sitting by pool in Hawaii.

Great drink! Mai Tai's are one of our favorite drinks. I have made many many versions and this one is a great version. I do think it is a MUST to add amaretto in this as well to get the almond flavor that Mai Tai's have. Also half of a freshly squeezed lime is great in it as well! I like to add the lime and amaretto in it to make a more authentic tasting Mai Tai, but this recipe is for sure still great as written. Thanks for the recipe! This will be added to the list of favorites.
I was looking for a drink to have out by the pool, on a warm summer day, this is it!! It not to sweet, and very refreshing.
its ok nothing special
Excellent, makes a great Mai Tai. I added an extra ounce of coconut rum to balance the taste. Great recipe!

This drink is awesome...takes you right to the islands! I agree with other viewers to use equal parts of spiced rum and coconut rum. I made enough for 2 so I used 2 jiggers of each and a 6 oz can of pineapple juice, 1/2 cup of oj and only 1 t. of grenadine. Absolutely delicious!

Great drink! I made exactly as recipe stated. The two rums are what make this drink. I made for our memorial weekend BBQ - big hit! Not a poor man's drink though - to buy all the ingredients gets pretty costly - but worth it for something different!
This is the perfect island drink! I added a bit more rum to boost it! Thanks for this great mai tai recipe!
AWESOME! We did, however, increase the coconut rum to 1 full jigger. We will definitely be making this again.
Fruity and refreshing. Takes me back to the Caribbean!
Excellent recipe! We made a whole pitcher and they are all gone already :(
This was delicious and easy to try being 1 serving. I had everything on hand except spiced rum, so I used Myers dark rum. It was worth making another.
I made this with Coyote Moons, NY Twisted Sister and cut the sugar in half and it was amazing!
Love it. This packs quite a punch!
I made this as written 2 different times with 2 different red wines as written and one without sugar and it was disgusting. Would never recommend this recipe.

Amazing! I did tweak it to my liking tho. Who knew that this amount of rum would’ve worked so well? Anyways I’ve come to the realization that it does not matter what kind of wine you use!! Sweet, dry, red or white! Use whatever but just adjust the sugar content to your liking. I also added Cointreau, grenadine & 7up! Great!

Exactly what I was hoping for on a humid afternoon. I did change it up just a tad, I was concerned about it being overly boozy because of other reviewers. I added a can of sparkling water just to try to thin it a touch. Seemed to help. Also added a little less sugar just because I ran out. This is fab and sweet and refreshing.
Best Sangria I ever had
Best sangria ever! It is the most requested recipe in my arsenal

YesYesYes!!! I was so nervous about making a good sangria for the 1st time during our Covid lockdown Easter and it was AWESOME!! Not a large gathering for Easter, but my husband, and my 2 adult kids that are here and I were thrilled how delicious this turned out. • Used the Kraken Spiced Rum • made a 1/4C simple syrup bc some comments said sugar was a little hard to dissolve • Added all kinds of fruit, including frozen mixed fruit to soak over night • Next morning added fresh fruit • Topped each glass with a splash of ginger ale We tasted it right when I made it and ?? whew! A kick!! But by the next day this drink tasted like the BEST sangria, and I knew immediately I should have made more lol!! Will be remaking this recipe real soon!!

I've been making this recipe since 2008 and it's always a hit! Over time, I've adjusted the recipe to use 3/4 cup of white rum (vice what the recipe calls for) and I use a red blend of wine (gives it a more balanced and smooth taste).
Great for parties! I doubled the recipe and only used 1/4 cup sugar. Don't like it too sweet.

I have been wanting to make this recipe up as our local fav Mexican has a wicked Sangria which we often enjoy with our friends. So for a Friday easy dinner at their place I made this with tequila rather than brandy, all the citrus and apple. Then threw in strawberries, because I had 3 packs in the fridge. It only got an hour in the fridge so hadn't really developed fully. But sure went down well, the dogs loved the apple pieces, and even ate the orange peel. I need to make again.
used pinot noir wine and only 1 cup of Malibu coconut rum
I loved this! However, I let it marinate in the fridge for 12 hours and did not add the sugar. (I don't like overly sweet drinks). It was delicious!
It was too much rum and way too much OJ. It tasted a little like medicine.

This is the worst recipe for Sangria I ever made and I've made plenty. Think about it: 1 bottle of wine, 1-1/2 cups of rum tempered by only 1/2 cup of OJ. I've been to Spain and never encountered sangria like this.
Very strong, but very good drink! A few of my friends cut it with sprite, because they found it too strong. Would make again!
Favorite class sangria recipe, I can drink the whole pitcher on my front porch watching the corn grow.
This was a big hit with my book club-not a drop left! The only change I made was to decrease the rum to one cup: we needed our senses because we still had to discuss the book! Muy delicioso!
It was excellent! I used organic cane sugar and melted it with half of the orange juice first. Also used organic orange juice, and citrus fruits.
I added some gingerale to mine to make it go a bit further. We all liked it.
This was a very good recipe, very close to what you get in Spain. The only thing I would change is add more fruit and a little less rum, maybe a cup instead of a cup and a half.
Turned out perfect!
Everybody at the party love it
Delish!

I made this for an outdoor party; it was super-easy and everyone enjoyed it. I used blackberry merlot and spiced rum. I misread the recipe and thought it called for only 1/2 cup of rum … I actually used 3/4 cup and that was plenty, especially since I now see a lot of reviewers are complaining that the rum is overpowering. Also, in my opinion this doesn't need any sugar at all. So 4 stars because of too much rum and sugar, but after cutting back on those ingredients I would give it 5 stars. Also, I made ice cubes with fruit-flavored sparkling water to keep the mixture cold without diluting the flavor too much.
This has been by far the best Sangria I have ever had!
One of my guests said this was the best sangria she ever had which is not bad considering it was a gathering of people who had spent weeks hiking through Spain on the Camino de Santiago.
I followed the recipe and it's perfect. I've made it numerous times and have shared the recipe with a few friends.

This was wonderful and very authentic. It was strong but didn't taste boozy. I used spiced rum and used some seltzer to cut it. As with many things it was better the next day and the few days after :) I will be using this again
I made it as is and have remade it every time I need Sangria for a umber

I made this last Fourth of July, and it was a huge hit. I ended up having to make three batches for just six people. I used Marques de Caceras Cranzia tempranillo with overproofed Wray and Nephew rum as the alcoholic bases, and they interacted quite well with each other. The thing is, it didn't even taste very alcoholic. It really snuck up on all of us. However, if you're going to go the tempranillo route, I do not recommend going the riserva or gran riserva route, or with any well-oaked wine for that matter. You're going to want a dry but fruity red. Oak is not going to add to this recipe, because it focuses heavily on fruit flavors.

Very fun drink! As suggested, I cut the rum (3/4 cup) and even still it has a kick! Instead of sugar, I use one cup 7-Up. I often mix the liquids and let it sit overnight and then add the fruit slices a few hours before serving. My friends love it as well and we're all HAPPY!

This is delicious! You can't taste the alcohol at all so it's also super dangerous! I didn't have a lemon, I dumped a can of pineapple chunks in, juice and all. This will be a summer go-to pretty much *every* weekend.

I looked long and hard for a recipe like this one. I remember the classic sangria from my college days when sangria was citrus fruits and red wine chilled. Today there are so many imposters with just about everything in them but the kitchen sink. This recipe brought back wonderful memories and a classic taste. It is on my go-to list forever.
I doubled the recipe and put in a pretty glass spouted container. Huge hit, everyone loved the sangria I paired with Christmas tamales .
Excellent recipe, I did reduce the rum to one cup as some comments said that 1.5 was too much. Aside from that, it was a delicious sangria. I'd make it again.

I made this recipe for thanksgiving. I let the fruit and the sugar soak in the rum for about 6 hours. I used white rum and added an apple for little extra flavor. It was really good. Everyone enjoyed it. This is a very easy recipe that i will make again.
This is a good hearty sangria. When I make this again I would cut the rum in half. Taste later and see if more rum is needed.
Excellent recipe. Everyone at my party liked it. On a warm day it was great to have this chilled on the patio. Stood up to ice really well, too.

AWESOME!! Made our camping Sangria Saturday Great I did use the Spiced rum and Raspberry Merlot ( Found in the desert wine section). Will use less sugar next time it didn't all dissolve. Definitely in my camping cookbook and my home cook book
Great recipe. Adapt it however you like, using whatever fruit and wine you like. Add spritzer/soda water to dilute a bit.
I made this sangria exactly as the recipe called for, and I would not change a thing! I made this the night before and added the fruit two hours before serving. The results were outstanding!
Nice, refreshing summer drink. I will make this again, trying different variations.
Very good. I added strawberry's and cut the rum in half.

Delicious! Made it as written with a very high quality, smooth, white rum. Served it at a Moroccan themed dinner party. The menu included Moroccan marinated olives, homemade hummus, toasted pita chips, zucchini patties with tatziki sauce, blood orange, beet and fennel salad, Moroccan Braised Beef from this site, and Israeli couscous. I have zero leftovers! Dessert was a beautiful lemon cheesecake from Anna Olson's cookbook.

I've made this several times for our now infamous Sangria Sundays...very much in high demand! This is so smooth that you will never know what hit you! I recommend using a wine that you know you like because it makes all the difference. And just go ahead and double the recipe, you will not regret it!
wayaaaaa too strong. Is it possible the rum should be 1/2 cup and not 1 1/2??
I follow the suggestions below and add 1/2 cup grand mariner since I don't have triple sec. Always yummy!!!
Way too much rum. I really like a strong drink, but the cup and a half is
Very tasty but too much alcohol. I would make it again but would cut the rum in half.

Our first try with sangria, and we like it! I didn't have orange juice, so I used pineapple/orange juice. Reduced alcohol a little, just because we didn't want it too strong. Used ~ 3/4 cup spiced rum, and ~1/4 cup Triple Sec. Since I had them, we used frozen cotton candy grapes for ice cubes. ~~~ We enjoyed this very much! We don't drink often, but when we're in the mood, I'm sure we'll have this again!

I made this yesterday for a BBQ. My family are not big drinkers, so I used 1 cup of rum instead of 1 1/2 cups. I also made the sangria all at once & put it in the fridge for a few hours. I was a perfect amount of alcohol. I recommend adding ice to your glass. It was a refreshing drink on a hot Florida day. Ill definitely make this again.

I made this for my annual Kentucky Derby party because no one really cared for the mint juleps I had been making. This was a really big hit. I did use the blackberry merlot and cut the sugar in half as some suggested. I went through two pitchers of this in an afternoon and had requests for the recipe. I will definitely make this again next year...and I probably will make it even sooner.

I have been making this recipe for a few years now and every time it gets rave reviews from my guests! I typically substitute a double bottle of wine which yields more and the taste isn't compromised. Also, it tastes better if you let the fruit soak the rum overnight. Definitely make a double batch because it will be gone by the end of the night! That said, warn your guests that it packs a punch. I've had a few people stand up at the end of the night unaware of the affect. Great for patio parties - happy summer!

Super useful! Really glad my cousin introduced me to this website. I did make a couple of changes in terms of the fruits used. 2 Limes 2 Plums 1 Apple 1 Lemon 1 Orange 1 Pear 6 Strawberries 20 Blueberries 12 Raspberries 10 Grapes I washed them all, cut them thinly, and placed them in the pitcher. Poured in 1 cup of Rum and 1/2 cup of Sugar, and left it to soak for 2 hours straight in the refrigerator. After 2 hours, I took them out and added half a bottle of wine followed by a cup of Orange Juice. The end product was just amazing with the Sangria looking blood-maroon in hue. Must try!
I made this for a dinner party I hosted, which was Latin themed, and the sangria was perfect. I actually made double the quantity so I had enough for the entire weekend! Would definitely recommend!

This was really tasty. I used an inexpensive White Merlot (it's really red and not white) and dark rum. The fruit, sugar, and rum macerated for about 24 hours. This was purely unintentional but really enhanced the flavor profile. You definitely need to be mindful of your consumption of this delicious beverage. It will catch you off guard and pretty quick!
I used Red Diamond "Temperamental" wine and half the rum and sugar. I also added about a cup of ginger ale. It was delicious and there was none left over!

Oh, wow. I made this for Thanksgiving tonight, assuming I would polish off the leftovers when my guests left. Not possible as they drank every last drop! I read reviews and used the recommended spiced rum and a big cheap bottle of blackberry merlot. I only had 3/4 cup of rum left, so I added a little cointreau to make a full cup of liquor. My fruit (lemon, lime, apple, strawberries, pineapple) soaked in the rum/cointreau/sugar/orange juice all day, and I added the merlot before bed last night. I also poured in some ginger ale before serving for fizz. Everyone loved it. My aunt said it was the best sangria she's ever had. Thanks for the recipe! Will use this again for parties for sure.

This was a huge hit at my girls night and party last night. I used two oranges sliced in rounds, a lemon, a lime, three different types of apples, about 25 strawberries sliced, and a pair (I needed to make a huge batch). I put all of the fruit in a container, put about three quarters of a cup of sugar over the fruit, and then added 2 cups of very high-quality spiced rum. I let that soak in the fridge overnight, and then in the morning, I poured about a cup and a half of orange juice and three bottles of wine over the fruit and rum mixture. I let that sit in the fridge for another couple of hours before the party. I served it with ice on the side, and everyone loved it. Couldn't get enough of it!! Because of the high quality rum, no one has a headache today either. :-)

After a week in Spain I decided to make my own Sangria instead of buying it in restaurants. I found this recipe online. It was so delicious, went down so smoothly & had a bit of a kick. When I went to put it back in the refrigerator I found the OJ sitting on the counter. Oh my, what a tipsy accident. I have repeated it with great pleasure.
This drink is a huge hit at parties. I've made it a few times now and everyone always asks if there's more when it's gone. Yummy!!
Got totally faced on this and took a dump on my friends lawn. Highly recommended!
This was a huge hit. A bit strong so we had to add more juice/water. This recipe is our new summertime favourite.
Soooo good! Made it for girls night! There wasn't a drop left!

This was my first attempt at making sangria and it was fantastic. I made minor changes to the recipe: reduced rum and sugar to 1 cup of spiced rum and 1/3 cup sugar. I cut up an apple and a pear and soaked them with the lemon and lime (I forgot to buy oranges so I did not use those). Next time, I might use more rum but would not add any more sugar. Fantastic recipe and everyone who tried it loved it as well. The apples and pears were a great treat to snack on after the sangria was gone!

Not a fan, honestly. Brandy is actually the best and most common hard alcohol to mix with the wine. Sorry, but I'll stick w/the Sangria! Sangria recipe here on AR. I use brandy & a splash of triple sec or OJ, maybe a splash of peach schnapps, allow it to blend/chill for several hours or overnight. I've also used blackberry brandy as well as ginger brandy for kicks - comes out great. I prefer to serve it with club soda - or ginger ale for those who prefer it sweeter. Again, sorry, but I'd skip this recipe and Google Sangria...you'll find brandy is much more authentic than rum. But hey, whatever works for ya! Also, add any citrus LAST ~ all fresh citrus turns bitter after a couple hours. Cheers!

This was a great recipe for a base. Next time I will do half a cup of oj as The flavor profile changed a little after a few days in the fridge.Too much orange juice gave it a slight grapefruit bitterness.Replaced the rum with a cup of single malt scotch and used blackberry merlot.You wouldn't think these too flavors would work but the scotch makes it smoother and easier to drink.My buddy and I made a batch and drank 1.5 liter mix in a matter of an hour.When it was gone we wanted another batch.Not drunk just relaxed.
Pure bona-fide AWESOMENESS!!!
Awesome!

Fabulous drink! I let the fruit and rum sit for about 5 hours. Very simple to make. Everyone at my party loved it....when it was all gone i made more but it doesn't taste the same when you don't let the fruit and rum sit a while. I will absolutely use this again and try to play up the fruits.
this recipe was my first attempt at sangria. I just had some at scarlett oharas in st Augustine and it was great. I think she used pinapple juice and simple surup.
I used a burgundy wine like suggested and the drink was beautiful but no one could stomach the strength! Won't be making this one again.

I loved this recipe! I used Captain Morgan spiced rum and Arbor Mist Blackberry Merlot. I made one batch with the 1/2 cup of sugar and one batch without it and to be honest- it doesn't need the sugar at all! The wine and orange juice made it sweet enough, but not overboard. This is perfect for a romantic evening or a summer day! Loved it

This recipe was delicious! I used a blackberry merlot and spiced rum as others suggested. I also added a half cup of triple sec. This was the best sangria recipe that I have tried thus far. Great recipe!
Really good recipe but has too much rum. We cut the rum in half. Some didn't like the tartness of the wine and could have used something a bit fruitier.
This drink is so good although I put it in a glass bowl with the fruit floating but also had garnished my wine glasses with fruit as well and i let my friends pour their own everyone enjoyed this

I found this recipe on here about 5 years ago, and with a couple tweaks for personal taste, I've made it my go to red sangria recipe. To me, sangria is a year round drink, but most like it as a summer beverage. I love it with rum, like this recipe calls for, but a neutral spirit like vodka works just as well. I'm from Texas, where we like things either really sweet, or really spicy, so I double the sugar. Aside from that, if you're in a hurry, you can really just throw all the ingredients together at once and serve it over ice (which you should do anyway). If you're having a party, go ahead and do yourself a favor and make double the amount. Some people like a splash of 7up to top off their glass.
I've made this a few times for cookouts and get togethers with friends. It is delicious! It goes fast. I suggest to double the recipe for serving friends.

This was amazing! I used the dark rum and a dry (for me) red, "Red Fox" from Goose Watch. I did cut the rum down to 1 cup. It was great the first day, absolutely amazing the second! Though I have to admit there wasn't much left for day two. Letting the fruit soak really made a difference. Definitely keeping this recipe around. Great for parties, special occasions, just for fun

When I first read about rum in sangria, I thought no way! But I did it with CM Spiced Rum, strawberries, raspberries, oranges, pears, pineapple. Soaked it for about a day and a half. Added no sugar, and the wine and OJ. It was a big hit! I will definitely make it again. The only thing is you have to plan in advance. I used to make sangria with only red wine and OJ, plus the fruit and I thought THAT was good! LOL, thanks for a great simple recipe!

I substitute 1c brandy for rum -and substitute chopped apples for the lemons and limes, I also cut back the sugar alot (apples make it sweeter) we sometimes skip the OJ too let the fruit soak & add a few cloves for a kick. Just my preference reminds me more of what we had in Spain
This is hands down the favorite at my parties. But.....it is STRONG! Make sure your friends have lots to eat. I use two-buck chuck from Trader Joes and Bacardi light rum. It is amazing
Very Tasty! Very strong. Pour it over some ice and enjoy! Thank you for this easy recipe
Delicious! I used berries along with citrus fruits and it was very good.

I have made this a lot of ways depending on what I have on hand. Always the fruit called for in the basic recipe but sometimes other fruit as well. Strawberries peaches nectarines apples pears ... A lot of times I haven't had the orange juice on hand. I have never used the full amount of sugar before and I usually use only 1 cup of rum. I have added frozen lime or lemon-aid instead of the orange juice. Today I, for the first time after a couple of years of messing with this recipe finally have made this recipe as listed above. Awesomeness ***** . My rating is for the recipe as listed. This could be called Smooth Heroin wine... One glass and your cheeks are warm... Take care and enjoy...

Made this for a family gathering at Christmas! Boy was it a hit!! I added Triple Sec and SPICED Rum. Decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup and added pineapple, orange, lemon, apple, cherries and pear. Oh and yes, I added the Misty Arbor Blackberry Merlot. You cannot go wrong with this recipe and I highly reccomend you add the spiced rum. It gives it a dimension you will love, if you really like sangria! Enjoy!!
This is excellent, and allows for considerable variations to tastes and fruit availability. Highly recommended, and yes it is potent.....

Made this as written except I used only 1 and a quarter cups of rum, and I found even that to be too much rum. I used Bacardi and Trader Joe's merlot. It made a little too much for my pitcher but looked very pretty and was yummy chilled. This was the first sangria I've made and it was very easy.

Double batch, cheap red blend, spiced rum, same citrus fruits plus frozen pineapple and mango chunks - YUM! I've made it before, always a big hit. The one thing I do differently, because I didn't read it wrong the first time, I just put it all in a glass pitcher at once and let it mull 3-4 hours.

I used arbor mist blackberry merlot 1.5 liter and mostly doubled the ingredients. Used sailor jerry spiced rum but only about a cup and it was still pretty strong. Also added some triple sec and raspberries. Turned out great!
way too alcoholic tasting

Delicious and refreshing. Kool-Aid for grown ups. My cousins in Madrid taught us to add some orange liqueur (Cointreau or Triple Sec) for a little extra kick. And if you can, let this sangria sit for two days before serving--5x more delicious. Serve icy cold with slice of the marinated citrus--it will be a gorgeous purple color after a day or so in the wine. Great recipe! Thanks!

Made this with spiced rum and it was amazing! What really made it a treat was having leftover drunken fruit, draining the dregs. Yes, it's very strong, but the citrus component really makes it nice and smooth.
I made this for a back yard cook out and it was a huge hit. This will forever me my classic summer drink.
GREAT SANGRIA - very easy to make and my friends loved it!

I've never made Sangria before and thought it would be a nice addition to our summer bbq. I used the spiced rum and soaked the fruit overnight. When I went to purchase Blackberry Merlot - based on other recommendations, the clerk at the liquor store said it was a very sweet wine. So - being worried it would be too sweet - I bought a regular Merlot and it was perfect! This one is a keeper!
I made this for a girls' night in and it was a big hit! I used spiced rum and a merlot. Be careful, the alcohol sneaks up on you!

UPDATE: SOME OF MY GAL PALS AND I VISITED A LOCAL WINERY RECNETLY (TOUR AND DRINKS!). I WAS FINALLY ABLE TO PURCHASE A BOTTLE OF BLACKBERRY WINE!!! I MADE A SECOND BATCH OF SANGRIA WITH SPICED RUM AND A MIXTURE OF RED / GREEN APPLES AND PEARS. WOW! ALTHOUGH MY HUBS PREFERS THIS WITH MERLOT, HE REALLY LIKED THE FRUIT. THAT'S SAYING A LOT SINCE HE PRETTY MUCH HATES ANY AND ALL FRUIT! :) Pretty good! I am not a wine drinker at ALL, but I really enjoyed this (especially with spiced rum)!!! Having said this, I do think this could use a touch more sugar. Had I been able to find the blackberry wine I wanted to use, this might have been sweet enough for my liking (I had to use Merlot instead). Next time I'll be sure to plan ahead so that I can stop at another grocery store to look for it. I will also substitute pears and apples for the citrus fruits since my hubby thinks they would soak up the booze better lol. Thanks for sharing your recipe, Lisa. I can't wait to make this again - and again! :-)
I only use a 1/2 cup rum to a liter of wine - this stuff is strong, but delicious. Already bought a case of wine just for sangria. These are just so good!!

I liked the general plan for this, simple and quick. I like my drinks sweet, and even with 'sweet' red wine this was a bit too much for me. I added Sprite directly to my glass, and that made it perfect for me. It is quite potent, though. Not that I'm complaining . . . .
I didn't enjoy this very much. The spiced rum overpowered it in my opinion. Would not make again.

Ugh. Bummer. Was looking forward to trying this recipe.... What a disappointment!!! Brought it to an afternoon cocktail party/ bbq. Way, way, way too sweet!? ( i even omitted some sugar). I bartend for a living and was so embarassed. Should have known better! Will not make this recipe again-- sorry.
I made this with the blackberry merlot and spiced rum, oh my, I'm glad I planned to stay home! Very potent!

I really loved this Sangria although I made a couple changes to it. I only used 1 cup of rum and I added about 1-2 cups of Sprite as well. I also used more fruit including strawberries, peaches, oranges, maraschino cherries,apple, pear, lemon and extra lime. Also, it's tastes soooooo good with all that fruit, the sugar is just completely unnecessary, so I didn't use any at all. And I soaked the fruit in rum overnight as suggested by others. (And yes, the fruit tastes amazing after soaking, so don't let too many people taste-test it before adding to the sangria!) I also used orange juice ice cubes in the glasses as suggested by someone else. My guests raved about it and it was all gone in no time! As per the recommendation of the staff member at the liquor store I used Jackson Triggs Merlot red wine and it was delicious. I will definitely be making this again!

I made this for our dinner guest last night, had lots of fresh Florida oranges, lemons and strawberries. I used fresh squeezed orange juice. The best part about Sangria is when the drink is gone you can still eat the fruit. :)

Very festive -- made for a small potluck dinner at my house. Ideal for a spring or summer event - so refreshing! Of course I modified it based on what I had on hand -- I added some sprite and club soda (almost an entire 2 litre bottle's worth) to make a larger amount -- the sugar is necessary at that point. Also added some apricot brandy (about 1/2 cup). I had some leftover limeade made up as well so I added that (about 2 cups -- note: this was NOT substitued for the OJ -- that was added as well.) Guests raved about it and said they wanted the recipe. It did look pretty with the citrus fruit slices in a large glass pitcher.
Made this for a Day of the Dead party. WOW...can't imagine a party without it now. Thank you!!!!

This is the best recipe for sangria. However, because I am a bit of a light weight, I cut down on the rum a bit. I also recommend using fresh squeezed orange juice, it really does make a difference in the flavor. It adds a freshness that orange juice concentrate does not offer.

OMG!!!! This is one kick Sangria. It sneaks up on you, be very careful! The first time I made it I used the Captain Morgan Spiced Rum and Triple Sec. It was so smooth. I used the Blackberry Merlot and it was wonderful. I used orange, lemon and lime slices. Definately a KEEPER!!! I made it the same way the next time and warned everyone to pace yourself. Look no further this is the one!!

I've served this at a couple of parties now and it's a huge hit - even with the guys! I use spiced rum and an inexpensive chillable red wine, and the flavor is wonderful. If you leave the rum-soaked fruit in the pitcher, you can keep adding red wine all evening without compromising the flavor. I like to serve it with ice and extra fruit in the glass. Watch out though - a couple of full glasses tend to knock your socks off!

Read some say that the rum was too strong for the flavor, so with that advice I put in half as much rum as called for, with the idea if it needed more I could always add more. Still with half the recommended amount of rum, it seems to strong. I think I am going to move onto another recipe.

There are many ways to make sangria, but I wanted a basic "jumping off" recipe for sangria I could customize. I doubled the recipe to take to a party where most of the attendees usually drink beer. The recipe worked very well and was completely gone by the end of the evening!
Very easy! The only thing I changed was to add one pear, as the writer suggested. So much flavor for so little work and my friends raved! I used Cruzan rum and Rex Goliath Free Range Red wine.

This was a tasty, easy-to-make sangria. I cut the rum in half and added cherries. My main qualm is that what makes the sangria taste good--the citrus fruit--is annoying once you go to drink it. Do you strain the slices? Do you eat them? Eating them makes a mess. Next time, I think I'll make this sangria the same way, but before serving it to guests I'll strain out the citrus slices and throw in only edible fruits, like pineapple, apple, or cherries. I don't know how that will affect the taste, but the experience might improve?

This was my first sangria making experience, and I'm glad I followed this recipe. I used spiced rum and Cab Sav. I messed up and added the wine and OJ with the booze and fruit (which turned out fine), and I let everything soak for 24 hours. This was less popular at my party than the White Peach Sangria also found on this site.
Great recipe. But, I got fruit loopy! Next time I will stick to basic recipe. Too much fruit soaked up the liquid. But it looked pretty!

I've made this recipe for a summer party the last couple of years. I double the recipe, use blackberry merlot and then use berries for my fruit -- strawberries, blueberries, blackberries, raspberries. I also split up the 1 1/2 cups of rum -- usually 1/2 cup of Captain's Spiced, 1/2 Pineapple, 1/4 triple sec, 1/4 cointreau. Leave out the sugar. Powerful!!!

instead of 1.5 cups of rum i only used 1/2 cup of brandy per batch. i also did half a lemon and half a lime instead of a full one. i let the orange, lemon and lime "cook" in the brandy/sugar mixture for a day then added a diced up apple and let that "cook" for 12 hours and then added the wine. that "cooked" for another 12 hours and then in the morning of the party i added the oj. enjoy !

A great summer alternative to beer for poolside cocktails! I use blackberry wine and Captain Morgan's spiced rum. I've had several friends tell me it's the best sangria they've ever tasted :) You might want to double this recipe--use a 1.5 liter bottle of wine and the entire 5th of Captain Morgans.

I've tried many of the sangria recipes on this site, and I have to say, this is by far the best red sangria recipe I've tried from ANY recipe site. So many of the reviews suggested reducing the rum by half and starting there (adding more if desired) so I did make that change, and I'm glad I did. I will also add a little less sugar next time (I think a quarter cup would be fine), but wow, this is fabulous!! Since the changes I made were purely my personal preference, I still feel this is a 5-star recipe, and I plan to use this as my go-to sangria recipe from now on.
The only change I made was since I did not have dry wine only semi-sweet I cut back a little on the surgar. It was very good and looked beautiful in the pitcher.
Easy and delicious! I only used about half the amount of rum, and for the wine I found a merlot/zinfandel blend which I thought worked out just fine. Will definitely be making this again.

The best sangria recipe. Next time I'd add less lime, and maybe some bing cherries or other sweet fruit. I used a cheap shiraz, and it was fabulous. For those who think it's too strong, serve chilled over a full glass of ice. I also reduced the rum to 1/2 cup on occassion.
drink with caution.

I've made this several times, always with rave reviews and requests for the recipe. My favorite is using Parrot Bay Pineapple rum and Manischewitz Blackberry wine. Soooo good. In addition to a lemon, lime and orange, I add sliced pineapple and sometime strawberries. Making some this weekend. Can't wait to sit on my patio sipping a glass and enjoying the evening.
Cheap wine redemption! I used white grape peach flavoring instead of citrus.
we made this for the office staff party and forgot the orange juice (!) - noone noticed and everyone loved it...i wonder why... :-)
Good flavor, but fairly strong.
I love this stuff!
Reduce rum to 1/2-3/4 cup per bottle of wine. Still strong but not over the top.

Made this for my girls night in party and it was a big hit! Everyone loved it. I followed the recipe with the exception of using another reviewers advice and added triple sec (1/2 cup) and adjusted the rum to one cup. VERY VERY GOOD!
Had this over thanksgiving and just served it again recently... Made only one pitcher, but everyone loved it so much that I should have made 2!
I love lemon, but this sangria is overwhelmingly citrus. IfI make it again. I will definitely tweak.

Since there was only 2 of us, I halved the recipe. Very, very good! Next time I will use Captain Morgan or omit the rum all together and use Triple Sec instead. I used a variety of fresh berries, oranges & apples! Amazing!!

Used spice rum. Used regular Merlot because I could not find a decent black berry merlot. So I added some frozen black berries. Used 1 each of red apple, green apple, lime, orange, and a lemon. Many of us like it strong so we didn't need soda, but others felt the need to add soda. All were satisfied.
A good place to start, but could be improved.
When they are in season, make this sangria with blood oranges and fresh squeezed blood orange juice. Incredible.
Great sangria recipe it never disappoints and people are always raving about it. I like using a merlot for this and Barefoot Merlot really makes this pop!
This recipe is an instant success! I used spiced rum and a cab/sav for wine. Outstanding!!
Yummy! Major hit at Girls Night In! I didnt have any rum on hand so I used brandy. Just as good.

This was great, it was my first time making Sangria, I substituted brandy for the rum. Everyone loved it, including my friend who makes it all the time. I think the best thing is that it has very few ingredients so you taste the wine and brandy (it's also quick and easy to make) I mixed the fruit and wine together the night before, then mixed everything together in the morning so all the flavours melded.

I used blackberry merlot (cheap but tastes sooo good!) and spiced rum along with all the other ingredients this calls for. I made 5 batches of it for my housewarming party and it was such a hit! Will DEFINITELY make this amazing Sangria again!
Wonderful! I used way too many fruits in my first batch, but the flavor was great and it is so easy to make.

Used Merlot. Had every intention of using a spiced rum only to discover that I only had half the amount of it needed so I had to add regular rum to the rest. Needless to say the spiced flavor didn't come through. I also made a batch Sangria and it called for brandy. So I did a taste test and I like the rum better. The brandy made it too "boozy"

Great recipe for Sangria. I used the spiced rum, but we didn't like the blackberry flavored wine (that was recommended by others) as much as regular wine (we used a cheap merlot the first time). I think the blackberry wine works great if you don't have time to let the flavors develop - or if you want a drink that is not as strong. Still, the great thing about this recipe is that you can experiment with the ingredients (both alcohol and fruit) and it'll still taste great.
This turned out really tasty, even though I forgot to add the orange juice! I will definitely make this again.

Have used this recipe multiple times! I live in Florida. Have had Cuban immigrants exclaim that: "Now THIS is like the Sangria at home." High praise indeed! Everyone, yes everyone LOVES this recipes. I save it and use it for all the spring, summer, fall parties I have! Good for drinking by the pool also! Now: January 2016: I make this for EVERY party I have: at least 3 times a year. This time I edited this way: and I must say: even more raves! I quadruple it: which is easy with allrecipes.com calculator on each recipe! Instead of orange juice use FRESH grapefruit juice (in the produce section). Instead of oranges: use red grapefruit slices. I use SPICED rum. Decrease the sugar by a 1/4. Two big pinches of salt (brings out the citrus flavor). For only 6 servings I would use a small pinch of salt. I always use a Cabernet wine. Okay to add an extra bottle of wine to stretch punch. Just keep tasting, as you add, before you add the slices of fruit. Keep muddling the fruit...the more the fruit is bruised in the punch: I think the better it tastes. I would say the punch today is the best yet. And I have made it at least 18 times!

4.5 Stars! I love this drink and can't wait to make it again. I doubled the original recipe for a party. I used blackberry wine as others suggested, but still added a bit of sugar. I didn't use quite as much rum (I used Cpt Morgan) since I had some older ladies who were worried about too much booze. I also had 7up on the side if anyone wanted to make a spritzer. For fruit, I used a whole lemon, 1 orange, half of an apple and a half of a can of pineapple with the juice. We actually ended up with leftover fruit, so next time I might not add as much. The drink would be great without it!
way too stong!

I just made this for a party yesterday and love it. It tastes great--not too sweet but not too dry. Also, it is a lot easier than some of the other sangria recipes out there, which is great for when you're planning a party for a crowd. I will definitely make this again.
So simple and so delicious. Everyone at our party asked for the recipe and it was almost embarrassing that it was so simple!
SO good!
Fantastic! I used peach rum which added a nice flavor -- otherwise followed the recipe exactly. This will be my new go to sangria recipe.
This is some mighty fine stuff. I had bought a bottle of premixed Sangria as emergency backup but that's like comparing Dom Perignon to Mad Dog 20/20. I will definitely make this again and again :)

I've made this recipe countless times and it never fails to win fans. I've shared it with friends on the east and west cost and what I always hear back from them is..."amazing sangria!". You simply cannot beat this recipe! Thanks!
Used spiced rum and blackberry wine as others suggested. Delicious! I hope to use this often for company
I love this recipe but be careful - it really packs a whollop!

This is a great recipe. I made this for a 4th of July cookout...and it was a hit. I only gave it 4 stars because I don't feel the sugar is necessary. I made it with Arbor Mist Blackberry Merlot and Parrot Bay Lime Rum...and followed the recipe exactly. It was a bit too sweet. But still delicious!

The original recipe is great! You can also improvise. I didn't have any red wine or brandy, so I used Zinfindel, mango rum, and plain rum. Had no fruit on hand so I used orange liquere. For a little carbonation I used a small bottle of sparkling tangerine juice. The point is, when in a pinch, you can use some subsitutions and still end up with a great drink.

This is my go to basic sangria recipe. I took another reviewers advice and used Blackberry Merlot instead of dry red wine. This also eliminates the need for the 1/2 cup of sugar since the Blackberry Merlot is a sweetened wine. I like using spiced rum such as Captain Morgans. I soak the fruit (I usually add strawberries) in the rum several hours before putting the other ingredients. A bonus is getting to eat the rum/wine soaked fruit afterwards :) Very yummy, there are never any leftovers!!
A little too sweet, but otherwise so tasty.
everyone enjoyed this alot, I should have doubled the recipe.
Fabulous sangria, but it will knock you for a loop. If you are going to have people driving home, you may want to reduce the rum just a little.

This must be an American version. I've had Sangria in almost very country that borders the Mediterranean and none of them had enough alcohol in them to even taste or feel it, irregardless of how much you drank.
I love this recipe, make it every time we want sangria. I usually use Parrot Bay Passion Fruit Rum to make it more fruity tasting. SOOOOO good!!!
YUM! So delicious and perfectly fruity! I loved this and will make often! Thanks!
Good

Really great recipe. Made it just as the recipe says with the minor substitution on sweet wine instead of dry. Used plain Bacardi rum and lemons, limes, and oranges. I mixed up the rum, fruit, and sugar the night before and added the wine a couple of hours before serving. The only issue I had was in trying to get the sugar dissolve. Awesome recipe, though. Will be making again.

The first time I made this I used one of my favorite red wines and golden cachaca instead of rum and it was great! This time I used 1 cup golden cachaca since it's all I had and a new wine that wasn't nice on it's own and it was still delicious!

I used a very cheap bottle of Sangiovesse from Trader Joes and the cheapest white rum I could find. Following the recipe exactly....it's perfect. I think in the future I will put the sliced fruit, rum, sugar & OJ in a zipper bag and freeze, pop it into the ice chest along with a cheap bottle of wine and take camping.

This always pleases the crowd when ever I bring it to a shin dig! One time I used a wine that was 20% alcohol and whoa it was nothing to play with. Just make sure you take your time while drinking this it sneaks up on you. Thanks for sharing!
Add Spicey Capt Morgans rum for a great twist!
WOW! So good! Beware it goes down VERY easy.

I made this for a jewelry party I was hosting and it was a HIT!! Every loved it and it looked very elegant and was very tasty! I added maraschino cherry's, and red and green apples and at the end of the party everyone fought over the fruit!

I made this for a girls night fondue party and it was fantastic! I doubled the recipe and used Carlo Rossi Sangria wine, 2 small limes and 1 large lemon cut into thin rounds, I cut 1 orange into rounds and another I cut the orange wedges into bite size pieces, I cut up 2 apples into bite size pieces and before serving I added a jar of drained and rinsed maraschino cherries. It had a wonderful sweet-citrus flavor and I will make it again and again!
Used Blackberry Merlot. I have made this over and over again. Everyone LOVES it.

I changes this around a bit, I added brandy and triple sec and cinnamon sticks to the recipe. I also took out the orange juice and added more sugar. I like my sangria sweet. I also let the fruit soak in just the liquor's with a little sugar and the cinnamon sticks. This recipe is a good start, but with my changes made it GREAT. If you do drink it the way I suggested, please drink it slow, it will sneak up on you later. Hope you enjoy!!!

This was delicious! The only thing I might change was the amount of sugar. As I rounded glass number 2, I started to feel a bit sugar high and it was too sweet for me to finish the second glass. If you add just a bit less sugar, good to go!
Very yummy recipe! I used arbor mist wine so it was a little more sweet and fruity and I used Sailor Jerry rum. Yum!
Delicious! I've made this numerous times for dinner parties, and it's always a hit. I usually reduce the amount of rum down to 1 cup, and increase the orange juice by about 1/2 cup.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this! I threw a couples bridal shower and made this as my cocktail drink and everyone could not get enough of it ( even the guys!). Its perfect and would not change a thing. Everyone went home with the recipe!
Great base recipe.

Very good. As someone suggested, I soaked the fruit in rum for a while. I took this to a party so I combined all the ingredients in advance and it was really good. Next time, I'll add apples and maybe mangos.
Watch Out! This sneaks up on you! Try subbing the OJ for Peach Schnapps!

Fantastic! Everyone RAVED about this drink! I used the blackberry merlot and spiced rum as other reviewers suggested and it turned out amazing! If it is too strong, you can top it off with a bit of diet or regular 7Up or Sprite...but we didn't do that and it was fantastic!!!

Fantastic! Everyone RAVED about this drink! I used the blackberry merlot and spiced rum as other reviewers suggested and it turned out amazing! If it is too strong, you can top it off with a bit of diet or regular 7Up or Sprite...but we didn't do that and it was fantastic!!!

This recipe is fantastic, blending simplicity with awesomeness. I make it as often as possible, and sometimes I am reduce to inventing reasons. But, it's great for the holidays and any party you can think of. I always make double batches of this, and it fills a gallon pitcher. I lower the octane a bit by reducing the total the rum amount to just over 2 cups, and the OJ to about 1.5 cups. Otherwise, the (junk) wine flavor gets lost. I like it better when it's all balanced.
