To make sure the red wine was not too dry, I used shiraz, which lended a light sweetness. My Spanish guest commented on how authentic the sangria was, and I overheard another guest telling someone that the sangria was his favorite drink at the party.

As a sangria novice with a sweet tooth, I found this recipe a perfect base to start from. I've made this recipe many times, and have had friends rave about it (and ask for the recipe!) However, I tend to throw in different types of fruit, whatever I have on hand (I find that strawberries, blueberries, and nectarines are fruits that work well!) and use only 3/4 cup to 1 cup of rum. I think the sugar is important to help draw out the flavor of the fruit, as well as crushing the fruit after it has chilled in the fridge. Also, I have found that a cheap blackberry merlot (as earlier posters suggested) works best, in my case, a $4 Arbor mist version! I'm the type of person that does not like to taste the alcohol so with these changes, the resulting sangria is sweet, fruity, and will be gone in minutes!

I would omit the sugar add 1/2 cup of tripple sec and add a splash of peach schnapps. (just a splash) Also an apple is a good addition as well. The sugar is what gives you that terrible headache the next morning. You won't miss it in the flavor. If you want to make this without the 2 hour chill time just fill pitcher with ice, add fruit, then brandy & tripple sec, then wine, then oj splash the schnapps stir with a wooden spoon and you're all done.

I followed the recipe and used the red burgundy wine as it suggested but it was much too dry and tart for me. I thought the orange juice and fruit would flavor and mellow out the dryness of the wine but it didn't. I wasted almost half of the batch I made. Don't think I will make it again.
Very good sangria, I served it at a dinner party and it was a big hit. Would make again!

This is not really a classic Spanish Sangria, much too sweet. Spanish Sangria is made with brandy rather than rum and the fruit is muddled with small amounts of unrefined sugar and club soda(agua con gas. The wine should be on the sweet side rather than dry.

This recipe is a great starting point, but it's way too strong even for folks who like liquor. I added more orange juice and some lemon-lime soda (like Sprite) to tone it down. It was a HUGE hit after that. I'll definitely be making this one again.

I made this for my boyfriend's birthday party last month for about 100 people. This was a HUGE hit!!! It was gone before the evening ended, and everyone was disappointed. I used 1/2 less rum, and added pineapples. People are asking me to make it again; I definitely will!
Perfect! I added some sliced berries and cherries for presentation, but it would have been fabulous without.

Did I do something wrong? After reading all the rave reviews I choose this recipe to serve at a party. I was so excited about it and it BOMBED! Every one said how good it was when they first tried it but then I found full glasses of it all night just sitting around where people had abandoned it in favor of something else. And I still have practically a whole cooler full of the stuff left. I kept overhearing people say how strong it was, and this was a drinking crowd! Oh well, maybe better luck next time.

Not my favorite - too much rum flavor, too sweetly sticky. I made it for a large crowd - a chili cookoff and not much was drank. I didn't have a large enough container for the fruit and rum and sugar, so I used a plastic bag. Maybe my proportions were off?

This stuff will knock you on your keester! We do "low carb" so I do not use the sugar or orange juice; instead, I add 1 can of Splenda-sweetened diet soda like Hansens's Tangerine Lime. I also reduced the rum to a cup or less. Try Gallo's Hearty Burgundy for the wine! Delicious and it improves over a couple days (if it lasts that long....)

I thought this was fabulous!! I made a double batch for a barbeque this weekend and there wasn't a drop left. This was one recipe where I did not totally agree with the suggestions of the reviewers. I purchased Blackberry Merlot for this recipe and found that it was just too sweet. I actually had to open a bottle of plain Merlot that I had in my wine rack and add it to the pitcher to cut the sweetness. Next time I will follow the recipe exactly. Oh, and I did use the Spiced Rum as suggested. Thank you for a great summertime drink!

The best Sangria EVER. The only changes I made was to use 1 cup of spiced rum and to add nectarine and champagne mango along with the citrus. I got many compliments and recipe requests. I'll definitely be making this again (and again, and again)! Thanks Lisa!
Very tasty after it sits overnight.

So delicious! Perfect for a summer afternoon on the deck with the grill fired up! I used a couple bottles of Merlot from Trader Joe's (inexpensive) as well as some apricots added to the citrus fruit. It was wonderful! And I have lots leftover (expected a bigger crowd than I got for dinner!) Thank you Lisa! This recipe is a keeper!

This has turned out to be a favorite among family and friends. I make the more potent variety and everyone loves it. The most difficult thing about the recipe is chopping the fruit. I use lemon, lime, orange, apple and black plums.

We made a punch bowl of this sangria for a brunch party and it was a HUGE hit! Used about a third less rum (spiced) and cheap merlot. Put in strawberries, kiwi, and maraschino cherries, in addition to the citrus. Yum! Will definitely make this again!!!
The best Sangria I have ever made! I used only 1 cup of rum to tame it down a bit, and it still tasted fabulous. The drunken fruit at the end was delicious. I also added 1/2 triple sec/Grand Marnier.

I made several pitchers for a dinner party a few months ago... used Bacardi Gold in some and Christian Bros brandy in some. Forgot the orange juice (oops!) but it was awesome anyway! Got LOTS of compliments on it. Got complaints that I hadn't made enough...
This is the best sangria recipe period! We make it almost every weekend. I make it just as stated and I have always gotten rave reviews.

Not impressed. I used Columbia Crest Merlot/Cabernet blend and added peaches and apples like others suggested. I blended the sangria with 7-up and without that I don't think anyone would have drank it. I took this to a Memorial Day picnic so I made a double batch based on the reviewers comments and ended up throwing away over half of it.
This was great! I got great reviews on this at our party... I added 1/2 cup of triple sec and only 1 cup of rum. Mangoes were also a great addition!

This recipe was good but not GREAT! Very strong on the rum if you follow the recipe given - next time I will cut back on the rum, and sweeten up a tad more to taste. I will say it was gone by the end of the party!!!
this was easy and fun to prepare, i used arbor mist blackberry merlot and 1 cup spiced rum. it was a little bit too strong on the rum so next time less, otherwise very good.

This is GREAT! I brewed 1 batch to share w/a friend for a BYO club event and realized a 2nd batch might come in handy -might have a friend or 2 that needs to be turned on to something different. I mixed up the first batch the night before the event and fortunately(?) I have to get up early otherwise I might have a couple more glasses. OH, I made this with 2 buck Chuck Merlot from Trader Joes to keep the cost down and not waste a "good" wine &Bacardi White (clear) rum -the recommended amount because this recipe doesn't need any added flavor, but any inexpensive white rum will probably do the trick. I added some fresh pink grapefruit to the mix and tomorrow for the party i'll be adding sliced nectarines and strawberries. Sangria is a great change from the norm and the fresh fruit makes for some tasty snacking. Just great to beat the AZ heat. ;) This is definitely a summertime favorite.
Very good. I did reduce the rum, as others suggested, to 3/4 cup. I used a $3.00 bottle of merlot and threw in some strawberries. Will definitely be making this quite a bit this summer!

mmmmmmmm.....I am sitting here as I type this drinking a glass. I used the Arbor Mist Blackberry Merlot, but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. Well,not exactly,cut back on the rum to 1 cup- and believe me~ it still has a kick! The only thing I would change in this recipe for "liquid heaven" is definitely add lots of interesting fruits. Although the lime, orange and lemon add great flavor....it would be nice to have another fruit besides the orange to eat and enjoy more of the Sangria:)
This was DELICIOUS and SO EASY!!! I am big on themes so I tried this on my boyfriend when we were having fajitas and we loved it! Finished it the next day and ate all the fruit too!! YUM!!!

I made this drink for a party, and got some mixed reviews. I'm not quite the rum drinker that I thought I was and the amount seemed a bit much. I suggest cutting back a little on the rum. It did however make the fruit quite tasty!!!
Best sangria recipe I have found, however I put in half the rum to reduce the bite.

I made this sangria with the blackberry merlot, only one cup of spiced rum, and I made each serving with three parts sangria, one part lemon lime soda. Excellent, and not too terribly strong this way. I plan to make this several times a year!

I made this for a party we had, and doubled the recipe. We also had a white sangria but THIS was the hit! Everyone loved it. Instead of using citrus, we used papaya, strawberry, mango which was amazing! You will love this recipe, 1 batch isn't enough!

This was good! I based my opinion on Cafe Sevila, this amazing Spanish Restaurant popular in California. I changed it a little based on other reviews, and to make it taste more like the Sangria at Cafe Sevila. Use apples!! If they suck up the rum, it's only wasted if you don't eat them! And instead of orange juice, add an orange flavored liquer like Cointreau, or if you really want to knock your socks off... Grand Marnier. This is what Cafe Sevila uses!
the best sangria ever! always gets rave reviews at any party.

I followed advice and used less rum - about a cup, I think. We loved it and got pretty tipsy. It's dangerous! I'll definitely make it again and again. I use a lot of fruit since that's the best part - peaches, strawberries, oranges, and limes...

This was fantastic! I made a couple of batches for an Oscar party I had the other night and couldn't believe how tasty it was! I used less than 1 1/2 cups of rum (about 1 to 1 1/4 cups) and no one thought it was too strong. I used spiced rum and a $6 bottle of red and it turned out great. Added strawberries, an orange and lime, black plums, and some panned peaches- made for a nice variety of colours. Bottom line: this tastes like you spent a long time on it, but it's unbelievably easy to make! If you like sangria, you'll love this recipe!
Very nice drink. A little on the potent side if you are having a few in the sun. You can cut it with club soda. Also try adding a sliced kiwi and two shots of Contreau. Mmmm.

I made a double batch using one bottle of merlot and one bottle of cabernet. I reduced the rum to 1 cup per batch (using 2 cups total for the double batch), and I used spiced rum as some reviewers suggested. WHAT A HIT?! It made for a wonderful evening with some good friends.
Wicked Good Sangria. Ignore what they say about apples and pears. Add them both and then crush the fruit with potato masher or spoon afer the Sangria has sat overnight.
this was DELICIOUS!!!! I did reduce the rum to 1 cup and topped it with Meyers. served it with a cuban themed dinner and everyone thought it wonderful. I will be making this again soon....

super yummy! Adjusted it to my taste- i added a little more O.J- some lime, lemon and orange slices. Went thru it quickly one summer night with the neighbors- had to make a double batch- what a night!!
Awesome!! We made a few batches of this and used different flavors of wine with different fruits each time. You can get creative with this recipe and it will still turn out great.

this recipe is excellent. It takes just like I remember from Spain. I reduced the amount of rum to 3/4 cup and used only 1/3 cup of freshly squeezed orange juice. That really made the recipe a lot better to me. I LOVE Sangria!!!

This recipe is fantastic!! I have made it many times and every time people have asked for the recipe. I used light bicardi rum and cheap burgundy red wine both times. I have had several sangrias and this is wonderful!
YUMMY!! Very cooling on a hot, summer day by the pool. My sister in-law and I drank 2 batches:)

By far this Sangria was the best I have ever had. It was restaurant quality. I have served this on several occassions and it always gets rave reviews. I used blackberry Merlot and Sangria wine along with Myers rum to soak the fruits in. Yum!

I've made this on a couple of occasions to rave reviews. I sliced the orange, lemon, lime very thinly and placed them in a pitcher with the rum and sugar and let it sit overnight. Before I left for my party, I added the OJ and wine. It was amazingly good!! Also, I just used a Cab I had opened a few days before for marinara sauce and didn't like enough to drink on it's on. Great way to get rid of a red you don't love! :)

I made this for our New Year's Eve party and it was a hit! Everyone was sad when the pitcher was empty. I halved the amount of rum and used regular (not blackberry or any other flavor) inexpensive merlot - it turned out delicious.

YUM! Served this for New Years and it was a hit. I did end up reducing the amount of rum (made a quadruple recipie, and used 3 cups spiced rum instead of ~6) and I soaked the fruit in it overnight and all day. For fruit, I used 2 limes, 2 oranges, 1 lemon, strawberries, and canned peaches (and about 1/2 the juice from the can). I used Arbour Mist blackberrry merlot for the wine, and only added about 3 cups of orange juice to the whole thing. Turned out -excellently-, and was just about perfect for strength. Thanks for a great recipie!

Potent stuff!! It's sweet, so it goes down easily - too easily!! I decreased the rum to 1 cup (plenty of rum!) and served it over a glass full of ice. We made the second batch with a homemade raspberry merlot - good that way too - delicious recipe!! Thanks!
Hooo Mama! This was really good, but dangerous! Too easy to just suck down quicky . . . and then it hits you. Drink AFTER using the food processor.

Sure made the Cookie Exchange Party memorable (or not!). What a nice change from the usual drinks - my friends all LOVED it! Used $6 bottle of blackberry merlot ('not a wine, but a wine PRODUCT' I was informed by my local liquor store advisor:) and spiced rum. Deeeeeeeelishus!

I have made this for my friends many times and it is ALWAYS a hit!!! I made it with the blackberry merlot and used only 1/2 the rum and added Sprite. VERY good, the alcohol sneaks up on you. The fruit gives it so much added flavor also. GREAT recipe!!
This is so yummy, my guests loved it. I accidentally forgot the OJ, but it was still delicious. I used Blackberry Merlot as suggested by some of the reviewers.
I am a huge Sangria fan and this is the best I've ever had. It is so easy to make!

I recently attended a dinner with a Spanish theme and made this recipe. I thought it sounded horrible (rum with wine? wine with OJ? Yuck) but I wanted to do something authentic. It was a huge, huge hit. Even the beer drinking guys wanted seconds of this. I did not cut it with any flavored sodas as some of the reviews said. I did use frozen cherries, blueberries, lemons and limes. I used merot wine and dark rum. I made two batches and everyone was dissapointed that it was all gone. I would highly recommend this recipe.
delicious - very strong

WOW! I didn't think I would like this because I don't like sweet drinks but it really wasn't all that sweet. I did use 1 1/2 bottles of wine (because I had one open). My guests loved this and declared it the best sangria they ever had.

I made this for a bridal shower and used the suggested Blackberry Merlot rather than just red wine. It was great! It tasted like sprite with a kick! The guests did not know that it had rum(spiced) in it. They soon found out after it hit them! It was great!
Perfect just the way it is! I did add some halved strawberries and black cherries, but that's just me. Would make this again in a heartbeat.

This is a great basic recipe. With these changes, I have never served it to anyone who doesn't like it. I use a bottle of blackberry merlot rather than dry red wine. I sometimes add half rum and half apricot brandy. I ALWAYS add peaches, strawberries, Kiwi, and sometime grapes to the citrus. Everyone loves scooping those up and eating them after they get to the bottom of the sangria. Don't skip on soaking the fruit in the rum and sugar for 2 hrs, and stir it up a couple of times during that 2 hrs.
Took this to a Sangria Tasting Party and it won. It's an awesome recipe.

This recipe i have been using for years and people pretty much lick the pitcher clean! I just made this for Labor Day weekend to take to the beach and my boyfriend drank more of it than I do and he hates wine!! I usually bring either 7-up or Sierra Mist to cut down on the strength because it is STRONG!!

Incredible! I followed everyone else's advice and cut down on the rum a bit, and diluted it just a bit with club soda. I used Cabernet Sauvingon and it was fabulous. Great recipe, total hit with everyone!
Had the girls over....WE LOVED it....ease up on the rhum though...it is powerful.... 1 cup is enough....
Very good recipe. Made it when a friend from out of town came. Plenty for 4 of us, we had it the next day.

Unreal! I have made this several times making my own adjustments each time, and it's always a winner. Just about any fruit works well, and I buy the cheapest wine possible and it's still great. I always get compliments when I make it and if you use the amount of rum called for in the recipe, look out! It'll sneak up on you!

Absolutely wonderful! Reminded me of when I was in Spain. I think next time, though, I might cut back a little on the rum. Either I'm a lightweight or that's pretty powerful stuff. The flavors were fantastic, though!

I agree with some of the reviewers about using spiced rum (Captain Morgan's) - it adds a unique flavor. I have served this at two parties and both times it was gone before all of the guests had even arrived.

I used this recipe twice, and it is really great. It's much, much better than the sangria that restaurants serve. Blackberry merlot, as suggested, works well, as does 750 mL of 80-proof rum (gold or dark rum).
Keeper!!! Refreshing and addictive summer drink! I too followed advice of others and used blackberry merlot...delicious!!

A huge hit with my boyfriend! I used a little more Captin Morgan than what was called for (to make it a little stronger) and added more citrus fruits (orange, pineapple). A wonderful summertime drink!
Excellent Sangria!
AWESOME RECIPE!! Use kiwis, strawberries, blueberries, and oranges for fruit. Used 3/4 cup of spiced rum which was the perfect amount.

YUM!!! This is such a good dish! I thought it sounded good just by reading the recipe and by reading the reviews from other users...but it was even better than I had expected. I am not much of a cooker and found this dish very easy to make. My husband went nuts about it and is already asking me to make it again! Thanks for sharing!

This recipe is a hit! To save time, I juiced the orange, lime and lemon, skipping the floating fruit and 2 hour "flavor development" phase entirely. To save my liver, I cut the rum content in half. Finally, we served the sangria in tall, ice filled glasses, continually refilling the ice. This makes for the perfect summer, out on the deck drink! Yum yum.
This is a great summertime drink! I brought it over by a friend's and we sat outside in the sun, listening to the oldies, and sippin' on this Sangria. It was just perfect.
This is a great summertime drink! I brought it over by a friend's and we sat outside in the sun, listening to the oldies, and sippin' on this Sangria. It was just perfect.
Great recipe! Next time I would add less sugar, but still really good.
This sangria was wonderful. I added a little more sugar just because I prefer added sweetness. But I will definitely file this recipe and use it often!

VERY VERY GOOD RECIPE!! Big hit here tonight. :) I will definitely be serving this alot. I used all the fruit this called for plus lots of strawberries. We used the blackberry wine. I only had 3/4 cup of rum in the house..but it was still very strong that way. SO we added some sprite to the pitcher as well. Very good combo!!!
I just made this with Splenda instead of sugar. It's fantastic! I cut the rum to a splish more than half of the recipe.

This was good even though it was quite potent. I made it for a 4th of July barbecue and all the guests loved it. I typically don't serve Sangria over ice but found it worked well with this recipe since the ice made it a little less strong. I also added some Sprite for those that were overwhelmed by the rum. I tried one batch with inexpensive wine and another with mid-price and the cheaper stuff was better. Very festive and the chopped apple I added was mmm, mmm good! Good recipe! I highly recommend it!
wow - was this strong!! i took the advice of others and cut back on the rum just a bit...delicious just the same....i will make this again.

Classic sangria at its best. I threw a big party and made 50 servings of this and it went fast. For the wine, I used the Charles Shaw Shiraz from Trader Joes - at $2 a bottle, it makes it an economically feasible party drink. I figured if you're going to add sugar and orange juice to wine, you shouldn't bother with the expensive stuff. Thanks for the recipe!
This was very good. A nice treat in the summer time.
Loved it!! I followed the recipe exactly and it was great! Will definitely make again!
Yum - packs a punch though. Only change i made was 1 cup rum, and 1/2 cup orange liquer. Definately a keeper.
AWESOME!!!!!!

Thank you, this was a great hit at a party I had to give. I used some of the the other reviews and used the spiced rum and blackberry wine. I also added apples, peaches, and strawberries. I made a double batch and there was none left over, everyone loved it.
So good! You gotta try this!

AWESOME! I served this at a dinner party and everyone loved it! I used Lambrusco wine and soaked pineapple, red grapes, limes, and oranges in the rum & sugar mix for a day and a half. Nummy!!! Will make again!!

This recipe is awesome. I've made it twice, with rave reviews both times. The first time I made a single recipe for a superbowl party. It finished in fifteen minutes. The second time I doubled the recipe for a baby shower, and it was gone in a few hours. Next time, I'll have to quadruple the recipe, and then we'll see.
YUMMY! Made it for Christmas dinner and it was gone in a flash.
I was expecting clear sangria. It wasn't. I used Chlien Merlot, vitamin OJ, and dri-light rum. OJ wasn't crystal clear. Wrong wine too??
Delicious and SO easy!!! My parents enjoyed it too. Not overly sweet either. I used Lambrusco. Will definitely make again!

My friends love this recipe and it's easy to make. My only caution is that you may want to reduce the rum as the drink is strong but deceptive. I always caution people against eating too much of the fruit also. It's only fun when you know how much you are drinking!

I made this for a bridal shower and it didn't go over too well. I think it was just way too strong. Next time I'll dilute the wine with a clear soda of some kind. I used burgundy wine and only 1 cup of rum.

I've made this recipe twice, and both times, I've been asked for the recipe! Some of the folks did add some ginger ale, and said it was great like that too. Easy - both in the making, and in the going down! Will make again and again!

I made this exactly like the recipe said (ok- a little less rum) and it turned out fabulous. Since it packs quite the punch my dinner party got off to a roaring start and just continued going on that way!

Very good, and such a beautiful presentation in a clear glass pitcher! I'm not much of a wine drinker, though, so I diluted it with giner ale. (And as a side note, it was not as good the next day; it seemed to have become bitter.) Thanks, Lisa!
Excellent! My favorite on cold winter nights! Thanks for sharing.
I had to dilute it with 7-UP. Guests complained about the strength. I guess we're sissies...
Exceptionally good...
Incredible! I served this for Christmas brunch in a punch bowl and it was a hit! I am serving again tonight for New Years.

Wow! I first tried this for July 4th and I haven't stopped getting requests to bring it to functions! I use blackberry wine and in addition to the citrus, I throw in sliced strawberries and peaches. Be careful...It's easy to drink a lot of this!
I just got back from Seville and this was so close to the real thing...Two glasses will have you GOOD for the rest of the night. Start out with less rum-- you can always add more later.
I just got back from Seville and this was so close to the real thing...Two glasses will have you GOOD for the rest of the night. Start out with less rum-- you can always add more later.
This is a fantastic recipe! Easy and a big hit with everyone! But be careful... this sangria is so delicious your guests will have a very good time ;)
Absolutely the best Sangria I've ever had! Will make this every summer. Wherever I take it I'm asked for the recipe!

This is a perfect sangria recipe. Without changing a thing, it tasted delicious (and it packs QUITE the punch). I mixed some with ginger ale and it was good, but everyone preferred the classic version. Also, the rum-soaked citrus fruits are perfect for cooking with chicken. Thanks!
yum, and really easy.
I used the blackberry merlot and changed the fruits to rasperries, strawberries & grapes because I prefer berries in my sangria. It was a hit!

I used Blackberry Merlot, Spiced Rum and added a little Triple Sec. I also added lots of fruit that I soaked in spiced rum and sugar for 24 hours. I made this in a punch bowl and used an "ice ring" made from sprite. It was a big hit.
My guests dont appreciate the dry wines I like, so I decided to try this Sangria...everyone loved it! Next time will have to do a double-batch! Thanks, and... Salud!
Awesome! I made this for a party and there was not a drop left. Everyone keeps calling for the recipe.

Excellent Sangria!!! After reading the reviews I decreased the amount of rum to 1 cup, but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. I made this for my friends and they all loved it. They kept saying it was strong and downing one glass after another. When it was all gone they wanted more. I will definately make this again, but probably use a little more sugar or a different wine (I don't usually drink wine, so this was missing just a bit of sweetness for my taste).

Awesome! I made a triple-batch and took it to the lake in a huge rubber-maid sealed container. I only used strawberries and oranges - the fruits I knew most people liked. I also used a big bottle of Macaroni Grill Chianti wine - it's less than $6 but tasted great!

Made this for my girlfriends surprise party, everyone loved it and had seconds. Made a double batch and left it overnight and it was gone in no time. I'm definitely going to make this again. Blackcurrant Merlot and Captain Morgan's Spiced Rum is the way to go! I only put a 1/4 cup of sugar and that was sweet enough.
Delicious! Everyone LOVED it. Went through a double batch in no time. I wouldn't change a thing!
I made the recipe with 1/3 C of sugar, and it was still too sweet. If I follow this recipe again I will try less than 1/4 C sugar and 1/2 C orange juice.
My first try at Sangria & everyone loves it!I have a friend that lived in Chile and she was insisting that the rum would ruin it,well she makes this Sangria now over the one she got from Chile.
A huge hit, although I lemons, limes, apples & pears, soaked in the sugar-rum mix overnight, and then added extra rum to taste when mixing. I use spiced rum, and it was delicious.

Excellent recipe. I used the spiced rum and the suggested fruit. It's a very strong drink, so I had extra orange juice that my guest added themselves. Also, I should have doubled it since it went quickly.
I served this at our 4th of July party, & it was a hit! I loved it!

Very good! Lots of requests for the recipe. Used the Blackberry Merlot, Capt. Morgan's Spiced Rum, and tons of fruit. I also cut out the Sprite. I soaked the fruit for two days. Huge hit at the 4th of July picnic. :)
Yum! Taking the advice of reviewers I cut the sugar down to 1/3 cup. I also added Honeydew melon balls and strawberries. This stuff was great and a big hit. I'll definately be making it again.

Very good! I used white rum and will spiced next time.......I used only a cup of rum and was glad I didn't use the full dose! (this is a sneaky brew, all right!) I am also going to try cutting the sugar a bit but adding the lemon-lime pop. I think I would like the tickle of carbonation. Perfect addition to our 4th of July backyard picnic!
Excellent! My boyfriend really loved it, he said it was the best Sangria he had ever tasted--better than his mom's! I will be making this again!
This is a HUGE hit at parties! It turned a little bit too sweet for me, so I use 1/4 cup of sugar. Thanks for the great Sangria recipe!

This was my first attempt at sangria and definitely not my last! The recipe was a big hit, but only after I had to add several cups of Sprite. Without the Sprite, this was just entirely too strong. Still, once the minor adjustment was made, I'd say this is a wonderful recipe (and my guests would say so, too!)
We went to Portugal on our honeymoon and this sangria recipe comes pretty close! It brought back great memories. We put in some mint leaves and it was delicious!!!

I read the reviews and went with the Blackberry Merlot and cut the white sugar in half. I made a triple batch, but only used a fifth of Bacardi white rum. I also soaked the fruit for 2 days, turning it twice a day to make sure it all got nice and soaked. Nectarines, Lemons, Limes, Apples, Oranges, Strawberries were what I used. Next time, much more strawberries and maybe 1 lemon and more oranges. I thougt of using Orange flavored rum and cut out all the white sugar, but thought I should just change one thing at a time. Wonderful, the fruit and drink was gone in no time.

We loved this version of sangria. I followed the suggestions & used both the Capt. Morgan's spiced rum & the blackberry merlot. We didn't bother with the sprite, but would have if guests wanted it. I used lots of fruits (the suggested and peaches, grapes, strawberries, pears). The remaining "happy fruit" in the bottom of the empty pitcher was a bonus! Not a piece was left!
Very good. Used Captain Morgans with Roja wine. Was a little strong, but after the first glass I didn't notice.

EXCELLENT! I ADDED STRAWBERRIES, PINEAPPLE, OJ, PINEAPPLE JUICE, AND A SPLASH OF SPRITE. I HAD TO MAKE 3 MORE BATCHES OF IT THROUGHOUT THE PARTY. IT'S GREAT, BUT IT WILL SNEAK UP ON YOU. THANKS FOR THE GREAT RECIPE.
Great recipe and very easy to make!
I had to make another batch in the middle of the party!! Even the "beer drinking" guys loved it! Will defintely make this again.

This was my first attempt at Sangria. I took the advice of others and used Blackberry Merlot, as well as spiced rum. I topped each serving with Sprite, and it was fantastic! When the Sangria was gone, I filled the pitcher with the remaining Sprite, so it could "soak up" the juices left in the fruit. It was a more "mellow" drink, which was needed after finishing the pitcher of Sangria. Thanks so much for this recipe!

This was very good as well, but I changed the recipe a bit. I used a 1.5 liter bottle of wine, 2 cups of rum, 1 cup of sugar, and 2 cups of OJ. My grandma even went wild over it. I also soaked strawberrys, pineapple, and marschino cherries in equal amounts of OJ and Rum overnight and that was very, very good as well. I did not add the fruit to the sangria, I put it in a seperate bowl so people could pick out what they wanted. It worked out well.

A good use of homemade wine, I added a little more juice (1/4 c. apple juice) and a variety of cut up fruit in the mixture - strawbs, cut grapes, kiwis - once discovered at a huge family dinner...GONE.
The best I've had since I sat at the cafe on La Calle Princesa in Madrid.. I plan on serving this all summer!
It's perfect. It's simple. A party favorite. If you want to splurge use Captain Morgan Private Stock Spiced Rum with a tad bit more orange juice...you'll never know what hit you.
Not the best I've had but the neighbors enjoyed it.
This mixture was pretty potent! It had a really good flavor but I added some (about 3/4 cup to the pitcher) Sprite to cut the bite down a little bit. Great spring BBQ drink!
This is now my staple for parties. I use Captain Morgans for the rum and lots of fruit, apples & pears. Yes they do soak up the rum but mmmmm are they delicious. People love my "happy apples".
We've made this for a couple of parties, and it's always a big hit! very refreshing for summer.
excellent! A great way to use up a cheap bottle of red wine.
Delicious!!!Used Wild Vines Blackberry Merlot,and no sugar,to make it a little less intoxicating.Strawberries were a great addition,you'll be tempted to eat all the fruit at the bottom!
VERY NICE- a nice alternative to all that citrus is to use rum-soaked halved strawberries.
I had to add a lot more orange juice, but I think it was my own fault...the rum I had on hand was 151 proof - I think I should have cut the amount in half! It tasted like pure alcohol!

Awesome!! I decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup because I'm not fond of really sweet drinks. I was in a rush, so I didn't get to chill it, but adding an ice cube or two to a glass was just perfect. Thanks for the recipe!
pretty good, though not the BEST. my friend has the BEST sangria recipe, but he won't share it with me!!!!!

This is a fabulous recipe!! I have shared with many friends. It was easy to make, and everyone enjoyed it. Careful though. It tastes like fruit juice, but you feel the effects of the alcohol later. Great to make for large parties.

WAY GOOD!!! Apples worked just fine. Also works well with brandy instead of rum. I have made this several times with various fruits {the produce kind as well as my friends}and every time was awesome! Thanks! Erin
followed recipe to a T. Way too strong. Put in a cup of 7up and more sugar, still not well recieved
This recipie is so easy and never fails to get compliments at our parties. A definite keeper!
watch out... this is strong stuff! maybe try less rum...

I made this recipe for a tapas themed party with friends from college. I thought this was a killer sangria and enjoyed it thoroughly. My friends were overwhelmed by the rum -- fortunately, you can add rum to taste for your guests. Buy smaller oranges and other fruits to fit in the pitcher. This is a great recipe! I'll make it again for sure; so easy!

OH MY!! This was fabulous! I used the spiced rum and along with the citrus I added some plum slices. If you desire a less potent Sangria cut the rum in half. The flavor is still wonderful. Freeze orange juice in ice cube trays and add a cube to each individual serving. YUM
over labor day weekend i made 4 batchs, everybody raved about it, great recipe
Great!! Big hit at mexican-themed party we recently held. I think there were only about 6 of us drinking it, and we went through almost 3 batches! Went down nice and smooth, as long as it's cold!
This was very good, but extremly strong. Will use less rum next time.

a wonderful recipe. i added lots of different types of fruit. i loved it as is, but i made this for my family and they had to add lots of sprite because it was so strong and a little extra sugar too. i recommend trying it as the recipe says and adjust to your own taste once it's finished.
Deceptively intoxicating, but extraordinarily good. We used the white rum, and chilled the fruit mixture overnight.
YUM! I made this for a "girls gathering" and it was a big hit. A little goes a long way...
I made 2 pitchers and brought to a pig roast! My brother drank 1 pitcher by himself!

Fabulous! I made a lot of this for a family party and everyone loved it. I served it out of a punch bowl and it looked very festive and tasted great. Next time I would like to cut the fruit into half slices and maybe add some different fruits - apples or cherries for color. Thanks for a great recipe!
Took this to the beach and served over ice. All of my friends loved it. We all will make it again.
Made a double batch for my husband's 50th birthday party and didn't have a drop left. Used spiced rum and made ice rings from fruit and Sprite (so they wouldn't dilute it). Fabulous!
Thanks for this recipe! It was Yummy - very strong, though.
Having made different versions of Sangria, I found this to be one of the very best recipes.
Followed the recipe exactly for Cinco De Mayo and it was very good. My husband and I really enjoyed this and would definitely make it again.
This sangria recipe is really really really good!!!!! Next time we'll use a little more rum.
ABSOLUTELY MARVELOUS!!!!!!! I used spiced rum and followed the rest of the recipe to a 'T'. This is wonderful!
Just made this for a party - everyone loved it! Just beware that this beverage is very potent - or you might just be wearing the fruit slices as earrings!

This is a wonderful sangria recipe. I used Bacardi's spiced rum and decreased the fum amount to 1 cup. A glass punch bowl worked great for presentation. I also added a few large ice cubes to keep the sangria chilled. Your guests will love this!
Good fruity drink, next time I would like to add apples. Would be great with paella or mexican food.

This tasted great! I've never had Sangria but my "Sangria expert" guest said it was perfect. I doubled the recipe for a party of 12 and put it in a punch bowl and it made for a great presentation. Tasted very nice and looked good. Just make sure you stir it whenever you are walking by after mixing all the ingredients to dissolve all the sugar.
Great taste. A little strong. I added less rum the second time, and a little more sugar, too.
Used the recommended ingredients and it came out yummy!

Wow, thanks guys for all the great reviews (this is Lisa, I lost that old password). I submitted this recipe almost 2 years ago, and it'e evolved since then. I've cut back the rum, added a bit of Triple Sec, and substituted Splenda for the sugar, and I use fresh pineapple, some pineapple juice with the orange, and strawberries now, too. (I still don't like apples!)

Wow! This was soo great! I used Bacardi White Spiced Rum and a spicy dry red wine. I served it in a glass pitcher and so it was not only yummy but beautiful on the table. This was the perfect touch to my dinner party and I am so glad I came across this recipe!

This was such an easy recipe! I did add 1 cup sugar and used 1/2 brandy along with the 1 cup of rum. I also filled glasses 3/4 way and topped it off with 7-up. It was too strong without it for our tastes.....Love this drink!!!!!!!!!
This worked perfectly with a Mexican themed meal I recently prepared. My guests really enjoyed it.

I served this with the Spanish paella recipe and they were both big hits at my dinner party. Plus I only had about 1/3 cup orange juice so I used 100% grape juice to make up the difference. The sangria was still very nice. Highly recommended.
We did not have enough time to prepare this recipe as indicated and it still tasted great! We intend to try it again the right way as we are sure it will be even better!
Super simple--any bottle of "cheap red wine" will work, and we loved it with Spiced Rum!
We let it stand overnight in the fridge without ice and Soda. This intensified the flavours. Added them both right before serving at the table. Absolutely delicious.
Quick, simple and delicious. We add a 1/4 cup of Coconut Rum to it as well, for a bit more of a tropical hint.
Loved it.
Perfect. It was a big hit for a summer birthday party.
I made for a large group so we followed the recipe x 4 and kept the mix in a pitcher and added club soda to the glass. It definitely reminded us of our beach vacations by the pool
Too much sugar. I would recommend 1/4 to 1/3 cup. Other than that they are a hit. Paires with chicken fajitas... yum.
Simple and wonderful

Good recipe. A nice change from so-sweet margaritas. The only thing I'd did differently is use my KitchenAid mixer to do the muddling! You'll need to cover the mixer head with a cup towel while muddling the lines or juice will go everywhere. Pour the ice and run in and stir. Pour all into a pitcher and serve.
Followed exactly, delicious & perfect amount! Thanks for sharing!
Delicious! Take your time muddling the mint and sugar, it’s worth it!
Absolutely delicious! I only added 1/4 cup of white sugar though and it was still pretty sweet.
Good base but I’d do 1 1/2 to 2 cups rum.

Made this for a family lunch and it was AMAZING. I used sugar-free Strawberry soda instead of club soda and it was so good. The combination of Strawberry, Lime, and Mint was the key. Oh, and I also used Malibu Coconut Rum.
This was good. The only thing I would say is don't leave the limes in the pitcher too long or they will make your drink bitter.
Fabulous as written, exactly what I was looking for! This recipe didn't specify what kind of rum to use but other mojito recipes used white rum so I did as well.

Made these yesterday, because I had a few girlfriends coming over for an afternoon get together. They were absolutely delicious! Not too sweet and very refreshing. A perfect summertime drink. We polished off the pitcher in a couple of hours, and I received many compliments. I followed the recipe exactly, except that the only white rum I had on hand was infused with lemon, but that seemed to work out just fine. This is now going to be my go-to make-ahead cocktail for casual summer gatherings.
Delicious and easy to prepare.

Excellent recipe—great proportion recommendations, especially in regards to the amount of mint. I must admit, however, that I doubled the amount of alcohol to two cups and did not find it overpowering. Some may think there is too much sugar, in which case they can just use a little less than recommended. However, considering it makes an entire pitcher, one 1/2 cup is not an overwhelming amount of sugar. Additionally, the steps could be a little revamped; I find the mint flavour (Canadian here) is absorbed better when it is ground up with the juice of the limes in addition to the sugar.
Easy and yummy

This is my go-to recipe for mojitos, so easy and delicious! I always double the recipe and after pouring into glass I will top off with a little lemon-lime soda, not much. Everyone loves these, even anti-mojito drinkers!

I’ve been looking for a recipe to make a whole batch of mojitos and this was perfect! It was just like the traditional mojito recipe I’ve always made but so much easier to make a whole pitcher at once rather than one at a time. The only downfall is that I ended up having to make 3 1/2 batches because they were such a hit!
These were great! I didn’t have club soda, so I substituted Sprite Zero. I had to cut the sugar back by 1/2 to accommodate the sub.
We enjoyed the drink we need to use less mint
DELICIOUS!!!!!!Better with the raw sugar in my opinion
Awesome! Everyone loved including me and I am not a mojito person!
I used tonic water instead. wonderful refreshing drink
I want to make this but need to buy the Rum. Do I buy the light or the dark rum?

So easy - the only problem is that it really doesn’t make enough. I’ve made them a few times now and I almost always omit the rum (my parents don’t drink) and add some extra club soda. I make two pitchers (at least) with fresh mint from my garden a few hours before company comes, and then let them chill in the fridge until serving.
Saved for my son and he and everyone at his party sent cheers,he added a little more lime in the other pitchers he made.They were all very happy.
I decided to juice most of the limes because I feared too much rind would make the drink bitter tasting.
Followed the recipe to a T, and it is fantastic! Thank you.
So easy and delicious. Thanks for sharing!

I thought the proportions were perfect but the steps needed some tweaking. For me it worked better muddling the mint (I used 6 whole sprigs) with the sugar and the juice of 2 limes. I cut the third lime into wedges, and gave them a squeeze before tossing them in. Then added the rum and seltzer and stirred.

Made this for a group of friends at the cottage and it was a hit! I used sprite for a base, and added more rum, lime juice, and sprite just to polish off ingredients. It was still a bit too sweet for some. It would still be good with less sugar.
This recipe is sooo good! We used 1/3 cup sugar since we don't like drinks too sweet and it was perfect! Wish I had one right now!
It was pretty good, a little too sweet for me. Next time I will do about half the sugar and a little more liquor. It was also better the next day. I recommend making it the day prior to drinking

Really good! I used McCracken dark spiced rum and muddled sweet mint, chocolate mint, peppermint and spearmint leaves from my mojito/tea mint pot. Next time I will make with. 5 to. 75 cup sugar because I like a little less sweet mojito. So much easier than asking by the glass.
Wonderful recipe, easy, refreshing and a lot easier to make for a crowd. We enjoyed these immensely and will make them again!
Super simple, very good.
Made as written first then made the second pitcher with raw demerara sugar, and added extra rum. Both were a delicious hit!

I made this recipe for my friends. Unsurprisingly, I nailed it. Surprisingly, however, my friends found the process laborious and the drink tasteless. If i were to go back, I would change everything. I will be recommending this to my friends.
Made this just as the recipe says, for our supper group, and everyone loved it! Wouldn't change a thing!
I was about to slam this because of how sweet it is, but realized my limes were still sitting on the counter. Its very tasty once the limes were added.
Refreshing and easy to make! I have used vodka when out of rum and it was good. I accidentally used oriental apple flavored vodka before and it was surprisingly very good!
refreshing and delicious
Recipe was right on. The only changes i made were just a little less sugar and a little more rum. Cheers!!
Great easy recipe for 3 to 4 people. Everyone loves it. I added an extra 1/2 cup of rum -could probably add more.
Love it. Delicious and refreshing
I don't drink mojitos but we hosted a party for my husbands boss and he requested mojitos. I followed the recipe and everone said it came out outstanding! Thank you!
Perfect!
It was way too sweet for my tastes. The sugar overwhelmed the lime and mint. Next time I will cut the sugar by 1/3 or 1/2.
I did a 1/3 cup sugar to cut the sweet. Very tasty!
Best mojito recipe. My husband did a big thumbs up
Best mojito recipe. My husband did a big thumbs up
Simply delicious and easy recipe.
Also my first attempt at making mojitos... I used the coconut Bacardi Rum instead and it was an instant hit!! Everyone loved it, definitely making this one again.
Had to modify it a bit to fit my pitcher and I don't usually keep club soda on hand. 36 mint leaves 3 limes 1 cup simple sugar 2 cups water Add water or alcohol as needed to taste.

Tastes great. I followed the recipe but didn't use as much lime or mint as directed, although I did quarter 2 limes and halved and juiced 1 more and dropped it in the mix - used maybe 20-25 leaves. I recommend not muddling the mint in the sugar too hard because it shreds the mint into tiny bits that get stuck all over your mouth. I also used some rum in my sugar and mint to rinse out the bowl and then pour into the pitcher. Happy drinking all!!
This is a great recipe. Made it on two occasions and will definitely make it again.
Made this 3 times. Can always use more lime and mint. If you don't have a muddler, try a potato masher. Works wonderfully!

So easy and delicious! I doubled the recipe for a neighborhood bbq and they were fantastic. If you make ahead add the club soda when pouring into glasses to keep it bubbly as club soda goes flat quickly.
I bought some half gallon mason jars and made this recipe. I brought 3 jars to a Bbq and they were gone in a flash! Half gallon serves about 5-6 give or take (depending on cup size).
Awesome recipe. I added a little less sugar on the second pitcher.
Very good and easy recipe. Would not change a thing!

Delicious! For my diabetic bf I subbed Truvia for half the sugar and used Zaya rum, and it was delicious! Probably tastes even better with all sugar. Because I had to pack it to our outdoor activity in 100 degree weather, I made the mix minus the club soda the night before, then mixed it by the glass. That worked quite well.
Super Yummy!!!
Good stuff right here! I used Bacardi Limon Rum and doubled the recipe which made almost a gallon. Make ahead and take with you to an event for EASY Mojitos!
This recipe is soooo good. I doubled it and used mango Bacardi rum. Everyone raved about it and wanted the recipe. it was perfect.
I like club soda much better than lemon-lime soda, it cuts the sweetness. I also make simple syrup and keep in fridge but if you are making it 'by the glass' this recipe can't be beat!
Perfect!
This is the BEST Mojito I've every made. A question though, can the club soda be replaced with champagne? Thank you for sharing your recipe.
Just right! Also good with a few added raspberries

Every year when the weather warms up, we have a Cuban party. I made another recipe the first year (I had a by the glass recipe), and between making mojitos and the Cuban sandwiches, I spent all my time in the kitchen. I found this recipe last year, and I simplified my life. I doubled the recipe so to fit our 2 liter pitcher, and muddled the mint and sugar ahead of time, enough for four pitchers. I really do prefer the actual sugar as opposed to the simple syrup recipes, and this one is just perfect. Take my advice and make them ahead if you are serving a crowd. You won't regret it.
Completely delicious and simple!
Simple easy recipe.The Mojitos came out great! Not too sweet, and very refreshing over ice on a hot summer evening. It's definitely a keeper!

Awesome mojito's! I'm one of those people who wasn't a huge fan of mojito's...the "squeeze", however, loves them! So happy I found this recipe as now we both enjoy when we make up a pitcher! I made the recipe exactly as posted.
Best Mojito recipe I've tried :)

You don't have to chill the copper mugs, they'll get and keep cold when you fill them with ice cubes. I used the 1/2 cup (4 ounces) of Crabbie's Orginal Alcoholic Ginger Beer and all the other ingredients but added one more: 1 tsp of 'simple syrup' which I made by using a 1:1 ratio of water and sugar (1/4 cup water to 1/4 cup sugar or any equal amounts you choose) then microwaving in a glass bowl (NOT in the copper mugs!) and stirring it to dissolve the sugar. The left over simple syrup should be sealed tightly and refrigerated to be used for other recipes within a week. Adding the sugar makes this a 5-star recipe as it tempers the sour/acid of the lime a bit.

The brand / quality of ginger beer makes a big difference. With a 'spicy' to balanced ginger beer, I like to add a splash of simple syrup. I really like Bundaberg, or Seattle's Rachel's Ginger Beer. You can skip the syrup if you pick a sweeter ginger brew. Fill your cocktail shaker with a handful of ice, pour in your favorite vodka, slice and squeeze the lime right in there, add the splash of simple syrup, and shake away. Pour the chilled / strained mix into your copper mug (but a glass timber can suffice), then top it with cold ginger beer and serve.

The key to using sugar vs simple syrup, is to use Caster Sugar or Baking Sugar, it is finer and dissolves much faster! Easy to make, just put 1 cup of regular sugar in food processor for 1 minute... If you are putting fresh lime wedges in, you need the grit of the sugar to assist the muddler to get the oils out of the limes!! Makes the drink even fresher... 2 Tablespoons of sugar is excessive, should be 2 full spoons using proper cocktail mixing spoon...

I made this in a mason jar, so I doubled the recipe, and because I juiced the lime, I used the juice from 1.5 lime, 3 tbs simple syrup and then followed the recipe for the mint, ice, rum and club soda. I have been making subpar mojitos for a while and this recipes helped me out of that! The key is more lime and mint than you would think necessary. I agree with other reviewers in using simple syrup instead of sugar granules, and shaking the drink helps blend the flavours much better as well.

This recipe is closest to my favorite mojito during a trip to Puerto Rico. The granular sugar is essential. Substituting simple syrup as some other reviewers suggested saves little time and detracts from the drink. The granular sugar, with the muddled lime and mint, adds to the sweet and complex texture. Serve with one of those wide straws and you'll want to drink these faster on a hot summer day than you can make them (which are still good without the rum, by the way).

Love this recipe!!

To truly make it a five star, use Agave nectar instead of sugar or simple syrup. A local bartender gave me that tip and all of his drinks have been awesome so that's how I made mine. Also...because I was making mojitos in bulk for a large party, I squeezed the lime juice ahead of time, no muddling, and used a blender for the mint mixed with some of the juice and rum. Let the mix set for several minutes and the mint "extract" will come out just as well as if I'd muddled the mint. About 1.5 gallons of mojitos lasted around 30 minutes...people loved them!!!
This recipe turned out really great for me. I substituted a stevia-sugar blend and it worked perfectly.

Trust me, you don't need to screw around with a good thing like some people suggesting here - using simple sirup, (2 cups of sugar to 1 cup of water, 2:1), unless you do this for a living and need to cut corners in order to be more productive. When it comes to making one for yourself or you friends, just use the real granulated sugar or sugar cube. Remember; muddling the ingredients together and especially the lime and mint leaves, require a good friction, grinding motion which you won't get from simple sirup!Whenever you'd be muddling sugar with citrus zests, granulated sugar is the "secret", it just requires a little extra effort which I think is well worth it especially when you perform in front of your buddies. Also don't worry about needing the "real" Cuban mint....any fresh bunch from your local store or your own yard will do. For a nice change you can even substitute fresh mint with fresh basil. Try it and let me know what you think.
