It was a tasty treat for a Thursday evening. :)

I was given fresh mint at our local growers market (score!) and needed something to do with it. Although without the muddler tool itself, I was able to muddle the mint in a glass with a rolling pin and then just squeeze the lime in with a small juicer. I also also used a whole lime instead of half and it tasted great to me. Excellent quick and tasty recipe that is easy to adjust.

I really enjoyed this. Since I'm not a Mojito connoisseur I hope you won't hate on me but I used pure organic lime juice instead of fresh limes. And since I don't do sugar, or sugar substitutes like Splenda, I used a dash (bigger dash than I meant to) of coconut nectar. I muddled it with my potato masher in a bowl. Anyway, I really enjoyed it. I don't know if others would like it the way I made it, but I liked it better than the few I've had in bars. Thanks!!
I skinnied it up -- substituted the sugar with Splenda. This lowers the carbs & cals, and Splenda melts instantly so its a win win. Yum!
Yummy patio drink by the pool #SummerTime2014 #Summer2014 =)

I made this recipe the other night. Delicious!! On the second one I only used 1 tablespoon of sugar. @ was a little to sweet for me. Just a tip for you Mojito lovers out there. I went to amazon.com and bought stainless steel mesh tea balls.(about $3.00 a piece) After I muttled the mint I put them in the mesh ball. The mesh ball comes with a chain and a hook. Just put in the glass put the hook on the rim and mint leaves don't float in you glass. I make big batch of these for our summer party and these keep the nozzle on our container from clogging up.
This tastes fine
Easy and delicious. Strongly recommend making and using sugar syrup; it blends perfectly. Also try this with over proof Jamaican rum---seriously awesome!
Perfect -- the only change I will make is to permanently change the recipe to make a pitcher :). absolutely delicious!!
When making simple syrup, add mint leaves to the mix to make mint simple syrup.

I tried this recipe and not having a mortar and pestle I used my ice cream scoop. It worked great. I thought 2 tablespoons of sugar was too much. I ended up having to crush the 4th lime wedge, add a squirt of lime juice (the plastic one), add more seltzer water and a trickle more rum. In other words a taller drink to cut the sweetness. I bought my own mint plant today just to make Mojitos. I think tomorrow I am going to go buy another one - this time the variety with the fuzzy leaves. I think it will be better.
Having sipped Mojito's on a couple visits to Havana, I'd say this was spot on!
Very Yummy and refreshing!!!!
I make these often but replace the rum with vodka as rum doesn't agree with me. Every time I serve them I get the same response. "so refreshing!"
The ingredients are good but you'll really need to use a simple syrup.
Love the recipe brought memories of Cuba back! I also added a dash of Bitters to it! Brought out a whole other taste!

Thank you ! This recipe is perfect. My husband had the exact recipe (I tried it) we both loved it. I made mine substituting agave nectar for the sugar( I'm type 1 diabetic) it was excellent as well ( i would use less agave nectar next time) I wouldn't change anything about this recipe!

Definitely a good place to start. Once you're ready to step it up , replace the sugar with one ounce of simple syrup (heat 1 cup water & 1 cup sugar I'm saucepan and let cool) and use 2 ounces of rum.

excellent !!! very refreshing I used lemons instead of limes because that is what I had I also used Sierra Mist instead of club soda and did not add any sugar not sweet - but not bitter next time I will use limes :)

This recipe gets a 4/4 for proportions and taste, but 2/4 for method. I find that muddle-ice-rum-soda does not infuse the whole drink with the minty, limey deliciousness that I want in a mojito. I HIGHLY recommend using this recipe's directions, but muddling your mint and limes (first mint and 1 lime, then 2 more limes) in a cocktail shaker, then adding sugar, rum, and ice and shaking until your hands freeze! Pour it ALL into a glass, fill up with more ice, and top with club soda. The result is frosty and flavorful. Seriously though, as far as ingredients and proportions, this is now my only mojito recipe. Perfect!!!
This drink came out perfect. Followed the recipe exactly. Made 6 batches with 3 limes and two packs of mint. Very tasty. It is on the sweet side so if you are not into sweet, don't add as much sugar.
Great taste, I replaced the sugar for splenda since I do not use sugar, and it was great!

Thanks for the recipe. I liked it a lot. It was fine to me with just the granulated sugar but it did not dissolve like I would have liked, even shaking it like crazy. (if you are going to shake it, don't shake it with the club soda, add the club soda after shaking). Next time I will try to use the simple syrup like others suggested.

I usually hate Mojito's but recently had a really good one at a local spot, so I decided that I would try making it myself. This is a really good recipe exactly how it is written! I will try the simple syrup trick next time and will update.
Wow! Didn't do the syrup but I will when I make a batch. But regardless OMG! The rum will sneak up on you be careful. Enjoy this is amazing!
Yum!!! Followed recipe exactly.
I fell in love with this recipe at once. I served it to the Poker group and they are requesting it as a regular beverage item now.
Haven't tried it yet but at my next function,it's gonna be a hit!
Best mojito I've ever had. Best if made in a pitcher, stirred very well incorporating ingredients that settle on the bottom, and then pouring into glasses. A winner!
My daughter grew mint for a school project. When I saw this recipe I figured why not? Well this is so good and simple. Loved it!
I am sipping on one now. It's refreshing, looks nice and reminds me of the Bacardi rum factory in Puerto Rico.

loved this. wanted to make a large quantity for a picnic at Ravinia. i adjusted the recipe to 25 servings and put 250 mint leaves and 3 cups sugar in a blender. used this as my base for the rest of the ingredients at the venue. delicious!
I normally do not leave reviews but, this recipe is amazing! Love it! This recipe reminds of Mojitos we had in Miami. Thanks for sharing.
If you add little bit of sprite in it you will find it much tastier

We make these with Vodka though and for the 4th we make them with blueberries...spectacular and for Christmas cranberries. Outstanding! Very ones fav drink. The vodka everyone agrees makes them more refreshing.
The Carribean version of a mint julep ,as they say, When in Rum do as the Rummies do.
Mojitos are my favorite! I sometimes use icing sugar instead of simple syrup as it dissolves easily (1tbsp). Another favorite is to use a tbsp of real maple syrup!
So easy... So refreshing... Thank-you so very much!~
So easy... So refreshing... Thank-you so very much!~

I made this with Perrier and fresh mint that was in plastic from the supermaeket. I used Splenda instead of sugar and muddled it with a wooden spoon. It was fantastic !!!!!! I accidentally put in 8 ounces of Perrier instead of 4 ounces but still it was delicious!
Easy and refreshing.
After muddling the mint and the lime the drink is full of tiny lime and mint parts. You kinda have to strain it unless you want to drink with "pulp".
Yum, great recipe, very simple. I feel like I should be lounging in the Caribbean!
Easy and delicious!

Excellent recipe as is. I didn't bother with the simple syrup - why make it harder on yourself when regular sugar works perfectly?? I just wanted a quick and easy recipe, and this was exactly that, plus it's delicious! It's just like any mojito I've had in bars, so I'm going to stick with this recipe (with the granulated sugar). One evening, I had Malibu coconut rum in the house, so I used that - serendipity! SOOO yummy.

DELICIOUS! Light, refreshing and a perfect blend of tart and sweet. After reading a considerable amount of reviews and the suggestions given in another review by the author, Brandy, I believe the key to getting this drink perfect is to be sure to use SUPERFINE SUGAR. I was going to try both simple syrup and the sugar to see which one worked best, but I decided at the store while picking up the mint leaves to check and see if they had the superfine sugar. They did and I bought it. This is definitely the key to adding the sugar easily. I used a mortar and pestle to muddle the ingredients and the superfine sugar just melted into the lime juice beautifully and completely with zero effort. The full dissolving of the sugar meant that it was going to mix into the drink evenly and give the proper amount of sweetness in every sip. I'll continue to use the superfine sugar because it's so easy and quick. I also splurged on a beautiful bottle of white rum called Oronoco and I believe that also made a big difference. My finished drink was smooth, perfectly sweet and tart and beautiful to look at. And I'm sure it's easy to overdo it - this cocktail went down way too easily!I used a swizzle stick and stirred it every now and then to keep mixing the flavors as I sipped it. I felt like I was on vacation. This is going to be my new special summer drink and I'm going to make another one this afternoon since it's so hot outside! Thank you, Brandy!
I absolutely loved this recipe! We made it in a blender since we were making multiple drinks. Delicious!

Good, but a few tweaks make a better mojito. First, stay away from the simple sugar as the most helpful comment suggests. I have tried it and liken it to lemonade made in the same manner(I hate it!). I like having some undissolved sugar in my drink. I use a citrus reamer to juice half a lime and crush it into the the mint leaves. If I'm being lazy I use enough bottled Key West lime juice to dampen the 2TBS sugar. Also try using SPRITE (or even ginger ale) instead of club soda. MOST IMPORTANTLY MIX EVERYTHING BEFORE ADDING THE CLUB SODA/SPRITE. Then add your carbonation and give the drink a quick swirl or two. Unless you must know exactly how much alcohol you are consuming dont bother measuring out the rum. After filling my glass near to the top with ice, I simply pour the glass about 2/3-3/4 of the way full of rum.
I like to use 151 proof Bacardi, and gold rum. I use a few drops of mint extract and a short squirt of agave nectar. Splendid!!
Just like the real thing I had in San Juan. Mmmm!

This is a pretty good recipe for a single drink but if I were going to make a full pitcher of mojitos, I'd make a mint-infused simple syrup instead of using granulated sugar. Granulated sugar just doesn't dissolve very well. I have plenty of spearmint in my back yard and this is a perfect treat after an afternoon of working on the pool and in the back yard. Thumbs up!
Not bad, but I would start with half the sugar or even less and then add more to taste. I like to be able to taste the alcohol and fresh mint!
Very easy to follow and the taste is perfect!!! Thanks for the share.
This recipe was nearly perfect. The only change I made was using home made simple syrup instead of sugar, and it tasted exactly like the ones I had in Mexico!
This is the only recipe we use when making mojitos. I have mint in my backyard in the summer so this is one of our favorite drinks.
The problem with these is that they are so good we drank to many.
Omg! Been looking for the perfect mojito recipe and this is it! Thanks! Only change i made was to use brown sugar but overall, perfect!
Delicious!

Delicious! I dont measure the amount of club soda used but I think it is probably just under 1/2 cup. Otherwise I follow the recipe exactly. These are delicious. I made this recipe 3-4 times and the last time I wanted mojitos, I spent a good 5 min searching the internet for this recipe - It can't be beat!
Nice Recipe! Thanks!!!

I saved this recipe a long time ago, but only tried it today for the first time. I bought a plant with fresh mint leaves growing. I made 2, both for my husband. He gave it 5 stars, said it was the best. He drank first one in 20 seconds. Thanks for a great recipe!

Excellent...no need to fool around with the recipe. I made this with exactly the ingredients and methods described. I didn't have a muddler...so I used the fat round end of a rolling pin. It was surprisingly delicious. I had never had one before. Forget about the fancy stuff about simple syrup. Its not necessary. I found the drink easy and fast to make. There is something special about how the mint and lime combine. What a treat. I really enjoyed myself...so much that I had to take a nap afterward!
Yum
the "simple sugar syrup" must be made from brown sugar... a bit richer flavor. Go this route and you are on your way to perfection. 4 stars.

I love this recipe! I just want to reiterate that the simple syrup is the KEY difference between an ok drink and an amazing one!!! Definitely take the time to make some! I'm boiling more up as I type! ;)
Fantastic!!
As much as my wife didn't want it...you really need to put in the full amount of sugar. Once you do, you'll have a great drink! Better than then the one I bought for $7 last weekend.
This is a really great recipe! Just like the bartender makes it.

Excellent!!! I don't have a muddler so I used the flat end of a wooden meat pounder. For round two, I took out the ice and left the other remnants in the bottom of the glass then repeated the recipe. Was even better than round one!
The best! nothing else to say, except there is now mint flavored seltzer out there!!

Excellent recipe for a very refreshing mojito. Instead of sugar, I used simple syrup. Initially I made the simple syrup, but it kept recrystallizing, so I finally just purchased some (sooooo easy!). Also, my lime tree is not mature yet, and I had some key lime juice on hand from a pie that I made, so I used that. Delicious! Now I need to buy more club soda because I finished the whole bottle. Love to have these while floating in the pool!
I thought this was refreshing and delicious. I could totally see being tempted to drink a whole pitcher. The only modification I made was reducing the sugar to 1 TBS. I would use even less next time.
OMG my new favorite ! Served them at a 9 and Dine on the weekend and everyone thought they were great.
Delicious! My favorite recipe for quick and easy mojitos. Not too sweet, not too bitter.
I thought this was great. I dont like drinks too sweet so I replaced 1 tbl Splenda for the two tbl sugar.

YUM!!! Try some mango flavored rum....amazing!! I muddle the lime, sugar, mint...then add the booze. Add ice...shake, shake, shake in a shaker then add the club soda. I agree with making a simple syrup. The best summer time drink.

I've had mojitos at several restaurants/bars and some places make them better than others. This recipe was right on with the times that i've loved my mojitos. I love them on the sweeter side. i added half a teaspoon more sugar than the recipe called for, but making it with what it calls for is excellent also. I would not go through the trouble of making a simple syrup as when you muddle the leaves with sugar and lime it really does start to incorporate the sugar. Even when i've gotten this drink when we go out, you still have to stir as you continue to enjoy your drink....our new summer drink for 2012!!!

Very good recipe after reading many bad ones. I approached only slightly differently by making it the way a bartender would make it. I simply muddled the ingredients in a shaker, added ice, then poured the rum over it. I shook the drink, poured it straight into the glas then added a bit more ice and topped with club soda. There was no sense of granular sugar in it. I used all 4 limes in the muddling, but I rimmed the lime along the glass edge. I also added just a touch of roses lime. I think if you were making quantities, simple syrup would make it easier but it's not required for a couple of drinks if you shake it well. The only downside is that you do get a fair amount of floating mint, but I think that adds to it both in aroma and flavor.
Made with simple sugar and not too sweet, great balance!
Made it, drank it, loved it! Will make again and again this summer! Thanks for the recipe! *I added extra lime juice per my taste.

Try using Malibu coconut rum instead of the traditional Bacardi! My brother in law is a bartender and he made one for me with Malibu and I have never gone back! I also made a simple syrup to use instead of the sugar, which is how they make it at his bar. Simple syrup is 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water. Let the syrup dissolve in the water over low heat and then allow to cool. These are so refreshing on a hot day!
You can also add 4-5 blueberries at the muddling stage to make a pretty blueberry mojito.
Wonderfully Refreshing!
This is exactly the way I make Mojitos except I use Mango Rum which gives it (I think) a better taste.

This mojito takes some extra work compared to the other better versions I've tried. There isn't really a big significance ofquartering the time and adding it to the glass to muddle. It takes up too much room in the glass that you cannot blend the ingredients together and doesn't add any extra flavor.
What a crowd pleaser! So light and refreshing! I made this with Splenda just to cut out the calories fom the sugar and EVERYBODY loved it!
YUM!!! I made a couple of changes...I used coconut rum, only 1T sugar and 2 oz rum. So good!! And very light, as far as cocktails go.

I make this regularly in the summer. It's a great hit with friends. Very simple to make. Only a few ingredients so make sure you use good rum, fresh mint and ripe limes. Simple syrup works better than sugar. Overall, great mojito recipe.

Excellent flavor! I have been making these for a while now, and waited until I had fresh cut mint to use (instead of extracts, packaged leaves, etc) in order to give it a proper review. As with a lot of recipes, fresh ingredients make all the difference, and in this case take the drink from good to great! The only thing I insisted on doing different was to use simple syrup instead of sugar, to make sure it dissolved/blended well. Proper muddling is also key to bringing out the oils of the mint leaves (found that one out the hard way). Thanks for sharing a great recipe.

Good recipe, but I take it a step further. No mint? No problem, try using basil leaves. Want to bring down the calories? Try agave syrup. I use a shaker for this so the agave syrup mixes in. I personally prefer to use a shaker anyway. I put about 4-6 large whole basil leaves and juice of one lime in a shaker and muddle. Then added agave syrup to taste and vodka, along with ice. Shake well. Strain into tall glasses filled with ice. I add a splash of mineral water and garnish with a basil leaf.

I made this drink following the recipe and I wasn't crazy about it. I've made it a couple of times using simple syrup and it tastes delicious! The sugar just doesn't dissolve and it leaves the drunk tasting really strong and the alcohol overpowers the drink. I made the simple syrup using one cup water and one cup sugar. I also add mango or strawberry.

Hubby and I had these years ago down in Key West where Hemingway was said to have consumed these in mass quantities. I like to put a bit of sugar in the glass (tall pint type) with the mint leaves as it helps to pull the oil out of the mint when muddling. I then add mint simple syrup to taste. (easy to make, just add mint to the syrup at the end of your cooking time and let steep for 15 minutes) Also you can use plain water or seltzer or sprite or whatever tickles your palate. These are dangerous and super yum!

I think the recipe is great but keep in mind that not all varieties of mint work well. The original recipe (that is, the one served in CUBA) calls for Yerba Buena, which is completely different from other species.
Excellent! Best recipe I've found.
YUMMY! The only change I made was to use simple syrup instead of the sugar.
Made these exactly as directed, using sugar and not simple syrup. An authentic, refreshing and beautiful drink.
My girlfriend and I love the recipe as is. We tried the simple syrup idea and found that the flavor wasn't as fresh. No need to tamper with this recipe if you know what you're doing...

Awesome recipe! THanks for sharing, Brandy! We were sure to use simple syrup and it was perfect. The key is to be sure to muddle very well to get all the flavors released. Just like what I order at a bar!
It's worth it to make the simple syrup! Yum

Basically the same as how I make mine except that I use about 1 1/2 teaspoon white sugar and I use 7UP instead of club soda. I like the idea of using simple syrup... I think I might try that next time!

Great mojito! I used diet seven up instead of club soda and 1 equal packet instead of the sugar. My husband loved it and said it tasted better than the $7 mojito he paid for at a restaurant the other day.

I muddled the mint leaves with the sugar with a motar /pedstal and then added the lime as suggested and it turned out great no need to use simple syrup when you do this. I used 7 up instead of soda water and they were perfect! I also used crushed ice instead of cubes for a different flare!
SO good!!! Easy to make and my first use of my mint in my garden! Be careful because these don't taste like alcohol at all so it will sneak up on you ;)

The great thing about this aptly named recipe is that it is so authentic. It tastes as it should--not too sweet, with some granulated sugar left at the end. Almost all the reviews that call for substituting this or that or making symple syrup may suit the American palate that has been weaned on industrialized food and gulps it down as fast as you can make it, but they will never be more than a faux-jito!
YUMMY! I've also made this with Agave syrup instead of the sugar and also with vodka instead of the rum. It's great as written or with any of these substitutions. I LOVE my mint plant!
Great recipe! I added sprite for the club soda and only 1/2 T sugar and was awesome!

Really good recipe. Nice and clean. I think I will reverse a step and muddle the mint with the sugar first. Then muddle the limes in there. The muddling the mint with the sugar should really get out a lot of the mint oil. Thanks for the great recipe!
super good mojito!! my wife and i cant stop drinking them!! the only little thing i did is put sugar around the rim of the glass. excellent recipe
I think this recipe is better with 2 oz of rum. :) Also, I use my homemade simple syrup.
Pretty good.... a little too sweet for my taste, but tone the sugar down a little and after a couple you'll never know the difference. :)

I changed it just a bit to make strawberry mojito's and they were excellent! I used simple syrup instead of sugar and only used 1/4 of a lime and substituted a strawberry for the other 1/4. I also used Bacardi Dragon Bery rum instead of white rum and used 2 oz. My beer drinking husband always asks me to make these now!
I must have done something wrong, because it didn't taste quite like I expected.

Thanks A LOT; I make these and now no place I go out to makes a Mojito that even COMPARES! Guess I need to cook at home more now and whip up one of these to go along with the meal! Only thing to keep in mind is the size of your mint leaves;some can be gigantor-so adjust amount accordingly-or go with the extra-minty version you'll have!

seriously delicious! My boyfriend loves mojitos and we have a gazillion places in NY that have really great ones and he says this is pretty much the best he's had. I don't get this whole "syrup" talk - it's perfect the way it is. I just should have used more ice =P.. AND I used tonic water, because I wasn't able to find club soda for my life haha.. and it wasn't bitter at all - the sugar killed the bitterness. This is one perfect drink :)
a good solid recipe......used fresh mint from garden!

SOOOOOOOO YUMMY & REFRESHING! Second batch we added a little more lime & sugar. Next time I'll go ahead and make the simple syrup with mint...just so I can make them faster! :) The only danger with these is that they are so easy to keep drinking!
For my "skinny" mojito, I use splenda in place of the sugar. I also use bottled lime juice such as "Poe's" or "Rose's" for convenience.
I also used simple syrup.
I used simple sugar instead of table sugar because I was worried about it dissolving. Even using an equal amount of simple sugar it was a bit sweet, but still very good.
This is the best Mojito recipe!
Simple sugar tip: make ahead & make extra. Store in glass jar or Tupperware in fridge. Keeps for a week or so. Use in margaritas, iced tea, iced coffee etc. Perfect mojito recipe.
Love it! I used the syrup version and it was amazing! Can't find one this good unless your in Miami! I will be making this for all of my friends ;)

Had my first Mohito. Made the mint simple syrup as someone suggested. Used lemon lime sparkling water for this one. For my 2nd I will use club soda to see which I prefer. Having my 2nd one now. I prefer the club soda. I also used the spiced white rum, careful now, it'll sneak up on you. I don't own a muddler so I used a wooden tart form, works pretty well!
Made the simple syrup with lime as suggested by one other review and my hubby agreed it was one of the best mojito's. Now I have mastered his favorite summer drinks

I am a Mojito expert, I can tell you where to find the best Mojito in town. I just made the simple syrup and add the mint leaves and lime...DELISH AND CHEER... Now I can make it at home....Thank you for the recipe and the reviews....
this is soo good and so easy! you'll probably want some of those thin straws though so that you're not constantly drinking the mint leaves :)

This is the closest I've found to a real Mojito like your favorite bartender will mix for you. It's essential that you use fresh spearmint and lime. If you don't like the flavor of club soda with the added sugar, replace the soda and sugar with 4oz of your favorite lemon/lime drink.

I've had mojito's before but never have I tried making them myself. We really enjoyed this recipe, made as written. Very refreshing. I would though, recommend making the simple syrup as suggested by other reviewers. Also, use "ice for cocktails" from this site which really does make a difference.
Very good and easy to make! Nice for a hot, summer day!
This was good. The suggestions of the others were good. Make sure the mint leaves are fresh.

Great refreshing drink. I made simple syrup like suggested. I put everything in my shaker (except the club soda) and shook and shook. Then strained into a glass and poured the club soda on top. Then you can throw in some whole mint leaves to make this drink look super pretty. It took me three drinks to get this right! Not complaining. lol

This is very good, but I think the perfect mojito needs a mint syrup (1:1 ratio of sugar or splenda to water, boil together for ~3mins, add fresh mint leaves to taste and allow to cool together before straining). I played all weekend and the mint flavor just translated better when I used the syrup. I muddled a few mint leaves with 1 lime wedge in the glass for effect, then added to taste the syrup, rum, and lime juice; ice cubes; and topped with club soda. This also cut down on the "dirty fish tank" effect of the drink, which never bothered me much but my husband complained about. Fun to make and very refreshing, thanks so much for sharing.

Made 6x serving for a 4th of july party. Took a while to make but the results were amazing. I also made the sugar into syrup, as some suggested. Friends said it was better than what they served at their bar.

These mojitos rock. I like 10-15 leaves per glass, depending on size. I also use simple syrup and everyone loves these. Careful to not mix the lime too much or it will be ruin it because of being too sour. Thanks for a refreshing summer cocktail.
We made this last night, but we used Tonic Water instead of club soda (because it's not as bitter), & I'm so glad we did - it tasted soooooooo awesome!!!
This made excellent refreshing Mojitos...thanks for sharing!

Very good. Made just as recipe says except... My mint leaves were large so I didn't put as many thinking it would be enough, nope the more the better. OKAY, I did change it up after having a few...so "my" recipe is made in a 16 oz Tevis glass (ha ha) 10 mint leaves, Kellie & Joes Key Lime Juice, 1 tbl splenda, (muddle) Add ice, 1 1/2 fluid ozs of Parrot Bay-Key Lime, then fill with club soda.
This was really good. I made exactly as is!!
really good recipe - delicious. next time I will make simple syrup though as some of the sugar settled to the bottom and it would have been nice to have it in the drink.

I love mojitos, and they really don't sell them in bars here in Ohio..., only in restaurants. So I wanted to try to make my own, taste just as good as anywhere I've tried them! I tried the club soda, and I used sprite. I liked the sprite better, that's just me though. Thank you for the recipe, yummmm!

Pretty much the same as my recipe, although I make them a bit differently. I muddle the lime, mint and 3 tsp simple syrup in a cocktail shaker, then pour over ice and add a shot glass of Myers rum and fill with club soda. Perfect every time.

I made this cocktail two years ago, but I've just realized I didn't reviewed it. I must say I am not a Mojito lover, I prefer fruity Mojito, but this recipe is a real deal. Better than any bars can do. I didn't change a thing.
Fresh mint from the garden, a good rum. This is perfect (and dangerous)!
What a refreashing summer drink. I like this drink because it isn't so acidic and it really cools you down on a hot night.

Really good! Don't use spiced rum- it has to be white! I use natural sugar, which doesn't dissolve well. I now use sweetened lemon-lime or citrus sodas instead of the club soda & sugar. I also add extra fresh squeezed lime and get rave reviews!

Good recipe, but replace the white sugar with a simple syrup flavored with mint. (It's easy enough to make.) Also, be sure to have a muddler on hand. We used 3/4 of a lime, 3 oz. of rum, and more like 15 mint leaves per glass -- less than that was wimpy.

The ingredients are the same that I use and make the best authentic mojito. As mentioned though, I make a simple syyrup with equal parts sugar and water and I add a bunch of mint to the simple syrup, while on the stove, let simmer for about 20 minutes to infuse the mint flavor, then discard mint, add the lime juice and lightly muddle some mint leaves, for added flavor and effect. It make a mighty minty mojito, but that's how I like it.
Very authentic! Definitely a keeper!
Very nice, I added an extra splash of lime juice. I also used Splenda instead of regular sugar. Makes it low cal and dissolves easier as well.
As is, yum! However, next time I will take the simple syrup advice as the sugar does not dissolve before the mojito is gone. Granted, that doesn't take much time...
Love this recipe but have a new twist. Didn't have soda so used Pellegrino and the result was super refreshing. Will stick with this for now on.
I made a simple syrup with 15 mint leaves in it ahead of time...these were absolutely wonderful!!
A-maz-ing! We have oodles of mint in our garden and I love mojitos. This recipe is so good that my hubby and I are on our second glass. ;)
As Dallas prepares for Game 6 in Miami, this may be "beverage of choice" . . . Go Mavs!
Very simple yet tasty recipe. We use agave nectar instead of the sugar. For a little spice, try muddling some crushed red pepper and cayenne pepper in with the lime.
These are awesome made with simple syrup and club soda.
These are sooo good! Very addicting! I don't like my drinks very sweet, so I cut the sugar in half.
Delicious & perfect!! Don't skimp on the ice.
These are so good and they are very addictive. I will be making these more often!

Great recipe! I used agave nectar instead of sugar, and, although I didn't measure, I think a tiny bit more rum than 1.5 oz. Also used an ice-cream scoop since I don't own a muddler. Turned out DELICIOUS!

I definitely recommend making a simple syrup as others have recommended. It was not nearly sweet enough, because all of the sugar sank to the bottom and did not dissolve. I would add the sugar slowly to taste, as some may like it sweeter than others. I also used sweetened lime juice instead of plain lime juice which gave it a really good flavor.
This is the best recipe! Here is a bit of advice though: Plan to make 2 or more pitchers if you have more than a couple of friends. These Mojitos go down easily and are gone in a flash!
Perfection!! I used a bit more sugar, probably should have made simple syrup because I prefer it sweeter.
Esta bebida es muy bueno!

Pretty good. DEFINITELY needs all the sugar, plus a little more for my taste. These are a good base, with a little tweaking I think they can be perfect. Until them, I'll stick with the strawberry mojito mix from a local store.

Awesome recipe! Made for 20 using conversion with great results but a few logistic changes as couldn't muddle in each glass per original recipe. First, with all the cleaning, separating and muddling of the mint, it takes about an hour of hard work so start early! First, I combined most of sugar with rum and club soda in jug then used remaining sugar to separately muddle mint leaves in about 5 stages (~20 leaves at a time) with lime juice. The sugar and lime really helped with the muddling. Also, I used a juice squeezer rather than muddling for several lime because it just got to be too much work to muddle that many! I finished it about 30 minutes prior to serving and it still looked great. On serving, I added to a glass on ice and added leftover mint pieces for garnish. I got lots of positive feedback on this one. Yummy!
My neighbors all loved it - me too!
Delicious! Great summer drink recipe.
Good but not sweet enough for me so I added more sugar and some sprite and yum!
Excellent recipe as is and easy to make subtle modifications to.
It was my first attempt and my husband was very happy. Both of us loved it

This has been my official summer drink for several years and a tried and true authentic recipe. The only other ingredient I add is 3 to 4 few drops of Angostura bitters; it does make a difference. For those looking to cut calories and/or corners substituting Sprite Zero for the sugar and club soda works very well.
Go to Cuba every year and this is my favourite drink. Fotrunate enough to have wild mint growing at my cabin in the bush so we enjoy the freshest mohito on the lake! Enjoy!

Being the lush chef that I am, I recommend a 2:1 soda to rum ratio. Also use a quality rum like cruzan triple distilled light, not lighter fluid bacardi. This drink is intended to respect a high class rum. Stuck at work....wish I could pour one right now: )
Great drink. I added a bit more lime. I like it tart!

Great Mojito recipe! I used maybe a 1/2 T. of sugar (to help with emulsifying the mint & lime), and then used a simple syrup to sweeten the rest of it. This was our favorite drink this summer, and everyone loved them. Very refreshing!

Wow. Best mojito ever! I followed the advice of a previous reviewer and made my own mint-infused simple syrup (so easy...just add 10 leaves of mint to the syrup and let it simmer for 10-20 minutes before cooling). I don't have a mortar, so used big spoon to mash lime wedges and mint leaves. I substituted syrup for sugar, adding more to taste. Fantastic!

When making this I use one packet of Splenda for each drink. I also grow my own mint in my backyard. I've been making this drink for about 2 yrs. It's funny tho, not many places in my town can make them to correct way. I first drank one in another city and was determined to learn how to make them. I pretty much do it the way this recipe says.

Made this for a group tonight and it was very good. I multiplied all the ingredients to make one large batch instead of individual drinks. Used powdered sugar, and only put in half the amount called for by the recipe. Muddled the mint, but did not bother to muddle the limes - just squeezed in the juice and then threw in the wedges. Turned out great.
this was yummy but we had to modify the quantity of all the ingredients to our liking. very tasty though!

This recipe is so AWESOME!!! I made it exactly as is and it was so good. I made a second cup and used Fresca instead of club soda and it was equally good but you could add more liquor to it this way without it being overpowering. I could probably drink 10 cups but I won't.

Love these things! Sugar syrup is a great idea, and you can make it a good while ahead since sugar is a natural preservative. The idea of less soda and more rum is one fine idea ;) @nance m - Splenda has the sweetness of sugar, but it doesn't have the physical characteristics of sugar, so you can't make a simple syrup using it. I know, I tried that making homemade liqueurs with Splenda, and it just doesn't do.
Easy and refreshing...I planted mint in my garden just for this drink. Its awesome!

When I say mojito, THIS is what I am talking about! Perfect in every way, this is an authentic version of a refreshing summertime drink. As an added bonus, muddling the mint and lime is a much better way to build up arm muscles than lifting weights!
Great mojito

Next time I will use this recipe but reduce the sugar. It was way too sweet (which is an unusual thing for me to say!). I made a simple sugar syrup in the microwave first-- it's the only way to get the sugar to dissolve.
Light, refreshing, and easy. For my taste, I prefer 1 tablespoon of sugar. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly.

These are perfect for a hot summer day! I made simple syrup and expanded the recipe to make a whole pitcher. Used the pineapple mint growing like mad in my front yard. And I loved them! In fact, I'm making another pitcher tonight!:)

I've used this recipe several times - it makes a really great mojito! The last time, I used the servings calculator to make 6 servings, and mixed everything in a gallon-sized pitcher. It turned out really, really good - may have been easier to mix with a simple syrup rather than just the sugar, but it worked fine for my purposes.

I've made good mojitos before, but this one isn't it. However, I think it could be improved. It's just way too sweet! I haven't modified it yet, but I'm guessing that about half the amount of sugar would be more realistic for this recipe.

The perfect summer beverage! So refreshing & not too sweet. I followed this basic recipe but used Molle888's variation and I couldn't make these fast enough! Do yourself a favor and just make these by the pitcher. Yes, they are a little more work, but your guests will really appreciate the effort....Enjoy!!!
Just couldn't get this to turn out right. It's a labor intensive cocktail, for sure.
reduce sugar - too sweet
loved it.
These were good and probably the best I've ever made at home but I still think the ones I get at bars are better.

This is the perfect mojito. My friend does something similar, except he uses a simple syrup. I think I prefer this method, it's much simpler and you can really control the sweetness. I'll definitely never use a mix for a mojito. This recipe is crisp, clean and simple.

Best mojito recipe! Thank you so much for sharing! My husband made it according to the directions and it tasted so good! I will try the simple syrup version if I ever have the time to plan it ahead. :) I like the idea of the syrup and I think I'll enjoy the drink even more with slightly less amount of sugar.

Ive made these three times quadrupling the recipe. Each time for the sugar I have used 1/2 real sugar and 1/2 splenda and the amount the recipe calls for is too sweet for my liking and not heavy enough on the rum. I have found they tast better using a third less sugar and a couple more ounces of rum.
If you prefer simple syrup like I do, try adding some mint to the pan when making the simple syrup and steep. Makes the simple syrup minty!
Better than anything I've ever had in a restaurant! Used Parrot Bay Coconut Rum.
Utterly fabulous.

awesome! tastes just like the restaurant/bar if you substitute simple sugar for the white sugar suggested here - I made it with the same amount run and simple sugar then followed the recipe exactly. YUM!!!
Very good, but I changed club soda to ginger all and decreased the sugar.
Very good! I used a citrus rum with it and everybody loved it!
so easy and so yummy! I didn't have club soda, so I just use sprite and put less sugar. It came out great!

Really excellent recipe, everyone loved it! I did use natural sugar instead of white, but that's just because it was what I had on hand. Great stuff, and so much better than any other Mojito I've ever had!
Great recipe. I let the lime, sugar and rum sit for a good hour before finishing the drink. I think that was part of the trick. Also, I used Bacardi light rum.
I planted mint plants just so I could make this drink! It was so good, I will make this again!!

Refreshing. It's important to muddle, because muddling releases the oils from the mint & the lime peel. Using sugar instead of a simple syrup is also important, because the crystals' grit releases even more of the flavorful oils. I only had lemon-lime soda & no club soda, so I did reduce the sugar. After making & tasting it with the recipe's proportions, I did add a little more lime, mint & rum (personal preference).

I followed the instructions to the letter and it was perfect for my taste. Delicious and refreshing, with the just the right combination of mint and lime. I'm cool as a cucumber as I write this on a searingly hot day thanks to that mojito.

Very refreshing! The amount of rum was just right. Like many other reviewers, I used simple syrup instead of granulated sugar. I'm going to try making the simple syrup with turbinado sugar next time around. This drink is perfect by the pool on a hot summer day. Added: I just made this again with ultrafine sugar and it is heavenly. Two tablespoons of sugar may be too much for some, but it's just right for me. Adjust the amounts of sugar, lime, and mint according to taste. The second time around, I added extra lime and muddled the sugar, lime and mint with the back of an ice cream scoop.
Very Very good. I did take the time to make the simple syrup and add that instead. Really really good. Thank you.
Very refreshing and authentic!
I use brown sugar instead of white and it gives the drink an incredible taste!!!

Two Tablespoons was WAY too much sugar. I made these a second time with 2 tsp of powdered sugar and squeezed 1/2 of a lime into the glass, rather than muddling the lime wedge. In the future I may also try simple syrup.

OMG! Yum!!! I used 1/2 lime, sliced fairly thin. 1/2 part Simple syrup (1 cup sugar & 1 cup water - warmed enough to help the sugar melt) 8 or so mint leaves; muddled together; then 1 part rum, 3 parts club soda. Then ice to fill the glass. These babies don't taste strong but watch out!

We just got back from Mexico, and were craving this delicious drink! This recipe was even BETTER than theirs! Absolutely make the simple sugar (1 cup sugar, 1/2 cup water in a saucepan. Heat very slowly, stirring constantly, until the liquid is clear). We used pint glasses, so 2 large spoons of it was plenty. I followed the recipe step by step, and we all really enjoyed them!

I am enjoying one right now and so glad that I tried this recipe....it is delicious and refreshing...I love fresh mint and lime. I did as some others and made a simple syrup instead of the straight sugar. Glad I did because it was smooth and not gritty. Thanks for this yummy and refreshing drink! Will definately be making again during the summer.
Tasty and easy to make. Healthier than buying a mix.
Almost as good as what we had in San Juan. Goes down quickly on a hot day, used simple syrup, may have to buy some lime juice to make in bulk next time.
Nuff said- in Sacramento the summer gets to over 105- this is the perfect solution. Perfect while BBQ ing make in pitchers for crowds.
This is so good and really easy! We have spearmint, the best mint, and peppermint in our herb garden, so I used all of them! It came out really good, but my leaves were small so I added more than 10!
Great starting point! As other reviewers I made a simple syrup instead of just the sugar. I also just made a huge pitcher used more rum and less soda. Delicious on a hot day.
First recipe I've tried for this drink; it was a success! Cheers!
I added more lime wedges but excellent guide to amount of sugar

Excellent mojito. Recommend using Cruzan rum to any others. It's smoother and cheaper! If you don't believe me all you have to do is compare it side by side to bacardi or malibu. The others smell like gasoline compared to Cruzan. Doing your homework on liqour makes all the difference in the taste of a good cocktail~ YUM!
Best homemade Mojito I've ever had, definitely restaurant quality . . . made these on Cuban night and everyone enjoyed them.

I made this recipe for my husband and his friend and they thought it was great!!! I made the first one exactly the way it said, then the second one I added alittle more mint and a tsp more of sugar.. It came out great!! Of course then my husband wanted a splash of pomegrate juice.. YUMMMMMMMMMM!!!! Definitely a hit!
Yummy drink. I used Vodka instead of rum.
Cool sweet and sticky! I did add more sugar cause I like em sweet.....like my men.
YUM YUM. The only thing I did different was to use honey because I can't have disaccharides. If you don't have rum, you can use vodka!!!
This is my favorite mixed drink now! I loved it sooo much I went out and bought a mint plant and a bag of limes. I had sugar water on hand for my hummingbirds, they have to share it now.
Good mojito! Like others, I used simple syrup.

Awesome Mojito. It's really easy to adjust to make pitchers - I made it for a party of about forty people and I was making pitcher after pitcher. I followed the recipe exactly and everyone seemed to like it.

My wife's favorite summer drink...looking for a recipe to replicate the local bar where these are served during happy hour and this fit the bill to a "T"...very easy to make...great for afternoons by the pool

I thought this was just okay. It needed WAY more mint leaves than the recipe called for. We added about 30 leaves all-told, and it was just about right, even with bruising them before adding. Not a bad "base" recipe, but I'll need to tweak it a bit so it suits my taste.
Made these Mojitos for the first time yesterday, and it was phenomenal! Will make it again.
We served these at a party and did not have enough, everyone loved them. Thanks for the great recipe :-)
Good guidelines, but this tastes better with a few changes. I used simple syrup and added mint and lime to taste (a little extra). Also, a little more run and less soda ;)Overall, a good recipe.

This is a real mojito drink like at the bar.Making the simple syrup is a must don't subsitute any of the ingredients. I made this for some people who don't drink mixed drinks and know they always request this when we have a gathering.
YUM!!!
Great summer drink, very refreshing. I put a sugar rim on the glass for presentation, and it looked as good as it tasted!
This is a "real" mojito. Very, very good and easy. Mint is very easy to grow in your own garden, so you can have fresh leaves whenever needed.
Awesome! If you dont have a motar and pestal, smash the leaves on a plate with the sugar. Then pour all the leaves and sugar into the glass.
Refreshing and absolutely delicious! Thanks for the recipe!
We used vodka, which was really good - it's probably great with rum too. I strained ours though, because I don't like pulp.
i thought this was excellent. i added 2 oz of rum per drink because i like them stronger. i used a wooden spoon to muddle and it worked great. i will definitely be making these again.

Picked some mint from my neighbors yard and mashed it in a bowl with an ice cream scoop. Used the simple syrup technique. The only problem was I didn't make enough (and I increased the recipe to 6 servings!)

Right on. I have mint growing wild in my yard so it's always available. I like how this recipe calls for sugar that you mix in when preparing the drink. I know some will argue simple sugar is a better way to go, but I thought the results were identical. When I made this, I didn't have club soda so I used carbonated spring water and it was a little less tart. I'm going to keep making it with carbonated water.

I think that the proportions are a bit off in this recipe -- my guests added quite a bit more limes and sugar to make the pitu palatable. A tip we discovered: if you're getting lazy crushing limes (and who doesn't after drinking a few?), add a tablespoon of lime juice and save some time.

I've been making this recipe for a while now, but have found a low-carb version for all my "atkins-type" friends. I simply substitute splenda and diet sprite for the sugar and soda--not sure if you can make simple syrup w/splenda, but I don't see why not...

UMMM! So good- gave 4 stars but would be 5 with my revisions. I took other suggestions and simmered equal amts of sugar and water and used that in place of the sugar. I probably didnt use the full amt of club soda- just topped it off. Very refreshing and yummy. Add more sugar to taste- I like mine sweet...
this drink was big hit! refreshing and easy to make. i did use simple syrup instead of regular sugar.

This recipe is almost the same as the one we use at my bar. We use simple syrup (equal parts sugar in the raw and water, boiled down) instead of granulated sugar because it mixes with more ease. We also just muddle one half of a lime with the mint (exactly 11 leaves), add ice, measure your rum (we use 2 ounces) and simple syrup, then shake that bad boy to death. Pour into a glass, and top with a splash of soda water. These are crazy popular at my bar. We also garnish these with a stick of sugar cane, but that is strictly for aesthetics. Annoying to make, but so good.
Excellant, highly recommended!
The best drink ever! This recipe is simple and classic without any tricks srewing it up. Thanks!
This is great! I adusted the recipe to make 4 in one pitcher and it turned out great. Everyone loved them. Can't wait to make more. I did use a simple syrup insted of sugar.

This is my favorite cocktail ever!! I tend to use more mint-and lime- alot more-- also we like turbinado sugar (Sugar in the Raw)instead of white- it has a bit of a brown sugar edge to it that mixes great with the lime. Thanks so much for this recipe.
This is one of my favorite cocktails

Never use a premixed bar mixture. Order a bourbon Manhattan to get a better grade whiskey and use a good grade vermouth. Both whiskey and wine need to be top quality, easy on bitters, generous with cherries and juice. A manhattan should always be smoooooth, velvety.
I added a tsp of cherry juice and a little more vermouth. Delicious!
Yep, liked it. Not sure if I prefer this or an old fashion...very similar

Great recipe and this for someone who likes a strong drink. 1oz vermouth will soften it and slightly more than 1oz will be the perfect way your wife will like it. Luxardo cherries are a must. Don’t go too cheap on your rye choice either and a great drink this will be.
A classic recipe! I like to use Rittenhouse or Bulleit Rye. Dolin sweet vermouth is very good.
Good!
Outstanding libation of the soul!
Yummy!

You have to have a basic understanding of vermouth before diving into this recipe. This recipe is fabulous (5 Star) using a good sweet vermouth. Those preferring drinks on the sweeter side can even bump that up towards a fullThe alternate recipe from Martha is also fabulous, but using dry vermouth makes it something other than a true Manhattan. There are also other high quality red vermouth on the market now
My favorite drink. I do not care for it with Bourbon though. I usually use a Canadian whiskey. It's strong, so I avoid serving it to novice drinkers or those who like sweet drinks.
Classic indeed! I prefer to use bourbon. While I don't typically enjoy sweet cocktails, this one straddles the fence between sweet and smoky....

I was given many years ago the recipe for 'the perfect Manhattan' as follows: 2 oz. 100 proof bourbon (like Jeremiah Weed), 1 oz. extra dry Vermouth, 5 drops bitters, 1-2 Maraschino cherries plus 1 teaspoon cherry juice. Serve over ice or not. You won't order it 'out' as others will not be as good.
Been a favorite for almost 30 years.
Great classic! Thank you for saying STIR...never SHAKE....it ruins the whiskey! We love it with bourbon.
This is a true classic- bracing for sure but yummy all the same.
This is dangerously delicious! We used Gretzky Canadian Cream because we didn’t have creme de cacao. This one is a keeper!
This recipe is DEa

Wow! This recipe was absolutely perfect! I was worried it would be too boozy but it was very sweet and mocha-like in flavor. Bought kahlua especial on accident, thought it was a better option but really it’s 70 proof, still worked great

This drink was great. I quadrupled the recipe and didn't add the full amount of creme de cacao as I wanted more of a coffee/espresso taste. I also used Starbucks double shot espresso with cream in place of the brewed espresso which comes in 4 pk cans. It was perfect and I won 2nd prize in a beach party contest! It was tasty! I also added a few brewed coffee ice cubes to keep the drink cold
I used Pinnacle Whipped vodka and topped with whipped cream - delicious. Sometimes I add shaved chocolate to the rim of the glass. Delicious!
I used Smirnoff Whipped Vodka in this recipe. I felt like making this "fizzy" so I topped it off with club soda which cut the sweetness a bit. VERY good.
Boring tasting drink.

This one is awesome. I moistened my glass with a lime wedge and then rimmed it with pink sugar. (See my picture) Added in some fresh cranberries and it was like heaven! Definitely making this one again!
I love this with a splash of "Fresca". Very refreshing summer drink.
Wonderful and especially nice with vanilla vodka.
It's even better with mandarin orange vodka!!!!
I squirted my lime wedge into my drink, then just tossed the wedge into my drink. Very good. I loved the tartness of this drink.

You can't go wrong w/a classic! I prefer to use Ocean Spray's Diet Sparkling Cranberry for some bubbles. I rarely have limes, so I tend to forgo the garnish. This makes a great weekend breakfast drink (especially if you don't live in Seattle and can't drink Manny's for breakfast...).
i have made these for years but have never used pineapple juice or orange juice i like it better without them
Followed the recipe, upped the rum and added pineapple slices to the blender.
Really refreshing and creamy. We liked the cream of coconut, even though my husband isn’t usually a coconut fan.
Excellent. I added just a tiny bit of grenadine syrup because we like sweet.
I love coconut, so I Love this drink. I used coconut rum and doubled the rum for extra kick. Very delicious.
This was so good I made a few more servings. I added a little extra rum & curacao only because one person I made it for wanted a little stronger. Otherwise, this was perfect .....
I made this last summer. Perfect as is, I changed nothing.
Really great. I will definitely be making this again
Great balance of flavors.
So refreshing and sooooo good.

Substituted sorbe coconut juice for the coconut cream. Skipped the pineapple ring and cherry garnish. I did not really care much for the curaçao liquor flavor. I was expecting more of a Kailua mudslide texture, but instead it was more foamy or frothy. Which could due to the sorbe coconut drink that I used.
Just sweet enough and totally delicious. Flavors were well balanced and tasted just as good as the ones we used to enjoy so long ago!
Not one change and from what I can remember, this drink was terrific! Loved it exactly the way it's called for in the recipe!

Just mixed up a batch for Father's Day celebration in a ratio of 1:1:2 of Parrot Bay Coconut, blue Curacao and pineapple juice and it was delicious! Will be on to round 2 here soon so I thought I should write this review first. Yum!
Loved it. One of my favs
Very tasty, after making a pitcher my husband and I both decided it needed more of a punch and doubled the rum.
Great summer drink. Very refreshing and my family and friends enjoy. We make it all the time.
YUM. So freaking awesome!
Just made this. So refreshing. Though I think I might try a little less cream and maybe a tad more pineapple
This drink is really good. To make it slushier add 1.5 cups of crushed ice. Also really strong pineapple taste so I'd recommend using a little less creme of coconut.
Fantastic drink!!!
AMAZING
I made this recipe for my sister's wedding shower and it was a hit! I've since made them a couple more times for my own personal use
I served these at a party
Really awesome taste sweet and yummy
Did not have coconut cream, or light rum, so I used coconut rum, and the drink was perfect. Just like the one I get at Moxies.

We tweaked it a bit, because we are island girls. We added a shot of simple syrup, shot of sprite, 1 1/2 oz coconut milk non sugar, tsp vanilla, 1 shot of sweet and sour, 2 shots of rum rather then one. It took it up a notch, and wow-ser it was great, delicious!!!!
This drink taste like vacation...it is very nice, has a subtle coconut flavor and is well-balanced. I can only drink one (and I like to drink).

This represents all things that are Hawaiian. From the beautiful color of the ocean to the magical tropical flavors. I used coconut flavored rum which gave it an added boost of coconut. No Hawaiian party should be without one!
Perfect, tropical,beachy feeling cocktail that my friends loved!

YUMMY! I made these drinks for my BUNCO group. They were a hit! Didn't know where to purchase "Cream of Coconut" but found it in the liquor store. Used 1/2 ounce of cr. of coconut instead of full ounce (on advice from the sales lady at the liquor store). They were wonderful! Start with 1/2 ounce of cr. of coconut and work up if you want more coconut flavor. I love coconut and 1/2 was enough for me.

This is one drink that will keep you Cool in the summer time and transport you to PARADISE! ! My Sugar Bear and I went to the Yard House after the movies. I asked the waitress for one of these and Man was it Yummy! ! The only way to make it taste better would be if I was sipping it IN Hawaii :):) Thanks AR, its a Keeper!
This is one of my all-time favorite mixed drinks! I usually don't add the pineapple slice or cherry, since it's just me and I don't need to impress, but it's yummy nonetheless!
No changes. Tastes wonderful
Needed more orange juice, than champagne.
Used it with an undrinkable Proseccco....this idea made it drinkable!!! hahahaha! Will make this again
Decent simple recipe. I will make it again.
Yummy!!!!!
Try this: Reverse the ratios with more juice and less alcohol... and then substitute POG juice for straight orange. Breakfast will never be the same!
The only change I made was using Barefoot pink champagne . I did try the poinsettia one but I think I'll stick to the traditional recipe.
Truly a good alcohol to juice ratio. Tastes refreshing and not too strong. Will experiment with different juices in the future just for fun.
Perfect. Made for Christmas brunch. Would have taken a picture, but we drank it
Simple and delicious!
Add a maraschino cherry or two
I liked this a whole lot, but I definitely like my mimosas to have just a little more juice. Next time I'll do 2 parts bubbly to 1 part juice.
This was the first time I drank a mimosa. Quite light and refreshing drink.
Simple enough and great for brunch time.
Back off a little on the champagne 1 part champagne and 1 part OJ is just as good.

I've never done more than equal parts of sparkling wine and OJ , except to add pineapple juice to soften the tartness sometimes. I'm not much of an alcoholic beverage drinker, and this is how I use up the champagne and proseco that I accumulate as holiday gifts and party leftovers. I serve it for brunch or luncheon get togethers. Mix your own --- go straight juice or wine (kept in ice bucket). Now the mixers can add a dash of triple sec to taste. What fun!
Make sure and use a champagne that you enjoy. The first time I tried this using brut champagne as suggested here and I didn't like it. Much better with pinot grigio champagne , my favorite.
I love Mimosa! This is the perfect proportion of champagne to orange juice. I saw someone had made this recently, and I asked my hubby to PLEASE bring home a bottle of champagne! :)
A mimosa for Brunch hits the spot. I did use 1/2 orange juice and 1/2 champagne. I garnished the mimosas with blueberries and clementine oranges. Some of my guests wanted ice. So, have ice on hand.
Excellent Taste!!

Traditional mimosa. I made a few "additions" and modifications due to personal taste: I made it in a punch bowl due to the amount of people serving, so be careful to watch the measurements when using the All Recipes serving totals. We have a diabetic in our family so I made a separate batch for him that included a low sugar orange juice and mixed in a minute maid diet mango drink. For the adults I added in the left over cranberry juice and pineapple juice I had from the cranberry whip recipe I made. For the children I made a separate version (with the cranberry/pineapple juices) but used a carbonated grape juice for the champagne. All were delicious!!!
How can you go wrong?
Cheers!

This is definately a part of our Thanksgiving tradition! My daughter, daugther-in-law and I gather in the kitchen to cook Thanksgiving dinner and sip on mimosas. I couldn't imagine Thanksgiving without these. It sure makes it more fun, haha ha.
We usually use half champagne (or sparkling cider for the kids) and half orange juice and add some raspberries to the glass. Yum!
A perfect ratio between the champagne and the orange juice. I also made a non-alcoholic version for my kids using ginger ale and orange juice, which was just as delicious!
Drink was good as-is but like everybody on this site does, I tweaked the recipe a little. Instead of champagne I used whisky and instead of OJ I tried ice. Perfecto!!!

This is a great refreshing way to enjoy brunch with my girl friends..or Sunday brunch with the family...Delicious..and you don't really have to worry about the alcohol content being too much.. 2 thumbs up!
Mimosa are usually 1/2 Champagne, 1/2 OJ and a Splash of triple Sec to soften the OJ. Serve with or without ice. But all are good !
Classic mimosa. Most guests asked for theirs 1/2 and 1/2. I used white zin champagne because I prefer it. Served with Mother's Day brunch. Was well enjoyed.
Favorite brunch drink to sip on! I use fresh squeezed orange juice to make it very special!
Classic!
Perfect mimosa recipe. My husband enjoyed making these, and will enjoy this with the leftover bubbly.
Thank you, Jodi!! I am 46 years old and have never had OR made a mimosa. As simple as it is, I appreciate the recipe!!

This is the first time I ever made mimosas. They tasted great and this is something very simple to make. I asked the Recipe Buzz on recommendations of champange to buy since I had no idea. Most people recommended a Brut champange so that is what I used.
I definitely enjoy making this drink. A non-alcoholic version would be to substituting sparkling white grape juice for the champagne.

I drank a glass of this on Christmas morning, as it only has 2 Tablespoons of wine per glass. I talked to some people on the recipe buzz about the best "sparkling wine" to use. I found that the mid priced ones worked the best. I got a bottle of Moscato D'asti, for about $11 at a whole sale club. It is a regular sweeter white wine I like anyway. It is slightly sparkling, unlike French champagne. And, it is much sweeter than the lower priced dry sparkling wines. I also used a favorite oj without the pulp. The proportions are perfect in this recipe, just follow it exactly.

That is the recipe, and I feel there may have been a few times I took it intravenously as well. Such a simple concoction if mixed in the right proportions tastes like the nectar of the Gods, but one spirit out of proportion can have disasterous results. Get the alcohol proportions right in the first two, and all is good. after that, you won't care. If the first tastes off balance, I usually have them add a shot of Roses Lime Juice as the most effective first aid(don't waste it), and watch the second being poured and accurately measured. A word of caution: DO NOT TREAT THESE AS SHOTS. Bad things will happen.

Okay for a fair or poor quality vodka. Vermouth take away the gasoline aftertaste. FIRST don't skimp on the quality of vermouth. Even the best vermouth is fairly cheap. The "Perfect Martini" = Chill a Martini glass AND store the vodka in a freezer or refrigerator. Fill a steel shaker with ice then pour in a good dose of QUALITY vermouth. Shake once or twice and then pour it out the bulk of the vermouth or until the shaker first just starts to drip (if you like a dry Martini) . Now you have the perfect amount of vermouth covering the ice in the shaker. Pour in 2-3 oz vodka, (If you have the means, Begluga Export or Gold line... or) Use a good quality Vodka (Belvedere, Kettle One, Grey Goose, Russian Standard Premiums, Stoli Gold) Shake slowly so as not to bruise the vodka (infuse with air and ice chips) until you feel the steel shaker frosting up. Dump the ice out of the glass and pour the shaker contents down the inside rim of the glass. I use a 1/4 inch thick lemon rind or if I want "Dirty" I go with two Queen olives freshly stuffed with Dutch BlueCheese. Skol!

Used with Crown Royal and Maker's Mark. Preferred with makers.

Made these by the recipe before and it's very good. Had a sore throat and was super tired on a very rainy day today so I kicked it up a notch and it was sooo good!! 1 peppermint tea bag 1 chamomile tea bag, 1/4 tsp pumpkin pie seasoning, 1 tsp honey, a long slice of tangerine rind, a dash of cayenne and two shot glasses of smoky scotch... Very strong an soothing and perfect
I haven't made it yet, but the recipe says to add the cinnamon and cloves, but cloves are not on the list of ingredients...
Delicious.... really opens up the sinuses.
Great just as the recipie suggested!
I use Ginger Brandy.
No yes I will make it again. It's a good single shot recipe. Take it at bedtime and sleep sleep sleep.

I changed this up a little bit from the original recipe. I did 8oz of hot water, 1 1/2 oz of jack daniels honey, 2 tbl spoons of honey, a dash of cinnamon, and a lemon slice. I can't taste the jack which was the whole point for me. The honey and lemon together make the drink taste awesome. I will be making this again.

This was perfect. I doubled the honey, water and whiskey (I used brandy), and just added a dash of cinnamon since I didn't have sticks. I also removed the lemon and cloves after five mins so it wouldn't be too strong when I got to the bottom. It turned out great and my throat feels much better. I recommend having one just before bed to help you sleep.
I love it!!!! it Helps with my tooth ache I used jack Daniel's Tennessee honey and I don't care for cloves or nutmeg so I left them out

A cold is in progress, knew I needed something special. Altered the recipe a bit. Used bottled lemon juice, a couple of Tbsp. Did away with the Clove. Used Honey whiskey. And threw in a Celestial Seasoning Bengal Spice tea bag. Someone should patent this stuff. it is so good!!!!
Fantastic!! My husband and I are both sick. We couldn't be more wiped out. This brightened our evening for the first time in days! Thank you for a great recipe! Cheers.
Best hot toddy recipe.....a huge hit! Definitely my go to recipe
Yum! I have a cough along with everyone else and this definitely opens the chest

Best Hot Toddy I ever made! I love cinnamon and nutmeg. I didn't have sticks, so I just used regular cinnamon. I also didn't use honey but maple syrup instead! Oh...plus spiced rum for me a whiskey for my hubby. So good! My throat is warmed from all the spices and rum. I may have to make another.
Perfect for my cold. This helps me through. I pour the water over my favorite bag of tea for added relief to my sinuses.

This is a very strong Hot Toddy recipe. I recommend if you drink this (especially if sick) to be ready to crawl into bed to drink this and stay in bed, do NOT go outside or try to do anything after you drink it if it's cold weather especially. Do not walk the dog after, just go to bed.

As an Irishwoman.... A little tweak. We use the same amount of whiskey (preferably Powers or Jameson) but use 1 teaspoon of white sugar Instead of the honey. One slice of lemon with the cloves pushed through the lemon, hot water, not boiling, and enjoy!

I was so skeptical, but after having numerous sinus infections in the past 5 years, and annoying cough spells from my horrible environmental allergies, I had to try an alternative. Nothing OTC works for me and none of the prescription meds help either. I just made this for the first time and I can breathe out of both nostrils, my ears aren't clogged anymore, and I'm not coughing for once. It made my chest and sinuses feel so much better!I'm thrilled and can kick myself in the butt for not trying this sooner!!
I Substituted the water for ginger ale.
Husband and I totally enjoyed this with a small slice of fruitcake. :-)
Awesome recipe! I made it with Sleepytime Vanilla Herbal tea as the base, and used Jack Daniel's Winter Jack Tenessee Cider. Sooooo good!

Sublime recipe when you have that scratchy throat "think I'm coming down with something" feeling, or need a winter's night panacea. I add a little extra honey, and some extra hot water, but otherwise perfect as is.
Very Yummy! I made mine with a tea bag as others had suggested.

Made me feel better, but that was probably the alcohol. Since I'm not a big fan of whiskey, I used Spiced Rum. It was really good! I did squeeze the juice from the lemon slice into the drink after letting it steep for five minutes. I think I may add a green tea bag next time just for the health benefit!
Just what the doctor ordered! Thanks!

I used this to help knock out a cold this winter and enjoyed it so much I'm continuing to use it - just in case. I think RAW honey is an important thing to try and get so you get all the enzymes. But, don't boil it and kill the good stuff. It's hard to find and sometimes costs more but see if it makes a difference for you.
Delicious! And a great way to help my cough. :) I would double the recipe, though.
Excellent (but potent) as written. Personal preference- I added 1 batch as written to 6ish ounces strong tea with a little extra honey.

Pretty classic, although the cinnamon and nutmeg not so much. Honey, stud the lemon slice with the whole cloves (keeps them contained in the lemon so they're not floating where you might drink one), whiskey (bourbon is tasty), and hot water.
Oh ya! Love me a hot toddy and this recipe is great! Warms the soul and so relaxing! Used pinches of spices in the recipe as did not have cinnamon sticks or whole cloves- tasted great!
This really worked to soothe a nagging cough. Also good with brandy. I used more the second time I tried, may try the tea bag as well.
Since I don't like the smell or taste of cloves, I left it out; used a little more nutmeg instead. YUM!
Only thing I changed was to make it with rum instead of whiskey---rum's my favorite thing. Oh...and I doubled the recipe. ;) MMMMMMM GOOD!! ?
You might try it with apple cider instead of water or tea for an interesting change.
My mom used to make Hot Toddies with orange juice and gin or vodka - cured anyone's cold and made them go right to sleep!

Liked this, although I've always preferred to make my hot toddy's with tea, and brandy with a tablespoon or two of honey and a teaspoon of lemon juice. I usually do about 6 ounces of boiling water with the tea bag and 1 1/2 oz of brandy for my wife and 2 oz for me :) Very soothing and very tasty.
Hit the spot. Made my cold more bearable. I made this with tea. Great stuff! :)

Jack Daniels is the cure all. I've always made this with a full cup of hot tea instead of 2 ounces of boiling water, in the past. However I like to follow a recipe as close as possible when rating it and I followed this one to the letter. It is awesome! I love the taste. (To be honest I probably wouldn't drink it without a sore throat, but it tastes great against my sore throat. I topped mine off with two moonshine cherries (cherries soaked in moonshine) and I feel great.
This works really well with Apple Cider instead of water. Yummm-O ! and my cold symptoms are forgotten for the night.
strong but my throat feels better

Many years ago I had a nasty cold that wouldn't quit. Grandpa gave me this recipe and told me to drink it sitting in a hot tub of water. Then dry off quickly and get into a warm bed and cover up with a down comforter and not throw the covers off. Boy, did I sweat that night. By morning the sheets were soaked, but my cold was gone! Now my wife has a nasty cold so I'm off to start boiling water. Cheers.
I think it made me feel a little bit better!

I used this recipe for a really sore throat, and I used a spicy tea bag along with it. I didn't have a cinnamon stick, so used 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon and left out the lemon. Next time I think I'll use either apple cider or apple juice. I'm happy to report that my sore throat is gone! :)
I used a lemon zinger tea, lemon juice b/c it was all I had, and filled the cup with hot water. Perfect for the crude.

I know it sounds strange but my father used to give me a hot toddy for woman problems and it did the trick every time. It gets rid of a nasty cold quickly. It is great as a relaxing night cap or for self medicating though that is an every now and then thing.
I've never had a hot toddy before but this had the nice warming punch that I was looking for. I have a toothache and this helped with it.
Can't wait for a cold or sore throat.

Use this when I feel a cold/cough coming on. I brew a regular sized cup of decaf tea and leave a little room at the top. Then I add the juice of 1/2 a lemon, honey, and whiskey - I am not a big fan of the flavor of whiskey so go light on that, probably use a half of a shot glass. Very soothing and relaxing on a rainy night!

Use this when I feel a cold/cough coming on. I brew a regular sized cup of decaf tea and leave a little room at the top. Then I add the juice of 1/2 a lemon, honey, and whiskey - I am not a big fan of the flavor of whiskey so go light on that, probably use a half of a shot glass. Very soothing and relaxing on a rainy night!
I just made these for a friend and myself and they were fantastic. The only thing I added was some shaken whipping cream on top - but they tasted awesome either way.

Well don't tell my boyfriend but he had the most horrible and annoying cough, he swears cough medicine doesn't help and refuses to make a dr. apt. Sooo, I made this drink for him about 45 mins ago and I have not heard a cough from him yet!

I like to make the water recipe but I also had juice from a fresh orange and 1/2 a teaspoon of vanilla. I also add brown sugar and a cinamon stick like another user suggested. It always helps me feel better and get some sleep!
Made it with tea, like others suggested. It was nice to have a warm beverage, but it didn't have a lot of flavor. However, I will keep this in mind for when I get a cold.

These are great for sore throats and the flu (or whatever else is ailing you). I leave out the cloves - personal preference. Bourbon works well in a pinch if you don't have whiskey. I got sick right after Thanksgiving and this was the only thing that gave me any relief. My husband thought these were gross, that is until he got sick shortly after and wanted me to make him one.......

I made this with tea instead of just hot water, I'm not a fan of watered down whisky. Didn't have lemons so I used lemon tea instead. It was delicious. My throat feels great and I'm nice and toasty warm. I would definitely make this again
My favorite drink recipe to have after shoveling the snow. Only change I made is that I can't wait the five minutes to drink it.

It did nothing for my stuffy nose but after drinking the hotty toddy (and no I'm not drunk and I do know how to spell the title of this drink), I sure didn't care about it. Goodnight ya'll! Oh wait. I did modify after tasting the final results, which tasted like watered down whiskey. I made hot tea and combined the 2 drinks. Served with "Fresh Pea Soup," "Italian Peas," "Fried Broccoli," "Pumpkin Seed Beer Brittle," and "Ham and Cheese Bowties."
This drink is the silver lining of getting sick. It's soothing, great-tasting, and knocks me out within 20 minutes. Thanks for the recipe!
The spices are a great touch. It is so soothing on a sore throat. Thank you so much for the great recipe! I can't wait till the next time I have a sore throat.

Except for the lemon, I add a pad of butter with some brown sugar. AND I use Meyers Dark Jamaican Rum.. Best hot toddy, hot buttered rum ever.Used to bartend at a ski lodge, now there were some happy skiers after a day out in elements. No colds the next day. hahaha..

I followed the suggestion in an earlier comment and used tea instead of water. I happened to have 'gingerbread' herbal tea, and so I omitted the spices, which simplified the recipe for me. We enjoyed it and will make it again. Thanks for the inspiration!

My late step dad used to make this for me (as a young adult of corse)and was just thinking about it the other day and went looking for the recipe, this is just the ticket, Thank you so much for posting.
Very good - but better with tea (Constant Comment a good match!!)

Didn't have whiskey so used vanilla rum and a hit of orange liqueur, on top of a constant comment green tea bag. Honestly I've been blowing my nose all day so after a few sips, not feeling tipsy, but the heat is helping to clear stuff out. I'm sure I'll sleep well tonight! thanks for the post
This really helped to relax my cold-addled brain and soothe my raw throat. Thanks.
I've been using this approximate recipe for several evenings now as I have a cold. It is definitely comforting.
I should get sick more often! how come this tasted so awful when my mom made it????????
I also made it with a tea bag. Added more water. Didn't have the stick cinnamon or cloves so just used a bit of cinnamon sprinkled on top.

Great recipe, but I changed one very important thing- I added a tea bag in the first step. I used orange spice tea, but I hear earl grey is pretty good, too. This gives the Toddy a bit more flavor, so it doesn't taste like hot, watered down whiskey. I also used burbon, and it warmed me right up!
I like to put the cloves into the lemon slice. Maybe just for fun...
Oh My! Definitely cleared up my sinuses - works almost as well as NyQuil. I don't think I'd drink this for pleasure, but I'll give it two thumbs up for medicinal purposes.
I made this for two flu-sick people, who are staying with me at the moment. It warmed them up and also it shut them up ;) Just the ticket!
The spices are a great addition to my traditional honey, lemon, whiskey, and water hot toddy recipe.
This was very good. Nice and strong and it helped my cold symptoms marvelously.
