I made this one night after a blizzard. We were out all day building the abominable snowman and we rewarded our efforts to a hot tod. It definately hit the spot. I'm keeping this one on my favorites.Thanks!
Strong, but very soothing. Kinda made me sleepy *LoL*
This was very nice. I'm really a light weight, so this relaxed me quite a bit. I don't think it cured my cold, but it made me not care so much about it!
Made mine with bourbon. MMMMMM!!!!!
I didn't like this much my first try, but being a whiskey fan I thought I'd give it a couple tweaks - mainly making it with hot tea rather than water, and a liberal douse of honey, and it was divine!

I'm feeling the first signs of a sore throat, so I wanted a hot drink. This was very tasty. I didn't have whiskey so I used Rum instead. This only fills up about 1/5th of a coffee mug though. If you want to fill the mug, you'll need to multiply the ingredients by five (that should knock you out for the night!) or else add a lot more water.
This is a nice recipe. I would change one thing however, that is to use Whisky instead of Whiskey. Being Scottish myself, it just has to be... :)
very strong, but good in the winter when it's too cold to barhop.

I really think there may be an error in this recioe. I was using an ordinary 8 oz drinking cup so I made this with water amount 6 oz. Otherwise, this is a decent recipe. I have the flu and made it tonight, it was very easy to make.
This tastes great and will knock your socks off, so don't have one too early in the evening!
yummy!

The Blueberry Tea cocktail has been a favorite of mine for many years and I usually ordered them out but rarely made them at home. I use a nice Earl Grey in mine instead of the Orange Pekoe and I think it's a very nice alteration. Favorite winter time soother!
I like to drink this when I’m sick with a cold too. I steep fresh ginger slices with the tea and add honey. Makes me feel better and helps me sleep.

I made this as described and it was lovely. It was so good that I finished that drink and immediately made another. My husband didn't like his, so I poured his over ice and drank that as well. Even better on ice. Is drank a real word? My only criticism is that it is potent and delicious and I am drunk. Next time i.will double the tea and halve my consumption. ACES!
I love this cocktail. I enjoy making it with an earl grey tea.

The classic west coast version of this is slightly different. Add a muddled wedge of orange to the sniffer and a cinnamon stick. Also consider a good Earl Grey such as Mighty Leaf to accentuate the citrus flavours.
And what makes it better is a tbl spoon of whip cream on top!! So good!
It is a great tea to relax in the evening. It will send you to bed with a smile
Tasted just like the Glühwein I had in the Christmas markets in Belgium and Germany! Perfect!
Made this for the first time this year and loved it! Not overly sweet and just enough spice to warm you up on these chilly winter nights!
This is my go to recipe! I have been making glühwein with this recipe for at least 10 yrs! Simple and excellent! Never fails
My husband is picky and even he loved it. And so simple.

Merry Christmas to all! I made a double batch of the recipe but swapped the 1.5 cups of sugar with 36 packets of Stevia to reduce calories. It was easy and actually took less time to turn to syrup. Ausgezeichnet!! Vergelt’s Gott!

Excellent! I also added anise and a few pods of cardamom. Also, I used a shiraz and cut the sugar down to a little less than 1/2 cup. It was a good decision, 3/4 cup of sugar would have been too much.
Delicious! I added some star anise and a few cardamom pods, and reduced the sugar by half. This is a favorite for sure!
Me and the neighbors LOVED this sitting outside handing out Halloween candy. Will be making this again!
It is EXACTLY like the original you can buy in stores. Will definitely be saving this recipe.
I always thought mulled wine to be a waste of red wine. So I made this with white wine. Still delicious!
Added peppercorn!
This was very easy to make but was far too sweet for our tastes. I used a Chilean carmenere for the wine.
This was too sweet for my taste.

I’ve never had mulled wine that I liked until I tried this. Fantastic! I added a bit of Cointreau and was careful not to let things boil. My suggestion: make more than you think you need if you want extra for later; you’ll likely not have leftovers.
I’ve never made anything like this and it was delicious. Definitely in my favorites file. I added a handful of fresh cranberries it was really yummy!
We recommend cutting the sugar in half. We squeezed 4 mandarins instead of an orange. The outcome tasted like Glühwein in Bavaria. Proßt!
Delicious! Reminds of the winter festival in Switzerland!!!

This recipe is a holiday tradition for me! It’s so simple to make yet amazingly authentic. After living in Germany for three years, I had to find a good recipe for Gluehwein and I found it with this. Thank you!
Seir gutt. very tasty version of my days in Austria
This recipe is perfect, I've been making it for a couple years now. It's now a family tradition to make this on Thanksgiving and Christmas.
So yummy, I wanted to drink all of it, but I shared it anyway. I will make it again.
I’ve been making this for several years in the winter and my family loves it! It’s easy to make and makes a great gift!

Used this recipe for this year’s Christmas party and it was loved by all! Doubled all the ingredients since there were about 12 guests. Keep the evaporation in mind and accordingly add a little bit more water and wine.

Tasty! I used the juice of 2 oranges, omitted boiling the orange halves in the syrup, substituted 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves for the whole cloves, and used 3 cinnamon sticks. Made this way the recipe tastes like the beverage sold in the Chicago Christkindlmarkt.

Growing up in Germany I drank gluhwein every Christmas, and this comes very very close to the real thing. I just remember it being a little stronger, maybe they added a bit more "umpf" in my hometown haha
Used the water, not OJ. This was really good. Reminded me of my days in Austria.
I used a good cabernet sauvignon. Came out fantastic!

Just got back from Germany and wanted Gluhwein like from the Christmas markets. This is very good. I didn't even have whole cinnamon or cloves so I used my regular powdered spices and I could not feel any gritty spice in my drink. I would use whole spices for company and nice glass cups but plan to keep using my giant economy size cinnamon for personal use this winter.

This was just like the Traditional Gluhwein I had Wiesbaden Germany at a Christmas Market last week. I made a double batch and added some allspice berries. It was not quite sweet enough so I added a little cranberry juice and it was perfect!
As is, will most definitely make it again!
have made this several times, and love it! i tend to add spiced rum into my mug before i pour the recipe in, as i like the extra alcohol. delicious with and without!
As a German Immigrant I am very familiar with this drink. My family always drinks it on Christmas Eve as traditional festivities Very delicious
Great easy recipe that tastes fantastic when done. Just like in Austria!

My mom is from Germany and she always made this for Christmas eve when we opened presents. Unfortunately, she had gotten to an age where she doesn't remember what the measurements were. This tasted just like how she made it. The only thing different was she didn't add the orange but I am sure it is a nice touch. Thanks for sharing and keeping our Christmas Eve tradition.
Good. Used a bottle of Merlot. Best when very warm.
This is the second time making this for entertaining friends. It's always a big hit!
Reminds me of Germany in the winter time!
Big hit at our Christmas party!

I use red velvet red wine. I followed are other recommendations to use orange juice in place of water. Some of our guests commented that the wine actually tasted better on ice. I noticed it got sweeter towards the bottom. A reminder to give it a stir while serving it. I will be making this over and over.
Came out perfect! I didn't have any whole cloves and substituted them for 1/2 teaspoon ground clove and it worked great.
Tastes like I remember it. Probably would've saved an hour if I knew to leave the lid off during the simmer/reduction.

Outstanding recipe. As SERVANTMARA suggested, I replaced the water with orange juice for more zest (same quantity) and I used 12 cloves (instead of 10). I used a Bordeaux wine called Louis Eschenauer. It was to die for. I will definitely make this again on Christmas Eve with the family.

Super yummy! I first had Gluehwein at a German Christmas Market here in town and fell in love. This tastes super similar! I'm diabetic so I altered a little bit and doubled the recipe. For 1.5L of Chianti red wine, I used water and only half the sugar...however I used 2 oranges instead of 1 and half a grapefruit. I'm excited to keep experimenting with this base!
So simple to make and soo soo good on a cold winter evening!!! This recipe is going in the box for later!
Tastes exactly like the one we enjoyed in Germany. The quality of the wine matters though, so choose with care.
Simple & delicious... like Christmas in a glass. What's not to love??

Outstanding recipe! My husband and I make our own wine, so. . . I decided I wanted to make a Christmas wine this year. We made a Beaujolais . After it went through its entire fermentation process and was ready for modeling, I then made this recipe to add to it. I multiplied the recipe, cut back a-bit on the oranges and added some of my own other spices! The taste was incredible. After simmering the entire pot we added it to our wine and then bottled two cases for friends and family for Christmas! Here’s hoping they love it as much as we do!
Making it for the second time. It is really good for the holiday season. Made as written with a cheap red table wine and it was delicious.
Just like the Gluehwein we've enjoyed at European Christmas markets. A little extra spice does not go amiss. :)

I followed the rest of the reviewers suggestions and substituted orange juice for the water and it turned out so much better than I could have ever thought. My only complaint is there is no point in making a single batch, its just too good.

Always a huge hit at family gatherings. I use brown sugar instead of white and it never seems to get thick and syrupy but maybe I get too impatient to drink it, it's good nonetheless. I double it and put it in a crockpot.
Way to sweet! I would cut the sugar in half, maybe even more.
I doubled the recipe for a party. Everyone enjoyed it. There was a little left so I poured it back in a wine bottle. I reheated it later and it was still delicious.
As the name indicates, it was a very easy recipe. I did not expect the gluhwein from Christmasmarkt in Germany, but the taste was in the right direction. It was delicious.
We had a bunch of people come over and this was a hit!
This is best done with merlot or pinot noir
Really good! I used OJ instead of water.
Just back from the German Christmas markets and this Gluhwine beats them all. Next Christmas this will be the recipe of choice for all our guests.
I loved it! I also used orange juice instead of water. It was a bit on the sweet side, but the flavor was incredible. It made an excellent christmas drink!
I trippeled the amount for new years eve, fantastic, The pot was empty everybody loved it, great recipe easy to make. . We used Yellowtail, red wine.

Fantastic! I've made it 4 times now and have even tripled the recipe. It takes me back to the Weinachtsmarkt in Deutschland and is a huge hit at parties, with family on Christmas and great for New Years too! I make it in a typical pot on the stove and once the wine is added and heated, I strain it into a crockpot to keep warm. I use a Merlot from Gnarly Head. It tastes great and makes you feel so warm and fuzzy.
This was one of the best mulled wine recipes I have tried. Great flavor, I added a little brandy to it as well.

Awesome and easy recipe! Also did not use water, opting for orange juice instead. Overall amazing! Felt like being in Germany all over again! Next time I'll use less sugar and a less expensive bottle of wine.

This recipe is amazing! The only thing I did differently was use orange juice (no pulp) instead of water and I cut the amount sugar in half because I didn't want it too sweet. I also added 5 cardamom pods along with all the other spices. I made it with Cabernet Sauvignon. Everyone loved it and kept going back for more!
Super easy, quick and delicious
This was a hit at my party!
I made it as written, but I quadrupled the recipe for large group. After it was done I put it in a slow cooker on low . There wasn't a drop left at the end of the party. It was a great hit!!

This is the perfect balance of spices to compete with any Christmas market in Germany. I have made it for years and do not change anything. I make the syrup days in advance and mix it with the wine just before the party.
Reduced sugar to 1/2 cup; added a few peppercorns, 1 tsp grated fresh ginger, 2 anise stars and 1/4 tsp cardamom
I used raw can rather than white sugar otherwise followed the simple directions. Unfortunately the orange lacked really good flavor so I did add a splash of juice. It was wonderful.

Served 3 years in Germany and this IS what they sell in the Christmas Market :) Saved all our gluhwein mugs and this does them justice, love it! BTW, if you have a lower-sugar palet, don't make it with orange juice, stick to water :D
Super good! I used a whole orange and a bottle of red wine, tastes amazing!

The flavor of this was great but it was slightly too sweet even though I love sweet wines and desserts....I suggest not replacing the water with orange juice as others suggest and cutting sugar back to 2/3 cup if squeezing the juice of the whole orange in. I used Merlot. Thank you for the recipe!

Tasted exactly like German gluwhein. Really pleased with it. Id change very little but found two cinnamon sticks were nice, a little less sugar and a little more water or replace the extra water with orange juice and it'd be perfect. After cutting the orange in half, put the cloves in the orange halves before squeezing the orange as it becomes much harder to put the cloves in when it's already squeezed.
I used brown sugar. And one more trick. You don't need to warm up a glass if you put a clean tea spoon in it while poring. Then just remove the spoon. Voila!

Absolutely the perfect winter drink! Delicious! The first time we made it with a very nice zin and WOW! The second time we used a cabernet and it was also fantastic! It seems that it doesn't really matter what kind of red you use, which is great. Makes it really versatile. We will definitely keep this recipe!

Things I changed: I used 7 cloves instead of 10. I added 1 cardamom pod. Of the 3/4 cup sugar; I split it 50:50 white sugar, brown sugar. For the red wine: I used a red blend (Llano signature red: Cab sav, merlot, malbec). I thought this was way too sweet. Also, I had mini mandarins, so I used 1.5 of those instead of 1 orange. In my tasting, I thought some almond would be a nice addition. I added a touch of amaretto to the mug, it tasted good. When I make again, I would use 6 tbsp brown sugar and almond slivers, or 4 tbsp brown sugar + 2 tbsp amaretto.
I am from the Northern region of Germany and we serve ours with a shot of SoCo,Amaretto or any other
I use this recipe every Christmas

I'm giving the recipe 5 stars even though mine took extra work to be drinkable! They didn't have either of the red wines I had hoped to use, so I got cupcake merlot. It was not at all like the spiced wine I had at a German restaurant, but I added honey to make it taste okay. I want to make it again with wine I like, because it was the merlot itself that did not taste good. I hoped the spices would fix that, but it didn't.
Delicious and cozy on a winter night. My hubby lived in Germany for a while and he says this is just like the stuff he had there.
Great recipe on a nice cold snowy winter night!
I liked this recipe! I added a little less sugar and I think If I were to make it again I would use maybe half the sugar.

Turned out really good. Though after reading reviews, had done some modifications. Added less water, and replaced it with orange juice. Also, added little bit of nutmeg, star anise and 1/2 inch piece of ginger while boiling the water (step 1). Thank you for sharing the reviews and this amazing recipe!!
It is spelled glühwein, which means so much as wine which makes you glow with warmth

Excellent! Just made it for 2014 Christmas. I wanted to surprise my siblings who joined us at our house since we are of German descent. Everyone loved it! since I make my own homemade wine, I have tried it 3 different ways. But my first batch so far was the best, using Cabernet & Concord with the original recipe. I am definitely starting a new family tradition. WEEZ
Pretty authentic, used orange juice in place of water and it gave a great flavor. Perfect for warming up on a cold winter day.
fantastic!!

Thanks for the recipe! I added another cinnamon stick & a few more cloves. This was perfect! I was missing the spirited German Christmas Markets we experienced last year. Your recipe helped bring some of the cheer to my home this year.
Amazing!

As the recipe stands, I give it 4 stars because I think it's too sweet. But that can be easily rectified by making the sugar syrup as in step 1, setting half of it aside, then continue with the recipe as written. When finished, add more of the reserved sugar syrup (or not) to taste. Forget Christmas, this is wonderful all year long! Oh, and to give this a Swedish twist, serve with raisins and/or slivered almonds in the mug. Absolutely divine.

Each time I visit Germany, I try to make sure it's at a time when I can hit a Weinachtsmarkt and drink glühwein. This is an excellent recipe! I didn't use sugar, but rather six packets of Splenda. I realized this was about 2/3 the sweetness that I would have gotten using the amount of sugar in the recipe, but I figured I could add more later, if need be. (6 packets were just right.) I did strain the glühwein before serving and then just put it back in the pot and set it on the kosher setting on the stove. After all, I didn't want the alcohol to cook off.

I am German and have had lots of Gluehwein in my life, funny enough I never made it myself, since you can simply buy it anywhere in Germany. Since I've been in the US for many years, I looked for a recipe and I really enjoy this home made Gluehwein, it tastes great and authentic and I like that I can vary the ingredients if I want to, such as adding more orange joice, or adding spiced rum. Thank you so much for sharing this recipe, it brings a piece of home to me :-)

Just came back from Germany and the Christmas markets and we were craving some Gluewien. I also used orange juice instead of the water and added 2 more cinnamon sticks. It was exactly like the Gluewein in Germany this way

Excellent winter drink! Like others I used more OJ than the one orange, but otherwise made as directed. Our au pair from Austria says this is just like what they drink at home. Will be a holiday favorite at our house from now on.
I doubled this recipe using half orange juice and half water. I made this with a cabernet from Sam's. It was a hit! Just like I used to drink in Germany.
The recipe, as is, is a bit too sweet for me. I had to add another half bottle of very dry red wine to get it to my liking.
Excellent!
A great, tasty treat. Thanks!
Too delicious! I'm not even a wine drinker but this has changed me into one!
Perfect! Would not change anything!
This is so good! We will be making more of this.

I make this every year. I lived for 2 years in Germany and loved the Kristkindlemarkt gluehwein. The smell filling the house is WONDERFUL, and brings back memories of walking around the market with the sounds of the traditional oom-pah-pah band in the background. Fantastic.

Wonderful spiced wine! Very simple not a lot of expensive ingredients. I followed the recipe until the end when I added 2 more cinnamon sticks while heating the wine. Nice, spicy, and warming. I'm thinking about adding some black peppercorn next time to see if I can get a spiced wine with a kick

I really liked this spiced wine - I think next time I will put a little less sugar in it (I think 1/2 cup would be fine). I'll definitely make it again - my friends and I enjoyed it today after our wreath making session - it's very festive!
My husband and father-in-law are born and bred in Germany. They said it tasted just like Gluehwein should! Yummy and makes the house smell wonderful!

This makes the best gluehwein! I've served it numerous times now, and I think it does taste better with the orange juice instead of the water, and reducing the sugar somewhat. I've also transferred it to my crockpot to keep warm, and used it while sitting around the firepit. Fabulous! Thanks for sharing this recipe, Else!
Absolutely fabulous. Compares with the ready made imports we get at Christmas time, only the orange gives it a fresher taste.

Hi from Turkey. This recipe is the best I tried so far, all family loved it so much. I added 2 orange, 1 I squezed in 2nd I added in slices and instead of removing I left all ingrediants in it. Even 6 days later the taste was amazing. Have a great Gluehwein. Thank you for this great recipe.

Cheap wine is the best!!! Seriously! My husband and I fell in LOVE with this drink while on vacation in Bavaria, Germany. We made this drink with an expensive bottle of Merlot, then did a second batch with a cheaper brand (Barefoot Merlot...$5.99 a bottle). The cheaper brand DEFINITELY had the RIGHT taste and smell! Reminded us of being at the Christmas Market at Marienplatz in Munich -after the following changes. The things I did different was scale back the sugar to 1/2 cup and used orange juice instead of water (and still used the whole orange) per bottle. Done this way...it's like you're getting the drink straight from Germany!
Very tasty! A little sweet for me the first time I tried it, so cut the sugar and water back to 1/2 cup each, and it suited my taste much more. Thanks to Else for sharing the recipe!!

This recipe was good with the orange juice instead of water, however the orange flavor was a bit over powering I recommend making a balance between water and orange juice to suit your taste. Still in general it was a great recipe, defiantly worth a try.

Delicious! Like other reviewers I used orange juice instead of water. I put the cloves into a tea ball to steep instead of shoving them into the orange skin (it was too tough and I broke a few cloves trying).
I love this stuff!!! I've made this exactly as written for years and wouldn't change a thing. This is the best time of year to enjoy it!

This a our new fall/winter staple!! I, too, used orange juice in lieu of water, cut back the sugar a bit and used a Shiraz. My boyfriend doesn't like wine at all, but absolutely loved this. What a great find. Thanks for sharing

Sooooo good with a few changes. Instead of boiling the water with sugar, I boiled store bought orange juice. I did not push the cloves into an orange peel, I just threw them in at the same time as the cinnamon stick. After 30 minutes I added the wine and then I added more sugar, orange juice and water to taste.
Everyone loved this recipe at our Thanksgiving dinner. Delicious, thanks!

We love this! I am an Airforce wife currently living in Germany. And let me tell you, this is WAY better than the stuff they serve at the German Christmas markets. I made it for our Christmas party, but I used orange juice instead of water as the other reviewers suggested. I couldn't believe how easy it was to make either. Everyone loved it and asked for the recipe. This will be a tradition in our home every winter...Thank You ELSE!

This was a hit, although it was too sweet for me. But people came back for thirds! The smell was awesome too. I did NOT do the OJ, but rather followed the recipe and moved everything to a crock pot. If you have a crowd, I recommend doubling this.

As many others have previously said, I too have fond memories of drinking Glühwein at many a Christkindlesmarkt when I was stationed in Germany. I recall being so surprised that I liked it because I typically drink Spätlese and find red wines such as Merlot too bitter. I made this with Shiraz, as a few reviewers suggested, to keep things on the sweeter side. I also used orange juice in place of water as many reviewers suggested. I think using a cinnamon stick and whole cloves are genius as ground versions would overwhelm it. I have tried many other Glühwein recipes and been sorely disappointed, however, this tastes just like the Glühwein I remember. Thank you, Else for sharing!

As many others have previously said, I too have fond memories of drinking Glühwein at many a Christkindlesmarkt when I was stationed in Germany. I recall being so surprised that I liked it because I typically drink Spätlese and find red wines such as Merlot too bitter. I made this with Shiraz, as a few reviewers suggested, to keep things on the sweeter side. I also used orange juice in place of water as many reviewers suggested. I think using a cinnamon stick and whole cloves are genius as ground versions would overwhelm it. I have tried many other Glühwein recipes and been sorely disappointed, however, this tastes just like the Glühwein I remember. Thank you, Else for sharing!

This is really good! I did cut back the water and sugar to 1/2 cup each. Everything else the same. Since I am the only one in my family that drinks wine I had to put most of this back in the bottle after it cooled. I thought it tasted better after it sat in the fridge for a couple of days. I like this hot or cold. Thanks for sharing!
This was incredible! I left it on low heat for about an hour to keep it warm and it reduced down a bit to a sweet, spicy, rich nectar. So my mistake made it even better! I'm making it again tonight.

Absolutely delicious! I prefer white wines over reds but decided to try this after tasting a "Christmas Wine" at a local winery. This tasted better than what they served! My husband asked me to make sure that I double the recipe the next time and to please have some when his mom comes over for Christmas dinner! I'll be serving plenty of this... It's gonna be a very Merry Christmas! :-)
this is simple and makes brilliant Gluehwein

Yum! We live in Belgium and have been going to all the Christmas markets here, Germany, and Holland. Our favorite part of the markets is drinking the different Gluehweins. I'm so happy you posted this recipe!! Used orange juice instead of the water and it was wonderful!! Will become a winter staple in our house now.

very good...can't wait for real cold weather and make this and drink it while walking down the streets with nicely lit christmas docoration...get a bit of European atmoshere if drinking in the freezing cold in a christmas atmosphere...
Yummmmmy!!! I added a little apple cider.....unbelievably delicious!

No need to buy mulling spices with this recipe (seriously, I picked up some mulling spices at the store and realized that the ingredients on the package were the same as the ingredients for this recipe). This was soooo good! The only thing I changed was the amount of sugar, I used 1/2 a cup instead of 3/4. I also tried this with apple cider and it tastes great.

Fantastic! I used orange juice in place of water and reduced the sugar to about a 1/2 cup. I used 4 cinnamon sticks and even added a few dashes of ground cinnamon toward the end. Often, I like to add a few splashes of brandy. It makes it a bit more potent, which is especially nice if your wine got a little too warm and some alcohol evaporated. I've already made this so many times, I had to make sure I put my review in.
This was a big hit! Very tasty.
I made this on a ski trip with friends. everyone loved it! Nice warm pick me up after a cold day on the slopes. I may try it next time with a little less sugar, seemed a little to sweet to me.

I even impressed my German friends. I used OJ instead of water and used a ton of cloves. Because of being crunched for time I made the 'sauce' several days before my christmas party, leaving in the orange, cloves and cinnamon. Reheated, strained the debris and served ... AMAZING!!!

Delicious! The only thing I would change next time is to cut the sugar down to half the amount. I used OJ as other reviewers suggested, for extra flavour. Looks pretty too in the Irish Coffee glasses.

Quite tasty. Try to pierce the orange with the cloves before you cut the orange. It is quite difficult to pierce the orange skins after the orange has been juiced. Do not worry if you are unable to pierce the orange skin with the cloves; just place the cloves and the orange flesh/peel in the sugar water. I strained the beverage as I poured it into the mugs.
I used a big bottle of Cab/Merlot and used OJ instead of water like others suggested. I also cut back on the sugar. This was delicious and a big hit at my party. Will definitely make again!

I love Gluehwein my husband lived in germany for the last three years and it is truly a favorite when you go to the christmas markets i'm pregnant this christmas so none for me till next year. An it is a quick way to make you warm happy quickly.

I am an American living in Holland and I make this recipe every year during the holidays. I also add a splash of cherry liqueur (Kirsch) and place pitted cherries (NOT maraschino) in the bottom of the mug before serving. Everyone loves it!
very good. i have a thermos pitcher and it stayed nice and hot in there. brought to a halloween party and everyone loved it
PERFECT!!!

I have been making the recipe since it first made it's appearance on this sight years ago. I make a double-batch, exactly as written, and it is always a hit. There is nothing like the way it makes your house smell. I am hosting Thanksgiving at my house and my guests have already checked to make sure we will have plenty of this around for those cold Michigan nights.
My husband made this exactly as stated. We used a cheap red table wine. It was delicious & tasted like what we've had in Europe.
This recipe is now a Christmas/any chilly day favourite. Followed recipe as is and it turns out perfect.

Well, if we had followed the recipe exactly maybe it would have been better. It was way too sweet for our taste. We used orange juice instead of water, as suggested by many people. If you are a wine drinker, especially a dry red wine drinker, don't use orange juice. It makes it too sweet! I will still be looking for another good mulled wine recipe. The search continues...
Found this recipe after trying Gluehwein at the Chicago Chriskindlmarkt. Tastes just the same, delicious!

This is an amazing recipe. It tastes just like what I drank while living in Germany. I made it for a bunch of friends for Thanksgiving and everyone really loved it. I kept getting compliments. That said, I used 2 bottles of cabernet sauvignon by Yellow Tail. I then doubled everything else but may have added a bit more sugar since I didn't measure exactly. The only thing I changed was I used mulling spices that I picked up from the store. I just put those in a large tea ball and let them steep. I also combined all the ingredients at once because I wanted a good portion of the alcohol to burn off. Everyone I know loves this and I give out the recipe pretty much every time I make it.
Everyone loved this recipe at a party that we hosted.
Thank you for this recipe. We put in less sugar, some rum - wunderbar!
This was great - only a couple things I did different - substitute water w/ OJ, 1/2 cup sugar instead of 3/4, and 2 cinnamon sticks instead of 1. What made it great was how incredibly easy it was!

I can understand why a lot of people would enjoy this-- for me, though, it was just too sweet, even after DOUBLING the amount of wine. BUT-- it was easy to make! And I found that allspice was a suitable substitute for the cloves, which I didn't have on hand.
Yummy and easy!

Fabulous recipe! I thought doubling the recipe to use two bottles of wine would be more than enough for my small Christmas party, but it went over so well I ended up making another "double batch." Merlot worked well, and as recommended, I kept it warm in the crock pot. I may try reducing the sugar next time as it is definitely very sweet, but in no way over the top.

This wasn't as good as I was hoping. I didn't really taste any of the spices, and I added extra. It was just warm wine for the most part. Took it to a Christmas Eve party and not many people drank it.
This was great for a holiday party that I went to. I used OJ instead of water, and it gave it more of a warm sangria taste. Very good! I used merlot. This was easy and fast. I will make it again!

I lived in Germany for several years and have missed gluehwein tremendously. I found this recipe this year and tried it using the recommended orange juice instead of water and a merlot for the wine. Amazing! Just as strong and fume-y as I remembered it (you'll see)! :) I will definitely be using this recipe again!

Will be making this regularly during the holidays. Double this for sure - if you are having company. Kick it up with a shot of brandy when serving. Puts it over the top! I used an inexpensive red wine (zin) and it was perfect.

I'd never heard of this, let alone had it before. I'm not a big fan of red wines, so I thought this was just okay. I drank the whole batch in two days, while it was snowing outside. Certainly, this is much better served hot; if you don't drink it quickly enough and it gets cold, it doesn't taste nearly as good. I made this exactly as written. However, the sugar/water mixture didn't get "thick and syrupy" within 30 minutes; maybe it's my elevation (6200 feet), or maybe I didn't have my "simmer" set high enough. I hope that wasn't a crucial part of the recipe. I also didn't get all the juice out of the orange halves (squeezed by hand), but they were pretty large, so I got a lot of juice anyway. But thanks for an introduction to this kind of drink; perhaps I'll find one that will "wow" me someday. Oh, and the wine I used was a 2006 California Shiraz (by Charles Shaw).
This is a bit sweet for me, but the spices are really great. I used a Zinfandel. Next time I may use something a little drier, just to offset the sweetness a bit.

WUNDERBAR! We loved this recipe. I did cut the sugar down to 1/2 cup, added an extra cinnamon stick, the juice of 1 lemon, and then strained the whole thing before serving. Made it with a simple Burgandy wine...I bet a Pinot Noir or Beaujolias would be good too. It was even better the second day after the flavors had blended more.
Warms you to the bone! Very tasty. Doubled the recipe, but followed it exactly and it was a bit hit last Thanksgiving.
PERFECT gluehwein/mulled wine recipe! Exactly the right amount of sugar and spice!
I made this many time already. I add more slices of oranges and lemons. Everybody loved it.
Great old time German recipe. Try other juices also for a change. (O.J., cherry juice, etc.)
I lived in Germany for a long time and this recipe tastes perfectly authentic. Great for a cold winter night!
This was so good! I took the advice of others and used orange juice instead of the water. It was a great drink for Christmas Eve.
It's great, but I tried following one of the other reviews, and changed the water for OJ, and it made it much too sweet. It's perfect just the way it is.
This was great! Everyone at our party loved it!

I had the pleasure of going to Germany several years ago, and this brought back some wonderful memories of that trip. This recipe is absolutely fantastic! My Husband is a diabetic, so I replaced the sugar with "Splenda Granular" and the recipe turned out great! Thanks for sharing your recipe Else!

I served this at a dinner party during the holidays and it was very well received. This is not a sophisticated drink - it's a good, flavorful somewhat sweet spiced wine that can be successfully made with an inexpensive bottle of red wine. I cut down on the sugar and used orange juice in place of the water. It was kind of like a winter-time Sangria. Yum.

This Gluehwein recipe was great, and so easy to make. My aunt from Germany makes this every year for the holidays, and this was my first time trying it for myself. It still wasn't quite as good as Aunt Helga's, but still very tasty and I would definitely make this again.

I have never heard of gluehwein but was looking for a festive spiced wine something for Christmas. My mother-in-law loved it, sister-in-law hated it and I thought it was pretty good though not what I was looking for. I followed the advice of others and used orange juice which made it too bitter for me - for me the water would have been the better choice. I enjoyed the spicy taste and thought it was more like a dessert wine.
this is my new favorite christmas tradition! not a drop survived!!!

I wanted something different this Christmas, so I gave this a try. I really enjoyed it. I used orange juice as others suggested, and was worried about it being too sweet, but it was lovely. I used an inexspensive French wine and sipped it while preparing Christmas dinner. Sehr gut! Danke, Else!

I used up a couple of bottles of partly finished reds(one Italian, one French) for this recipe. I used half brown/white sugar and orange juice as recommended by other reviewers. The kitchen smelt wonderful and everyone enjoyed it. I will be making this again for New Years to keep us warm whilst watching fireworks.
I made it last night for a Gluehwien Party and it was gone in the first hour and I tripled the recipe!! Good Job!

I made this for a Christmas party last weekend. I quadrupled the recipe and all if it was gone by the end. The only change I made was cutting the water in half and adding OJ for the other half. A very good German friend loved it.

My boyfriend is from a tiny village near Wasserberg in Bavaria. He was missing Gluehwein so I made this recipe for him and his boss, who is from Regensberg. They say that this recipe is actually what they call "Punsch", and that Gluehwein is heated wine too but a bit different. I dunno, maybe this is known as Gluehwein in other regions of Germany. Still, we enjoyed this recipe very much!
This is fantastic!! I also substituted oj for water. I had this at our annual cocktail party and I didn't want to share! Many people wanted the recipe. This is a keeper!!

The only reason I rated this a five is that there was no higher rating. I made it using burgundy wine and followed the suggestion of others and substituted the water with orange juice. Everyone loved it. I will definitely be making this often in the future. Thanks, Else.

This could be great. Unless you're a sugar addict, I'd cut the sugar down to 1/2c. Following some suggestions I used low sugar oj and still found this too sweet. For this I used Barefoot Merlot for the wine. Great start though :)

I'm rating this from a POV of someone who hasn't had Gluehwein before but was looking for a good mulled wine for a holiday party. Overall it was good but the general concensus was that it was too sweet, so we added another half bottle of merlot. I would probably make it again with the initial 1 and a half bottles of merlot.
Orange juice instead of water and this is PERFECT. I am told by every German I know that this is the original recipe. Oh so good!!! Also yummy if Cherry juice is substituted for the water.
Always a party favorite, especially when it's cold outside. I also substitute water with orange juice, add green apple and orange slices and a little berry rum which adds a real flavor kick. Yumm!
Very very good!

What a nice blend of flavors! I ended up having to use ground cloves rather than whole ones and I felt that their flavor was far too strong...next time I will be sure to use whole cloves as the recipe calls for.
Almost exactly like what you can buy on the streets in central Europe. I used OJ and just a very cheap merlot--turned out great.

Not very good. I made it for Christmas Eve, and I thought it tasted bad. Noone went back for seconds. I made it exactly to the recipe, but I did use cheap Merlot, maybe try to use a good, sweet red wine.

This is one of my favorite things to make for friends and family during the holidays! It is sooo yummy and spicy and sweet, it warms you to the bone. I use orange juice instead of water for added flavor. For parties, I get a cheap cask of red wine and quadruple the recipe. It never lasts long!

I made this for friends who were on a float in our town's Christmas Parade. I used brown sugar instead of white, and poured it into several insulated mugs with lids. Everyone wanted the recipe, and it helped them warm up after a night on a float. (I suspect it helped us all *float* home, too!) The only other change was that after the sugar/water/orange peel mixture boiled, I turned the stove off and let it sit while I did an errand. When I returned, the mixture had thickened. Since I used a small saucepan, I heated half of the wine in the microwave then added everything into a large thermos. My husband said he could smell it when the thermos was opened! Oh, since there was already orange juice in it, I also added about 1/2 cup of orange liquer for an extra shot of cheer. Will definitely serve again! Thanks for the recipe.
As good as everyone says! I always strain this thoroughly before serving it. Careful...you could drink a lot of this!
Oh my word. Utterly fantastic. I made this for my husband and he was just as impressed, the smell in our house was great and the deep rich warming effect. Lovely!! Many thanks. :)

We made this on a whim one night after a recent blizzard in the northeast. I was hesitant to dedicating a bottle of wine to the effort since the last spiced wine we tried was so overspiced that it seemed like cough syrup. But this was a great balance of sweet and citrus and spicy, all without overpowering the wine. I didn't have an orange on hand so I used juice instead of the water and it came out great, I've already gotten requests to make it again and can't wait to try adjusting levels of cinnamon, clove and sugar for mild variations on the theme. A definite winner!
My Mom is from Germany and hasn't been home in a while. It really made her holiday. She said it was just like home. Thank you.

One guest asked if it was potpurri. It does smell wonderful, but too overpowering to drink - maybe less oranges/cloves would help. While I found it easy to prepare, I give it a low rating due to its unpopularity at parties. Sometimes simpler is better - i.e., red wine as is.

I took other people's suggestions and used orange juice instead of water. I also doubled the recipe and used 1/2 cup of regular sugar and 1/2 cup of brown sugar. It went fast! My guests were asking for more. I will be making this again.

If I could give this recipe more stars, I would. We simmered the sugar, water, OJ, cinnamon and cloves on the stove and then transferred to the crockpot when it was time to add the wine. We started with 2 bottles of Kendall Jackson Pinot Noir, and it was gone within about 15 minutes. We actually had to go to the grocer for three more bottles of Pinot Noir! It was amazing!
Wonderful. I took the suggestions of many reviewers and substituted orange juice for the water, and think it's a great change. I'll definitely make this again.

What a great recipe! I was skeptical at first about using 3/4 cup white sugar. I thought it would be way too much, but it wasn't. When I sipped the Gluehwein, the sweetness was perfect and all those memories from visiting Christmas markets in Germany came back. Wonderful recipe.....thank you Else!
excellent recipe, very close to the authentic flavor as said by a visiting german friend

Yummy... and the smell is wonderful. I always make this during the Holidays, and everybody loves it (even my husbands sister who thinks alcohol is yucky). This is a staple in our house during the winter months. I usually cut down on the sugar by 1/4 cup, and add and exra 1/4 cup of water. We always buy the cheap wine for this.

I actually haven't made this recipe, but it's so similar to what my Mom used to make that I will probably be using it for a crowd. I'm familiar with making individual servings, without the water/sugar/orange step. Put some red wine in a saucepan, add some sugar, cinnamon stick, half orange w/ juice and heat. It is soo yummy and warming. Definitely gives you a glow, inside and out! :)
Perfect for parties or a cold day outside.

Maybe it was just me but there was something about this that I didn't care for. It could have been the brand of wine which I used (Black Opal) but the aroma of the warm wine made it very difficult to drink.

I have made this several times. I have substituted orange juice for water, an orange juice/pineapple juice mixture & an apple juice/orange juice mixture for the water. On all I used 2 cinnamon sticks instead of 1. Fabulous! I also substituted some of the white sugar with brown sugar. Equally yummy. I also tried it the original way, but added an extra cinnamon stick. It is really good when you get the mixture thick. I used local muscadine wine. No matter how it is fixed, it is hard to beat! A real crowd pleaser.
Not sure what I did wrong, but this didn't taste as great as I had hoped. A little too sweet and not enough clove/cinnamon taste.

This is amazing! I made a triple recipie of this for a party, using Tropicana orange juice instead of the water, and I reduced the white sugar a bit and added just a little bit of brown sugar. It did not get syrupy, but with that much orange juice I didn't expect it would. I tripled the cinnamon sticks, but still only used 10 cloves, and only one orange. For wine, I used 1 and 1/2 bottles of Sawmill Creek shiraz. I added 2 bottles while it was on the stove, and then kept it warm in the crock pot, adding another 1/2 bottle directly to the crock pot (the full 3 bottles wouldn't fit). The porportions worked out perfectly though. Very yummy, and very cozy drink.... will definitely make again!
Very good, I would use less sugar next time, especially if you enjoy the subtleness/dryness of red wine.
The perfect end to a long cold winters walk.
Some friends and I made this, and it came out absolutely superb!

I wanted this "crockpot" style to stay nice and warm for the duration of the party. Well, just forget that! It was gone within 30 minutes, doubling the recipe just wasn't enough (for 16 people). Everyone raved as they downed this rosy-warm aromatic drink. Have back-ups pre-made. The trick I used with the crockpot was adding 2 inches of water, turning it on high with a lid while the oranges/cloves simmered in the oj mixture (not water) to get it nice & hot. So, instead of adding the wine to the stovetop pot, I dumped everything in the crockpot after the oranges were finished simmering. This worked great but I knew I was in trouble when it only filled it halfway. I used Yellowtail Shiraz/Cabernet as someone else suggested. Too good! Will make as often as I can.

a tasty and spicy (and alcoholic) alternative to hot cider. i used orange juice instead of the water and reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup on a friend's recommendation--turned out great! as he said, it's pretty hard to screw this up!
Way too sweet for me, but yummy just the same.

I will never buy bottled Gluehwein again (it's so hard to find anyway)! Just the smell of this takes me back to Munich’s Christmas Market (Christkindlmarkt) that I visited as a child. Thank you so much!
This recipe was excellent. I used local plum wine for the red wine, which made the drink wonderfully sweet!

This is a wonderful drink by the fire when you have spent the day out in the cool, brisk air looking for that Christmas tree:~) It is one of my fondest memories of Germany....sipping on a warm cup, trekking through the Christkindle Markt taking in the sights and smells of Munchen! If you can get the wine "Bulls Blood" in your area, (I believe it is a Hungarian red wine) it absolutely will make the best gluehwein! When I make my Gluehwein, I slice the orange and place the cloves within the orange. Everyone has there own way of making it though, that is just my preference. Try this, you will LOVE IT!

I was in Frankfurt, Germany last year for their Christmas Market. All you can smell is Gluehwein, there is a vendor every few feet. It was the best thing I had ever tasted! This recipe is extactly like I remember it.

Excellent. I made this using two tangerines, about 16 cloves, and half a teaspoon of ground cinnamon. The citrus tends to get a bit of pulp into the wine, so strain it before serving if you mind pulp. Also, if you're serving this to people who don't usually drink wine, I recommend using a sweet wine like Shiraz -- I used a (dry) burgundy and even with the sugar, the initial taste was quite tart when the wine was served hot. This keeps well refrigerated -- just warm in the microwave when you want to serve it.

Outstanding!!! I made this recipe with two 1.5 L bottles of Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon. I quadrupled the rest of the ingredients and subsituted orange juice for the water. After simmering the juice mixture I transfered it to the crock pot set on high and added the wine. After it was hot I kept it warm. It happened to be Halloween and 30 degrees outside so I offered "to go" cups to the parents of the trick or treaters! They loved it! This is a fabulous recipe and one that I will make throughout the holidays! Thanks for sharing!
I made this for New Year's and even friends who don't like wine thought this was good.

This was my contribution to a house party I attended. I used Merlot that I bottle myself and substituted 1/2 the water with Tropicana orange juice. I also removed the simmering oranges from the pot, removed the cloves, sliced the oranges into thick slivers and returned them to the pot. I then transferred everything to a crock pot to keep warm. It was a great hit with the guests and I will certainly make it again, and again. Many thanks for this keeper.

I normally am not a wine drinker, but I was having guests for Christmas, one of whom is of German ancestry (my brother-in-law), and I wanted to serve something a little differentand special. This was a big hit; even I loved it. The only thing I changed in the recipe was that I substituted orange juice for the water. My brother-in-law commented that it tasted just like his late mother's recipe. Quite a compliment.
Very tasty and the wine is quite a bit stronger than you might expect! My family loved it on a cold December night!

WOWEE! This is good stuff! We had this on Christmas and on New Year's Eve and it was a hit both times. We used merlot and it turned out great. The only thing is that I could never get it to the syrupy stage so we just added the wine after simmering awhile. You won't be disappointed!
Yummy!!!

I've been looking for a recipe for this since I left Austria! I went there in 1996 to visit my friends who live in Vienna, and I had this in Krungel (a town where Badmitterndorf ski school is located) and it was great after skiing all day! Thanks and we enjoy it!

I'm not German, and have never heard of this drink before. But, just by looking at the ingredients I knew it would be yummy. Sure, enough...I made it for all of my friends and now they're all asking me for the recipe! THANK YOU!!

Absolutely great recipe for the traditional German Gluehwein! I served this just yesterday (12/20/03) and everyone loved it. I did add just a little orange juice, just because I used very strong homemade wine! Thank you for this recipe...will use it again next year!
I'm not a fan of red wine and so I used blush. I have also used white wine and it has come out great. I also add 1 Tbls lemon juice, 2 sticks of cinnamon and no water. Very good!

As someone who lives in Germany, this is the biggest holiday hit you can find! It is available everywhere in towns and the popular christmas markets and this is exactly how to make it. Although, I wouldn't add the water, but instead substitute orange juice to give it more of a zest. Drink it while it's hot!
This recipe is definately one to keep! We thoroughly enjoyed it after being out in the cold working all day! Thanks.
Great as a reception beverage to serve guests on a cold day. This was different and tasty, great during the holidays.
I've used this several times already and can't believe how good it is, thanks.
Delicious, sweet and warm
Made this recipe between Christmas and New Year 2000 and it went down a treat. I'll definitely be making it again. Advice... drink it whilst it is still warm; when it cools it's just not the same.
Thank you for this recipe. I was in Germany 74-77 and have been looking for this recipe. Again Thank you. And Merry Christmas!

Delicious! The day after the Super Bowl the syruped strawberries were sold out. I added 1/8 C. of sugar to unsweetened frozen strawberries. The ideal blend of sweet and tart! Super easy for a usual wine drinker.

OMG My first time making a Strawberry Margarita and this recipe was the very best! I did as one person said and doubled the amount of strawberries and it was the best margarita I've had in years! it was so easy too! I love it!

This is the BEST frozen strawberry margarita recipe! E V E R!! The only thing that we changed was the triple sec, we added margarita mix. We have used Jose Quervo gold and 818 tequila. It is definitely a must to try!
came out perfect, recipe very simple
Perfect amount for 4 margarita glasses. Not too strong, not too sweet! Everyone loved them.
Used fresh strawberries and it was great! Better than going out for sure!

This margarita is awesome. I did some modifications based on comments from other reviewers. I used 4 oz tequila instead of 6, I used 8oz frozen strawberries with no syrup and I added 1/4 cup of sugar. It was perfect. Strong but not overwhelming. I also added a few pieces of ice to make it more slushy. Everyone enjoyed. The recipe makes 2 margaritas. If you need more than 2, double or triple the recipe.
This margarita taste great!

I made this using whole frozen strawberries, agave syrup, and fresh lime juice to reduce the calories and it was delicious. I basically just looked up the recipe to have a guide as to how much alcohol to add.
Loved it!
Excellent. Will be using this moving forward! We sometimes throw half a large jalapeno in for a sweet and spicy version.
I thought this recipe was super easy and good. I used fresh limes and squeezed a little agave in.
These are the BEST margaritas I have ever had! I wouldn’t change a thing!!
These are the BEST margaritas I have ever had! I wouldn’t change a thing!!
fantastic and a huge hit!!!
This margarita was delicious, and a big hit with everyone! I don’t have any complaints. Didn’t take too much time to prepare either.

Super yum. I tweaked it to accommodate 2 people. Added a little fresh lime juice and used frozen strawberries sans syrup. I added a touch of light agave instead. Swapped out frozen Limeade with lemonade, and used Cointreau instead of triple sec . Great simple recipe !
Yummy!

The best ever! I just used this recipe and just enjoyed the best strawberry margarita ever! I'm giving this 5 stars and would give it more if I could. I'm not one to believe that you should rate a recipe 5 stars, if not followed exactly, HOWEVER, I used organic frozen strawberries and added 2 ounces of strawberry syrup, since my frozen strawberries had no syrup and I still think it deserves 5 stars!!!
Delicious! My guests enjoyed them!!!
Perfect Margarita!!!! No changes were needed...
It was loved by one and all. THe limeade really makes the recipe. When we ran out of strawberries we blended watermelon and that was also delicious.
so good!
so good!
Didn't have the strawberries in syrup just no sugar added and they where still perfect. Put extra in the freezer and had great frozen margarita ices!!!
Finally, a cocktail recipe that turned out exactly like it was supposed to! So. Good.
We added frozen strawberries and strawberry concentrate. Amazing!!!
As awesome as it was 10yrs ago. I don’t drink hard liquor often, but when I do, I go with the best recipe.

I added 4 oz of tequila instead of 6 and just added sugar to the frozen strawberries to make it syrupy. I got large daiquiri glasses and we ended up with two full glasses. Absolutely delicious. Only problem is that... it doesn’t last long ;-)
This is fantastic! I varied the recipe and used fresh strawberry, blueberry, and raspberry. It was great with and without sugar. Thank you for posting it!
I added 15ml agave nectar. Really good on a hot day.
Omg simply delicious!!!!
Very good. A little tart but still good.
Perfect combination of tequila and triple sec. I have a Margaritalville blender and this recipe made the perfect Margarita! I used Pomagranite juice instead of strawberries. YUMMY!
Delicious ! No changes, we loved it
I love this margarita. Will definitely be making again.

Delicious. Used a Ninja drink blender and it came out a perfect, smooth slush. Cointreau and Cazadores tequila were my choices along with generic limeade concentrate and a cup filled with frozen strawberries then poured over Daily's strawberry mix to the cup mark. It turned out strong but balanced and very drinkable.
This is one of my favorite drinks. It’s very easy to make and has become a staple at dinner parties in summer.
This is a foolproof recipe. Always tastes great and simple to make.

This was great! My best friend always talks about how great the margaritas at the Mexican restaurant near our house are and how she wishes she could get the recipe. She said this recipe was better! I did add 1/2 cup of sugar to make it extra sweet
This is soooo good! And so easy! We keep making this, love it!
Awesome! Made it with fresh cut strawberries cut up in sugar and used the syrup as well - - used a bit more strawberries than called for. Will make this all summer!
Definitely will make it again, it's so much better than pre made mixes.
So good! I cut back the tequila to 4 oz and bumped the triple sec up to 3 because I didn't want the drinks very strong. Easy & delicious!
Loved it!!!

This was a huge hit with my strawberry margarita loving friends. It even converted me, who prefers lime margaritas over fruity ones. I did add a little extra strawberries per other reviews. It's my new go to strawberry margarita recipe!

A friend dropped by and asked me to make her a frozen strawberry margarita like the one she had on her recent Florida vacation. A Google search found me this recipe. I did modify it slightly by using 4 oz of fresh lime juice and added 2 oz of cane sugar syrup for sweetness (instead of limeade). It went over well with my guests. Two pitchers full well received. Would have made more but ran out of limes, strawberries and Tequila. Refreshed my stock today!!!!

After working all day on home improvements, my family and I were thirsty. Looked up some recipes, and this came up. It did its job well. I am buzzed and it tasted great. Alcohol was at a reasonable level for one that drinks. Great Job!!
I loved this margarita! I actually used a very cheap tequila too so I can't imagine how a nicer brand would taste! I also used lime juice to make the sugar rim and it worked perfectly.
Super easy to make and great margaritas. Not over-powering, even for my alcohol sensitive wife. Using a good tequila helps a bunch. I will make exactly as written again.
Tasted like a restaurant margarita - I don't have a large blender so I cut the recipe in half and made it in my Nutribullet. So easy, fast and delicious!
absolutely a delicious drink
Was delicious but the alcohol was very dominate in this drink. Will definitely use maybe half the amount suggested. Was way too strong but still the flavor was great
I love a good strawberry margarita and this is delicious
Quick easy and delicious!!!!
This was sooo good! Will be making again and again...lol
It was a hit! Perfect flavor!
I made no changes and it was a hit. So good perfect for a hot summer barbecue.
Very good strawberry margarita! I used strawberry's from Food Lion that had splenda in them. Changed the flavor a little bit but cut back on the sugar and calories.

These were amazing!! I had four of them down before I even realized it!! I made them for a Mexican dinner I made for some family and they were a huge hit!! We had two pitchers gone between four of us in no time!! I used fresh strawberries that I added sugar to the night before and it turned out great!!!
This was fantastic! Used just a bit less tequila and triple sec and it was perfect!
No changes made. This was delicious. Made it for me and my boyfriend and he loved it too. I just sat the blender on the table instead of the refridgerator

My go to and I woudln't change a thing. I keep all the ingredients on hand so to make at any time. I will sometimes make without adding the strawberries in syrup for a lime version, still just as good.

It was ok I have definitely had better margaritas. I will stick to fresh strawberries in the future, I felt like using frozen just did not have the same strawberry flavor as using fresh does leaving the drink tasting a little watery.
Delish! I did add some extra strawberries, but oh so good! Will definitely make them again.
Also worked with whole frozen strawberries. added a little extra sugar since I didn't have the strawberry syrup.
Tastes like it came from a Mexican restaurant! I was pleased with the turnout. I wish it was a little thicker though. I put 4 ounces of tequila instead of 6 and it was plenty!
Mighty Fine !!
This is the Ultimate Strawberry Margarita! The only change I made was to add a little Stevia and use Lime Juice instead of Limeade, to cut down on the sugar.
Fantastic.. I did the strawberries without the syrup. Still tastes perfect!

This was the best-tasting strawberry margarita I ever had!!! Varied the recipe for 4 servings as follows: 4 oz of fresh squeezed lime juice with pulp instead of the lime concentrate; 4 oz of tequila (used Alacran tequila - tequila blanco, 100% agave and 40% alcohol; any tequila blanco or white tequila will work) instead of 6 oz; increased triple sec Cointreanu from 2 oz to 4 oz; increased unsweetened frozen strawberries from 8 oz to 10 oz; added about 2-3 tablespoons of azucar morena to taste; placed all ingredients in the blender and added crushed ice until it was filled. Thanks for sharing the recipe and reviews! vgomezquita
Had to triple the strawberries and it still wwasn't enough strawberry flavor. Barely taste the tequila,too.

this was by far the best ever...my husband absolutely loved it and my daughters said it was the best they have ever tasted...I don't drink, so I went on their recommendations...they are a very critical crew so I always defer to their tastes! LOVED IT
Definitely an ultimate margarita! A big hit at get togethers.

Good but use frozen or fresh strawberries without sugar! You could use simple syrup for more sweetness BUT I found the sugar in the lime concentrate to be sweet enough for me! Rub rim of glass with a slice of lime before adding sugar!

Never made these before. Was in the mood and found this recipe. Due to the reviews, I followed the recipe with the sweetened strawberries, and added frozen strawberries and less ice. Awesome! We are on the fourth pitcher!
Best strawberry margarita ever!!
Perfection!
Everyone loved it, including the kids (virgin).

First time making a Margarita - it will not be my last!! The only thing I changed was to use fresh strawberries - 3 cups to 1/4 cup sugar - semi froze them and added ALL of them into the blender - which did cut down a bit on the ice...maybe 4+ cups of ice. My Favorite Five (the girls I work with) LOVED them!!! They were so impressed - especially since they know that I have never mixed a drink before in my life....and that has been a long time ;) I mix everything together (except Ice) and freeze. When ready to use I thaw and blend with ice.
Even the guys skipped their beers and drank these. Soooo yummy.

This makes for a great Margarita! Sugar or salt on the glass works. I used Orange flavored Triple Sec, and added whipped cream to the top of the finished product. Rave reviews. Infinitely cheaper than what you'd pay at a restaurant, yet every bit as good

Delicious! I used the whole can of limeade and adjusted the other ingredients accordingly. I blended everything up (minus the ice), and froze it in a container in the freezer. When I needed it, it was perfectly slushy and delicious. A definite keeper~YUM! Thanks for sharing. :)
I made these for our Fantasy Football draft. Being the only girl in the league, I thought I'd get the whole pitcher. The beer drinking guys loved them! Buy more supplies than you think you'll need.
I did a virgin strawberry margarita and it turned out great. Had to add some water to make up for the lack of liquid but still turned out great!
Great! Will make again and again! I add extra lime just because I like the citrus taste but this recipe rocks!
It was ok... not great.
This is the very best formula. Also I sub rum for tequila for a Dacquiri. I have used one pound of frozen ,no sugar berries. If you like less sugar .bill mandell

These are delicious! I put it all in the blender at once and it was so easy. The people who did not rate them well need to learn that this is the kind of recipe you tweek to your liking. If you think it has too much alcohol or not enough, change the amount! For my preferences, this margharita was perfect. Also, none of us thought it was too sweet. There's enough techila to tone down the sweetness in the other ingredients. Just play with it. If you are worried about the frozen strawberries with syrup being too sweet, use only 4 oz of them and add either plain frozen or fresh berries. It's not hard people. Don't lower the rating of the recipe by several stars just because all of us have different taste buds.

Very good drink; we use 2 oz of frozen strawberry punch concentrate and 2 oz of limeade, to bring out the strawberry flavor. We also coat the glasses with sugar instead of salt. Because the drink is so fruity, we make a batch w/o tequila for the kids, or pour them some before adding a little less tequila for our drinks. Also, a good orange liqueur will work as a substitute for triple sec.
Tweaked this recipe a bit after reading others on the Internet. Why aren't the ingredients measured in ounces, like every other drink recipe??????????

Fantastic! We made a triple batch for our Cinco de Mayo fiesta! I mixed up all the ingredients (except the ice) the night before, put it in a Ziploc and put it in the freezer. We crushed up a blender full of ice, poured 1/3 of the mixture in, stirred it and then spooned it into our glasses. Repeated twice throughout the night! HUGE hit! Can't wait to experiment with other flavor combos all summer long!
I usually don't rate recipes but this is really good. Highly recommend it. I added a few fresh strawberries to the recipe. You will love it.

Made with fresh strawberries, just slice them put them in a ziplock bag with just enough sugar to coat and freeze them. I can't tell you how many times I heard our guest say, "Dang these are good margaritas".

Excellent margarita recipe! At last, I have found "my" drink. Strong enough to kick my butt, but delicious enough to enjoy getting there. I just cannot rave about this drink enough. And it was so easy! I never try mixing drinks, but this one turned out delicious on the first attempt just by following the easy directions. So great!

This is a great frozen margarita recipe. It was ridiculously easy to make and tasted so good! My sister-in-law noted that many times strawberry margaritas can be too sweet. However, the lime in this margarita recipe provides some tartness that balances it out. I will definitely use this recipe again.

I love the recipe, but I used the frozen the first time, and I had to double it to get strawberry flavor. The next time I used about 10 fresh strawberries and some juice from the frozen, and that helped. I like the recipe, but you need to decide where your flavor is with the strawberry. Good luck.
Love this recipe! Just perfect! I get compliments on it all the time!
Excellent. Thanks for sharing.
This is so delicious!! It taste exactly like the one they serve at a popular local Mexican resteraunt we go to!! Very refreshing!Try it,you will be happy you did!!

They taste great. I'm not much of a tequila drinker so I only did 4 oz of tequila. Only downside is the morning after...so much sugar = nasty hangover. EDIT: I'm here to update and tell you all that I think the culprit of hangovers is the triple sec. Last night we did these bad boys and only used the tequila, strawberries, and frozen limeade and feeling perfectly fine today. :)
Absolutely outstanding recipe! :::CHEERS:::

Tried this recipe last night and it was fabulous! I did sub Grand Marnier for the triple sec and my own frozen berries with a simple syrup for the store-bought frozen berries, but I'm sure it would have been fine as written. My husband and I both loved it and will definitely be making it again!
this is soooooo good!! didnt add the tequila..but still had that great taste! :) thanks.
I'm not old enough to drink but my mom made this without alcohol for my brothers and I and we just loved it!
Wow! Refreshing, tasty and very easy. Of course, I used more alcohol than called for in the recipe. :)
Wow, excellent flavor! Very strong though. I had to add more strawberries and limeade, but if you like a strong margarita, you will love this recipe.

Great recipe... tweaked slightly. Used 6 ounces Simply Lime limeade (not frozen or from concentrate) and used "two handfuls" of frozen strawberries (no syrup). I made it once with tequila, but the second time I substituted the tequila with Cruzan strawberry rum (which everyone preferred), and I added 2 ounces of orange juice. Talk about delicious! Thanks!
fantastic...
I agree, I would'nt change a thing. Delicious !!!
Great base recipe easy to remember! I substituted Grand Marnier for the triple sec and frozen whole berries not in syrup that I had in freezer. Yummy

I make this recipe and it is good but becomes "OUT of THIS WORLD" with eliminating the Triple Sec and adding 1oz. of Orange Extract, Wow!! Then top it with homemade whipped cream and a mint leaf from the garden coated with some of the powdered sugar.The Orange Extract to me adds the little thing that seems to be missing.

They tasted really good, but I felt they didn't have enough alcohol. I was drinking before trying these, and by the time I got half way done with mine, I had already sobered up. They were also very thick, so you couldn't really drink them so much as eat them. My fiance abandoned his entirely. If I try making them again I'll definitely be adding more alcohol. Hopefully that will make them a little less thick.
these are great!
This REALY is the ULTIMATE margarita! It was very tasty, simple, and the ingredients were easy to find! I'll definitely keep this one around for next new years!!
I used frozen raspberries instead because my friend doesn't like strawberries. Kept everything else the same; these were phenomenal!! Strong, but yummy enough to hide it :)
made these for some friends last night, they were a hit! they were amazing! thank you :)

My favorite margaritas! I've been meaning to review this for quite some time. After I made these once a couple of years ago, they became my signature contribution to potlucks and parties. I rim my glasses with granulated sugar instead of powdered, though I must say, I haven't actually tried the latter. You just can't go wrong with these!

I did it a little different and added all the ingredients and then filled the remainder of the blender with ice and blended. I thought the taste of the limeade was too much. I think one blender full will do for the night...so next time I will try cutting down the limeade to 2 fluid ounces.

OMG!! Yummy. I thought my recipe was good but this was far better!! My husband absolutely loved the flavor, and the kick was awesome too!! I added a little more tequila and triple sec but it did not take away from the flavor!

I'm writing my review as I sip! (And sip, and sip...). I happened to have one of those bucket margarita mixes already made, with tequila, etc. But I don't care for the bucket mixture or the texture of the ice when it isn't blended. So I put the frozen mixture in the blender with fresh strawberries and some added ice and voila! I definitely think fresh strawberries make a difference. This will be a weekend regular!

by far one of the best margaritas. i used fresh halved strawberries with sugar which i let stand for about an hour and then froze them. i didn't have triple sec but had peach schnapps i also had lemonade concentrate instead of the limeade. it still tasted awesome....thanks for the recipe, this will be my go to margarita recipe :)
Made these for a crowd & everyone thought they were tasty. Not exactly lilke you get in a restaurant - different - but just as good.
I've made margaritas many times and this is now my favorite recipe. The store bought mixes don't even compare! Perfect!

ULTIMATE IS CORRECT!! Me and my boyfriend made a pitcher last Saturday and we liked it so much we did it again the next day! We are strawberry lovers so we used more than the 8oz it calls for in the recipe. (We used about 12oz.) Also, just this past weekend for my girlfriends, I used this recipe even without the strawberries. So I might try even other fruits to use....mmmmm.... maybe Mangos!
EXCELLENT!!! This was a spur of the moment choice on a steamy day this summer. What a pleasure! This recipe is a keeper and something I will serve my friends and (continue making for myself)! lol
AWESOME!!!!!!!!!
Great recipe, will be it using over and over again!!!!

Nice margarita! Although not the best margarita I've ever made or consumed, this is a decent homemade version nonetheless. My only "gripe" is that the strawberry flavor was somewhat lacking (it's very subtle, IMHO). I think I'll tinker with the ratio of frozen strawberries next time to see what I can come up with. :) TIP: Moisten the rim of you glass with a lime wedge or cut strawberry half, THEN dip in sugar (powdered, granulated or large crystals). The fruit does double duty.... Not only does it allow the sugar to adhere to your glass (the fruit "juice" is sticky), it also serves as a cute garnish! Thanks for sharing, JTWTECH! You made taco night yum-o. :-)

Was invited to a margarita loving fiends house to soak in her new hot tub....made these Strawberry Margaritas and they were a big hit! Added a bit less tequila and used fresh picked strawberries, they were awesome! The flavor from the limeade was just right. Don't know what was more relaxing, the long soak in the hot tub or these wonderful cocktails! Will def make these again! Midnight Margaritas anyone?!

I'm drinking this right now and it's strong as, well let's just say I'm on they way to a long nap. It tastes great, looks great, and packs a powerful punch. I was going to make it again tomorrow, but I don't think I can handle this sandman for two consecutive days. Beware: it's delicsh!
This was a good recipe but I'd cut down a little o both alcohols, I like my drinks sting but these are Too strong. Thanks for the recipe

Made these for a 4th of July party last night. Planned on making a couple of pitchers and ended up having to run to the store and get more LimeAde because we went through MANY pitchers!! This is by far one of the tastiest Margaritas I have ever had! But be warned, it really packs a punch!!!
This was amazing. Used fresh strawberries because we were trying to use them up, and there were perfect chunks of berries in the drink. We plan on drinking this all summer long!!
Oh ya, come to Momma.
OMG!!! I am in love!! I have searched for a good margarita recipe for a year! This is the absolute best!!! I'm so happy I found it!!!
Perfect!

these are excellent and just the most perfect taste. I've made them before without the lime concentrate and that is exactle what was missing. The lime concentrate is what makes them perfect. YUM YUM!!!
Easy to make! Tasty as all get out! No need for the sugar on the glass rim, but it looks great.
I used fresh strawberries instead frozen and it was PERFECT. Will be making this again, and again, and again!
This recipe is so delicious. I can not wait to try other flavors. THANK YOU!!!!!
They were absolutely amazing. I decided to only use frozen fruit to avoid the watering down that usually happens and they were gone in a flash. We loved the combination of strawberries & mango.
perfect...though I used fresh strawberries blended with about a 1/4 cup of powdered sugar.
Very yummy! Made it for a party and everyone loved it.
This is truly the ultimate frozen strawberry margarita. Its rare that I have no alterations, but I truly don't think anything could improve upon this recipe. Bravo!
followed recipes exactly--EVERYONE DRANK MANY AND RAVED. went perfect with jalapeno poppers spread with chips recipe that everyone also LOVED!!!!!
This is the best we have ever had...I get so many compliments and requests when we get together with friends....thanks so much for this recipie!!!!
This is by far the best Strawberry Margarita I have ever made. I accidentally added 6 oz of the limeade but we will be making these over and over.
Delicious! Read MOST HELPFUL reviews for good tips! Yum!

Uber-yum! I made this drink for a "Girls' Night In" and they were a big hit (the words "fabulous" and "delicious" were used liberally)! I did tweak the recipe recipe a bit, though. I used a 10 fl oz bag of frozen strawberries (no syrup), substituted half a cup (or so) of Rose's sweetened lime juice for the frozen limeade concentrate and added about half a cup of sugar. This drink is a PERFECT addition to any party. My friends loved their margaritas and can't wait to have them again!
Tried this one with frozen rasberries and it turned out great also!

This is how I've been making my margaritas for years! I tend not to measure things out, so some batches are a bit stronger than others. I've also tried it with frozen mango pieces which worked pretty well
Awesome! I prefer these to any I've had at restaurants.
MAGNIFICENT PERFECT AWESOME
MAGNIFICENT PERFECT AWESOME
Had some friends and family over for a cookout and they all LOVED these, now I am asked to make these every time we get together. They ARE the Ultimate Margarita!!

Stop looking, because THIS IS IT - the BEST frozen strawberry margarita ever. After trying many, many recipes that didn't come close to what I wanted, I came across this...and in 5 minutes I had the delicious, elusive concoction I've been seeking for so long. ENJOY!

Yum Yum Yum! I don't even like margaritas or tequila but this was so good. I took the advice of another reviewer and got good tequila (Jose Cuervo) since there is so much in this drink. I'll definitely be making this again!
This was perfect! I made this for a BBQ & everyone (even the guys!) loved this easy to make, refreshing drink! Yum! Thanks for sharing!

We LOVED this! I have a pretty large blender, so when it says to fill a blender with ice, I think we had to increase the other ingredients accordingly. We ended up using the same amount of tequila and triple sec, but increased the strawberries to 16oz and the limeade concentrate to 6oz.
